PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Harold Young) took the chair at 10.30 a.m., and read prayers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GIETZELT

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 77 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate of the Australian Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the State of New South Wales respectfully showeth:
That the plan by the Australian Postal Commission to downgrade postal and mail services throughout Australia, will place in jeopardy the existing services and the security of the mails by:
downgrading a large number of official post offices;
reducing the number of post offices open for business during the lunch period;
reducing the number of street posting boxes;
delaying telegrams by reducing the number of delivery offices;
downgrading post office services by employing untrained and unqualified staff; and
using private contractors for mail cartage.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Australian Government will take immediate action to prevent the Australian Postal Commission implementing any plan which will downgrade the postal and mail services of the citizens of Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CHILDS

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 748 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the Senate and Parliament assembled. We, the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth, do humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government:

1. Not raise any rates of sales tax, or impose new sales taxes, on any printed goods or paper products especially newspapers, books, magazines, pamphlets, leaflets and packaging and wrapping materials.
2. Be aware that any rise in sales tax on the goods would greatly affect employment and working conditions in the printing industry.
3. Be aware that any rise in indirect taxation is an unfair burden on consumers and/or wage and salary earners.
4. That a resource rental tax be imposed on foreign mining companies to make up any loss in revenue.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GILES

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 14 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate of the Australian Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the State of Western Australia respectfully showeth:
That the plan by the Australian Postal Commission to investigate the downgrading or closure of Goomalling post office places in jeopardy the existing postal and mail services to our community.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Australian Government will take immediate action to prevent the Australian Postal Commission taking any action to downgrade the postal and mail services of our community.
And, your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CHILDS

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 71 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate of the Australian Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the State of New South Wales respectfully showeth:
That the plan by the Australian Postal Commission to investigate the downgrading or closure of Adelong post office places in jeopardy the existing postal and mail services to our community.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Australian Government will take immediate action to prevent the Australian Postal Commission taking any action to downgrade the postal and mail services of our community.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: COLSTON

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 70 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that the introduction of tuition fees for post-graduate and second degree students will:

(i) severely limit access to such levels of study. The ability of a student to pay tuition fees will be the main criteria for entry to such courses. The restricted availability of Commonwealth post-graduate scholarships and the difficulty of finding part-time work in employment related areas further restricts the ability of post-graduate students to pay tuition fees.

(ii) result in higher attrition rates in post-graduate and second degree studies. Recent surveys have indicated that up to 50 per cent of students would be unable to continue their studies if tuition fees at the level of $1,000 per year were introduced. Inability to continue study is both a personal tragedy and a waste of the community's resources.

(iii) limit Australia's capacity to cope with technological, economic and social change. Many degree students who will have to pay tuition fees undertake further study to upgrade their qualifications to cope with changes in their area of employment. Many are forced to undertake retraining in areas outside their current employment because of declining job opportunities in such areas due to economic change. Further study for many students will bring no financial benefit but simply allow them to extend their contribution in the course of their work. For example thousands of teachers have undertaken further study to gain expertise in such areas as migrant education, remedial literacy and numeracy teaching, curriculum development and so on.

(iv) further restrict access to such study for women students. As a result of the abolition of tuition fees the proportion of women students in tertiary education has increased significantly. Mature age women students have benefited by the opportunity denied them when they left school.

(v) seriously undermine Australia's research effort. Approximately 22 per cent of Australian research takes place in tertiary institutions. The bulk of Australia's basic research is undertaken in universities. The introduction of tuition fees threatens Australia's capacity to cope with major structural change in the economy.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate will reject the introduction of tuition fees.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: COLSTON

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 27 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable President and Senators in the Parliament assembled. This Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

1. the proposal to introduce fees for higher and second degrees will mean that access to post-graduate and recurrent education will be limited to the rich. Australian research and ability to cope with technological change will suffer; this proposal must be seen as a step in the direction of the introduction of fees for all tertiary students.

2. the proposed introduction of a loans scheme for students will mean graduating with a heavy debt or being denied a tertiary education if loans are refused because a student is seen as a ''poor risk'' (particularly affecting women and those doing non-vocational courses); only the rich will be able to get a tertiary education without course restrictions and the burden of indebtedness.

3. in regard to the proposal to restrict eligibility for TEAS and the foreshadowing of reviewing TEAS levels only in the light of the availability of loans; it should be noted that any further downgrading of TEAS, which is already inadequate, can only further limit access to education.

4. the proposed restriction of Adult Secondary Assistance to those needing qualifications for employment will severely restrict access to a full high school education and necessary bridging education to tertiary education for those who left school early.

5. the proposal not to fund 30 Colleges of Advanced Education if they are not rationalised is an attack on teacher education. This attack will create teacher shortages in the mid 1980s, restrict access to education now and endanger the future quality of teaching available to Australian children.
Your petitioners therefore pray that:
(i) post-secondary tuition fees not be introduced for any courses or for any category of students;
(ii) that the TEAS scheme be extended so as to more fully meet the real financial needs of students;
(iii) that a comprehensive loans scheme not be introduced;
(iv) that there be no restriction of Adult Secondary Assistance;
(v) that the proposal not to fund 30 CAEs unless they are rationalised be rescinded.
And your petitioners as in duty bound shall ever humbly pray.
The Clerk-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Tasmanian Wilderness Areas
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that your petitioners are gravely concerned at proposed future hydro-electric developments in South West Tasmania. As this area is on the Register of the National Estate it is therefore of national concern and your petitioners humbly call upon the Senate to support a Federal Inquiry into South West Tasmania as recommended by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation.

Your petitioners therefore humbly call upon the Federal Parliament not to allocate funds or allow funds to be raised for development of roads or dams in the South West of Tasmania but rather to provide such funds as would enable the preservation of this area. This is a national issue and therefore Tasmanians should not be made to bear any financial burden resulting from its preservation.
Your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Foreman and Dame Margaret Guilfoyle.

PETITION.TITLE: Tasmanian Wilderness Areas
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that your petitioners are gravely concerned at proposed hydro-electric developments in South-West Tasmania. As this area is on the Register of the National Estate it is of national concern and your petitioners humbly call upon the Senate to support, or, if necessary, to initiate a Federal Inquiry into South-West Tasmania.

Your petitioners also call upon the Federal Parliament not to allocate or allow funds to be raised for the construction of dams in the South-West of Tasmania but to provide such funds as would enable the preservation of this area. This is a national asset and Tasmanians should not be made to bear any financial burden resulting from its preservation.
Your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the gallery of a delegation from the National Assembly of the Hungarian People's Republic. The delegation is led by the Deputy Speaker of the National Assembly, Mr Janos Peter. On behalf of honourable senators I extend to the delegation our best wishes and a very warm welcome to Australia.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Finance. Last week Mr Bruce Denham, the General Manager of the Electricity Trust of South Australia, warned that South Australians can expect to pay higher electricity charges until the Federal Government approves greater semi-governmental borrowings. He also stated that the reason why Victoria had a 20 per cent increase in electricity charges was the severe restrictions being imposed by the Australian Loan Council. I refer the Minister to those statements and ask: Is it not a fact that the Government's restrictive policies in this area have led and will continue to lead to extra charges, to extra costs to consumers and industry and, as a consequence, to increases in inflation and unemployment? How can the Government explain this inconsistent and contradictory economic policy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I did not see the statement referred to by Senator Elstob. But I think it is a fact that varying rates of electricity charges are imposed in the different States of Australia and a number of factors would be related to the precise costs. In some States there may be an attitude that there ought to be some subsidisation or equalisation of costs. In others there may be a very different point of view. It is always competent for State Premiers at Loan Council meetings to press their own position and to take as strong action as they are able to within the Loan Council to see that the needs of their States are met. I will have a look at the question that arises from the statement that was referred to, and if there is any information I am able to provide I will see that it is given to the Senate.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport. I refer to the current situation at Brisbane Airport, where air traffic control is not available between 9 p.m. and midnight, with resultant inconvenience to the travelling public. Is it true that controllers at Brisbane Airport are not prepared to work overtime, whereas controllers at other airports are prepared to work overtime to maintain services? If this is so, notwithstanding the administrative and/or political bungling that has led to the current shortage of controllers, will the Minister advise whether the disruptions at Brisbane Airport are caused as much by industrial action as by the operational shortage of controllers?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have some information on the matter which has been raised by Senator Collard. It is true, I think, that controllers at Brisbane Airport decided at a meeting convened by the local branch of their industrial organisation-the Civil Air Operations Officers Association-that they would not extend their normal shifts of seven hours without a break beyond 9 p.m. during the period of the current shortage. The principal reason for the disruption to passengers at Brisbane is the shortage of traffic controllers. We have been considering that question in the Senate and in the other chamber for some considerable time now.

ANSWER.PARA: Had the controllers agreed to work one hour overtime each night the inconvenience caused by diversion or cancellation of delayed flights would have been significantly reduced. Apparently the Department of Transport has not been able to negotiate successfully with the relevant industrial organisation for unconditional working of overtime at Brisbane as required. However, the Association has advised that controllers will work overtime and also agree to roster flexibility in return for fundamental changes to conditions of employment of air traffic controllers. That claim which has been put forward by the Association is being considered at present by both the Department and the Public Service Board. I expect that the Minister will be in a position to make a statement in that connection at the earliest opportunity.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did the Minister representing the Minister for Communications note the comments of the Chairman of the Australian Broadcasting Commission, Mr Norgard, on the Australian Broadcasting Commission's AM program this morning on the question of corporate funding of ABC programs? Did Mr Norgard indicate, or at least hint, that by providing inadequate funding to the ABC the Government was placing pressure on the ABC, in effect, to accept some form of corporate funding? Is it a fact that the Government is exerting such pressure? As part of the general financial squeeze on the ABC, does the Government propose to implement those recommendations of the Dix report that would in effect destroy the ABC's symphony orchestras by transferring the responsibility of running them to State governments and also by dismantling those vital and essential elements of Australian music-the training orchestras? I urge the Minister to give a reply to this question as there is great concern in the community over these matters.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know really what is behind Senator Mason's question. The facts are quite clear. This Government supports, and continues to support, the Australian Broadcasting Commission. It does so in a very major way with financial and other support. I understand that on 14 October Mr John Norgard delivered the C. G. Lewis Memorial Lecture entitled 'The Future of National Broadcasting in Australia' at the Australian Institute of Public Administration in Adelaide. Although I did not hear this morning's AM program, it may well be that it was inspired by this lecture. Mr Norgard's comments concerning corporate sponsorship for the ABC have been widely reported in today's Press. I take it that Senator Mason heard comments in this respect on the radio. Mr Norgard is quoted as saying that in the current situation concerning government funding the ABC needed to contribute to its own funding through corporate sponsorship and merchandising of programs and related material. He expressed the belief that corporate sponsorship could operate satisfactorily, given adequate safeguards.

ANSWER.PARA: The ABC favours the introduction of corporate sponsorship and in its review proposed that the ABC be enabled to introduce corporate sponsorship in carefully controlled circumstances. This suggestion was supported by the Dix Committee which recommended the introduction of corporate underwriting in the sense of the contribution of funds or other resources by organisations towards the cost of program production. Corporate underwriting would be subject to strict guidelines to regulate the practice.

The Dix report is currently under consideration by Government and the matter of corporate sponsorship is receiving close attention. A parliamentary debate will be held later in the Budget session, or when possible, to canvass this and other key issues within the report. It is quite clear that the Government is concerned to ensure the best possible basis for the operation of the ABC. We are very concerned-here I pick up the point about the orchestras-that the orchestras, which play such an important part in the cultural life of this country, should continue so to do.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is also directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, relates to the cost of telephone calls for people living in remote areas. I ask the Minister whether he has seen the news release from Telecom Australia about the charges for its new AUSTPAC services which states:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . Telecom will be taking an historic step in breaking the tyranny of distance for its data customers.
For the first time in the history of data communications in this country, charges for the transfer of data between computers and terminals will not depend on the distance between them.

I ask: Will the Minister ascertain from Telecom when it will break the tyranny of distance for its subscriber trunk dialling users and finally come to its senses and charge for all telephone calls in this nation on the basis of time, not distance?

TALK.START.PARA: —Although I have not seen the news release to which the honourable senator refers I am impressed by its content, which shows quite clearly the benefits which will flow to a class of consumers from yet another Telecom initiative. The honourable senator asked whether that kind of benefit can be extended to other Australians, namely, those of us who use STD services. That clearly would involve a policy decision by Government. I will draw to the attention of the Minister both the content and the import of the news release which has attracted Senator Lewis's attention. I will also draw to the Minister's attention the proposition which Senator Lewis has put, emphasising, I gather, the interest of Senator Lewis's Victorian constituents.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs and refers to a statement made by the Minister in the Senate on Thursday, 10 September this year. The Minister said:

QUESTION.PARA: We have made an election commitment to change the voluntary electoral enrolment for Aboriginals under the Commonwealth Electoral Act and to make it compulsory.
I ask the Minister what this commitment means, what precise changes are envisaged and what timetable has been worked out for implementing this commitment.

TALK.START.PARA: —The commitment means precisely what Senator Ryan just quoted in her question. The arrangements will be in the hands of the Minister for Administrative Services. As yet I do not know the timetable for implementation. But the commitment is one which stands.
—Can the Minister for Social Security inform the chamber of the present situation that exists regarding funding for Aspect House in Tasmania?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —This matter has been raised in the Senate on a number of occasions. I think that in response to earlier questions I have outlined that Aspect House received approval from my predecessor for funding for services to handicapped children, that a level of funding of approximately $60,000 per annum was approved and that funds considerably in excess of that amount were utilised in less than the first six months of operation. There has since been a deal of publicity and concern about the future of that project. As a result of that, a group comprising representatives of the State Government departments involved and my own Department has examined the operations of Aspect House and has reported to both the Commonwealth Government and the State Government. I was in the process of dealing with that report with the Honourable Andrew Lohrey, I think last week, when in fact he, for reasons quite unrelated to Aspect House, ceased to be a Minister in the Tasmanian Government. The matter is now, I think, in the hands of the Premier of Tasmania.

ANSWER.PARA: In response to a request which was made to us by the parents involved in Aspect House, both the Premier of Tasmania and I have agreed that we should hold action until the parents have had a chance to respond to the report which was made by departmental officers who examined Aspect House, and we have asked that that response be made as promptly as possible. Following receipt of that response, I will be further considering the matter in conjunction with the relevant State Minister from Tasmania. Needless to say, we are anxious to find an appropriate solution to the problem which has emerged, and I expect that we will be able to proceed in this matter in the same close consultation with the Tasmanian Government as we have done over recent weeks.

The matter is quite difficult. The matter involves handicapped children. It involves a project which did get some approval and which has now got under way, as I said before, on a very much larger basis than was ever approved. It is the wish of both governments, I think, to find a solution which will ensure that the needs of those children are met in a proper way and within the funds available to both governments.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. As a preamble I point out to the Minister that the Melbourne Age of 21 September carried an article in relation to West Papua concerning allegations of freedom fighters in West Papua firing on a Garuda airliner and a denial of same by the Indonesian Government. Today's Melbourne Age also carries a report from Port Moresby and again the Indonesians are denying that in this instance freedom fighters from West Papua raided a gaol to release some of their captive comrades. My question to the Minister is this: In the interests of information, will the Minister ask the Australian intelligence personnel operating in this region to make a factual report on these events so that both this Parliament and the Australian people can be made fully aware of just what is happening in our near north?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I will refer Senator Primmer's question to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and he will no doubt give consideration to the request that the Australian intelligence personnel make a report. I will advise the Senate as soon as possible of the response of the Minister.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ABORIGINAL LAND DISPUTE ON CROKER ISLAND

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct a question to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. I refer the Minister to the application by Aboriginal people on Croker Island, in the Northern Territory, concerning a land dispute between them and part-Aboriginal people who were originally transferred during their childhood by the Federal Government from Central Australia to Croker Island, that application at present being before the International Court of Justice. My question is whether the International Court of Justice is the correct venue for such an application, considering that there is provision in the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act for the appointment of an arbitrator to mediate between Aboriginal groups in such disputes. I ask the Minister also: What approaches, if any, has either group made to the Federal Government or the Northern Land Council to settle the matter, and what further information is available to the Senate on the dispute?

—I think it would be a matter of regret to all honourable senators that this conflict involving the community on Croker Island should have arisen. As I understand the matter-my colleagues from the Northern Territory could correct me-Croker Island had two communities; a community with traditional ownership ties and a community that was displaced and put on Croker Island some time around the beginning of the Second World War.

—In 1937, Senator Kilgariff said. It is this group that is demanding some title to part of the land. The matter is one of conflict between two Aboriginal groups as to who should hold title. It is disappointing that one group should have taken the matter to an international forum because I doubt that it is the way to resolve the difficulties. If Senator Kilgariff is saying that he thinks we should explore every other avenue for mediation and resolution of the problem, I agree with him. If we can use our good offices in any way to assist to mediate in this matter, I think all honourable senators would want us so to do. With relation to the particular matter Senator Kilgariff raised, namely, whether there is more information in the hands of the Department or whether other avenues are open, I will look into this and try to advise the honourable senator in due course.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Prime Minister to a statement by the highly respected Professor George Zubrzycki on the situation in Poland. Referring to the fact that the Polish people wanted political freedom first, which would lead to economic recovery, and that the Soviet Union realised this and was attempting to strangle Poland economically, Professor Zubrzycki is reported in this morning's Canberra Times as saying:

QUESTION.PARA: For a bloodless revolution to succeed, people outside Poland have to give moral and economic support. We must show civic courage in supporting the Polish people.
What commitment has been made or is to be made by the Government in respect of economic aid to the Polish people? What form will this take?

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not seen the statement by the professor. I know him well and I respect him; he is a fine Australian, a fine academic and a fine member of the Polish community. Of course, what he says deserves the utmost respect. The Australian Government, of course, shares the anxiety of all people of the free world about the struggle of the Polish people for their political freedom and, of course, is looking to the great sensitivity of the region in that regard. The essential question is specifically what commitment there is to economic aid. I do not have the details on that with me but I will seek them out and let Senator Harradine have them.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Education. Does the Minister recall the announcement by the Government of a tertiary loans scheme to be introduced at the beginning of 1982 to supplement the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme? Have details of this loans scheme been worked out? Can we overcome the problems which have caused the recent abandonment of such a scheme in Britain? In particular, will our loans scheme be available for tertiary fees, the prospect of which is causing some concern that some high quality but impecunious post-graduate students will be prevented from pursuing their courses because they cannot afford them? When will details of the scheme be announced?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government has indicated its intention of introducing a tertiary student loans scheme in 1982. I direct the attention of the Senate to the Prime Minister's announcement of this decision as part of his statement to Parliament on, I think, 30 April this year concerning results of the Review of Commonwealth Functions. The scheme will enable students to supplement their current incomes with amounts which will be repayable after their graduation. In preparation for the introduction of the scheme Ministers have been considering such questions as eligibility and administration. There have been fruitful discussions between Commonwealth officials and representatives of the Australian Bankers Association. Some aspects of the scheme have still to be settled, which may cause problems in having the scheme operating at the beginning of 1982. But the Government is firm in its intention to set up a loans scheme as a supplement to existing schemes of student assistance. As for the specific details, I will invite my colleague in another place to direct his attention to the matter.

ANSWER.PARA: Several years ago, when I had the portfolio of Education, I instituted a study of loans schemes. The report thereon is available for honourable senators to peruse. The loans schemes of various countries were studied and a wide variety of success and non-success was noted. That experience is available to the Government in making its decisions. It is aware that there would be students who would find the scheme a useful supplement in their journey through tertiary education. I will refer the remaining aspects of the question to my colleague in another place in order to obtain any additional reply he may consider it necessary to give.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Veterans' Affairs aware that recently a 61-year-old service pensioner died in the Repatriation General Hospital in Hobart a few days after his pension had been cut off? Can the Minister give an assurance that, in future, when a veteran fails to return the form which has to be completed before his income-tested pension continues, officers of the Department will personally check on the recipient to satisfy themselves as to the reason-such as serious illness-the veteran has not returned the necessary paper work? While the Deputy Commissioner of Repatriation in Tasmania said that there was no link between the withdrawal of the pension and the man's death, will the Minister acknowledge that this incident highlights the need for a more personal approach within his Department to these types of problems, not only in Hobart, as has been acknowledged, but throughout the country?

—The particular event to which Senator Coates has drawn the attention of the Senate was most unfortunate and, as I understand the situation, stemmed from the facts outlined by him. He was correct in saying that what he described has been the normal practice followed by the Department in respect of income statements forwarded to veterans for completion; that is, if they are not returned within a certain time the benefits are cut off. However, I believe that to draw the conclusion Senator Coates has drawn-that is, that the cutting off of income and the subsequent death of the veteran concerned were connected-does not stand too much analysis. Nevertheless, I view the matter with a great deal of concern and have asked the Deputy Commissioner in Hobart to examine his procedures and have instituted in the Department a wider inquiry in respect of the matter. I believe that we should bend over backwards to ensure that, in situations such as these, benefits are made available to veterans in as easy a way as possible when they are entitled to them.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for the Capital Territory aware of the motor vehicle accident, resulting in two deaths, which occurred on Parkes Way adjacent to Lady Denman Drive last Friday evening? Is the Minister aware that the accident occurred on the stretch of road where two people were killed about a year ago? Is the Minister aware that there is criticism that the two adjacent roads cause confusion to motorists at night because of the relative positions of car lights? Will the Minister seek an inquiry concerning this stretch of road, to ascertain ways of eliminating the confusion before further accidents occur at night in this area?

—I believe that the Minister is aware of the accident to which Senator Reid referred and that, in fact, another accident occurred some 12 months ago in that area. The Minister is very aware of the criticism referred to and is concerned about that particular section of the road system. He has seen the article referred to in the Canberra Times. I understand that the Minister has received representations on the matter and is seeking an urgent and full report on all aspects of the road system in this vicinity. As Senator Reid may know, the circumstances surrounding the accident to which she referred are currently the subject of official inquiries. Further comment at this stage could prejudice the outcome of those inquiries. As to the further detail which Senator Reid seeks, I will refer those matters to the Minister and seek his comments as early as possible.

—My question is directed to the Attorney-General. I refer to the program of prosecutions following certain arrests which were made on Anzac Day 1981 under the Australian Capital Territory Traffic (Amendment) Ordinance 1981. How many prosecutions have been dealt with and with what results in the Court of Petty Sessions? How many prosecutions remain to be dealt with by the court? Is there any realistic expectation that all prosecutions and any appeals will be concluded by Anzac Day 1982?

—Sixty-four persons were arrested on Anzac Day and charged with offences. So far four have been dealt with by the Canberra courts. Two of the informations have been dismissed and two other cases have resulted in convictions. However, in one of those cases an appeal has been lodged to the Supreme Court of the Australian Capital Territory. That appeal has not yet been set down for hearing. It is expected that a date for the hearing will be fixed early in November. As a result of the pending appeal the hearing dates of all the other cases have been progressively moved back as the dates which were originally set are reached. I suppose that is because the courts are waiting until the appeal is disposed of. These cases have now been fixed for hearing on various dates between December and May next year.
—I ask a supplementary question. Do I understand-I think it is just a simple extrapolation of the answer-that there is no expectation that these matters will be disposed of before Anzac Day 1982?
—The honourable senator can put his own interpretation on it. I have given him the facts. My understanding of the answer is that some cases may not be disposed of by Anzac Day next year.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs to an article in the West Australian newspaper of 12 October wherein the Archbishop of Perth, Dr P. Carnley, seriously questioned the accuracy and validity of the recent World Council of Churches report on Aboriginal conditions in Australia. Is the Minister aware that the World Council of Churches report stated that the Aboriginal infant mortality rate in 1978 in Western Australia was 53 per thousand, whereas the real figure was 27.5 per thousand, the lowest in Australia? Is the Minister further aware that the report stated that there were 100 active cases of leprosy per 100,000 Aboriginals in the Pilbara and Kimberley, whereas in 1980 there were only seven notifications in the whole of Western Australia from the total population and no indexed case for 15 months and that, whilst there are over 12,000 Aborigines in the Kimberley, there are only six known active cases for all races in Western Australia?

QUESTION.PARA: Is it not also a fact that the report stated that there was no systematic program dealing with diseases prevalent amongst Aboriginals, although there is a regular program, and that medical contact with Aboriginals averaged seven per person per year in 1980? Inasmuch as there are also a great many other distortions and untruths in respect to land rights, education and a whole range of areas contained in the World Council of Churches report, will the Minister report to the Government in detail as quickly as possible on the World Council of Churches report?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is true that some of the figures in the World Council of Churches report can be criticised for their accuracy. It is also true that some of the qualitative judgments in the report were ones which I have already publicly accepted and have said should be examined very carefully. My colleague from Western Australia spoke about an infant mortality rate of 27.5 per thousand. Whilst that may be the best Aboriginal infant mortality rate in Australia it is still far worse than the non-Aboriginal infant mortality rate in almost any area. We can look at it either way. Senator Crichton-Browne might very reasonably say that it has improved over a certain period.
—It has reduced 2 1/2 per cent in the last two years.

—And it is continuing to reduce. We can look at it either way. We can also say that it is still far above the non-Aboriginal rate and it is something we want to reduce still further. I was concerned about the report of the World Council of Churches on several grounds. The team, when it came to Australia, made statements which indicated that it had preconceived judgments and preconceived ideas. That is the first thing. Secondly, it had as its chief adviser a person who was openly and avowedly critical of Christianity and who had said that he regarded one church magazine as pornography and that he regarded Christianity as being one of the great crosses the Aboriginal people had to bear. Yet that man was the chief adviser, and prominent Aboriginal Christians were overlooked. In spite of these matters I was prepared to examine the report on its merits. I say in qualitative terms that it had messages which I hope Australians will take on board.

ANSWER.PARA: The report failed in one major way. It failed to balance its account of the blemishes in this country with any account of the accomplishments and achievements. I think it is fair to seek a balanced view when looking at a matter such as Aboriginal advancement. To that extent I think Senator Crichton-Browne is quite correct to draw to our attention a need to balance up the picture presented to us. I am in the process of writing to a number of church leaders with whom I was in correspondence over this report and I intend to make available to them a document, when it is ready, which sets out some views on the other side. I undertake to make such a document available to the Senate. I mention also that there has recently been published-it is available through the Australian Government Publishing Service-a booklet on Aboriginals which sets out--

TALK.START.PARA: —A very good book.

—Senator Teague indicates that he thinks it is a very good book. I think it is a very good book too. It sets out some of the balancing points of view. I suggest that if people are going to read any of the material they should read the report of the World Council of Churches and the other side of the picture and put them both together to try to get a balanced point of view. Only by doing that can we hope to get a decent attitude and decent advancement for Aboriginals.

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Is it a fact that there has been a Government decision to wait until the sales tax issue currently before this Parliament has been settled before bringing in a new television stations licence fees Bill which will reduce significantly the fees paid by the wealthier television stations? Has the timing of this new Bill been arranged so as to try to minimise the obvious contrast between the Government's harsh taxing actions on ordinary people and its generous accommodation of a well-off sector of business? When will this Bill be introduced?

—I am rather surprised at the first part of the question because, of course, the timing of the handling of the sales tax legislation in the Senate can be put at rest when it is dealt with next Tuesday by the simple device of the Opposition supporting the sales tax Bills. Let it be perfectly clear that the question fails at the very outset. These Bills would now have been law as an integral part of the Budget if the Opposition had not opposed them. The timing, as at this moment, is in the hands of the Australian Labor Party. Therefore, the rest of the question is irrelevant in terms of its link with any other legislation. I will be putting out, I hope today, a second week's schedule of legislation for the Labor Party. That will indicate the Bills in the order in which they will be produced. There is no delay in relation to any legislation other than the delay being caused by the obstruction of the Labor Party in this place.

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government. It relates to Qantas Airways Ltd services to South Africa. Is the Minister aware that even though there has recently been some talk about increased sanctions against South Africa the issue of air services between South Africa and other places has not been raised and in fact 10 out of the 27 airlines which service South Africa from abroad are owned by the governments of Commonwealth countries, including several black African nations? Is the Minister aware that the recently approved, continued twice-weekly South African service between Australia and South Africa is very heavily booked and in some cases is booked out six months in advance? Has the Government been informed that Qantas flights to places such as Mauritius and other African countries are not likely to be economic? Finally, I ask: As Qantas is losing money and needs all the business help it can get, why does the Government not assist Qantas and Australia by immediately approving Qantas flying between South Africa and Australia?

—The particular question does not come under areas of my responsibility although I take it Senator Townley directed it to me in the general sense of Government policy, overlapping portfolios. I accept it on that basis. I do not have specific details. The question deserves an examination of each of its facets. I will refer it to the Minister or Ministers concerned and seek a response.

—Has the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration received representations from individuals and groups concerning the current state of adult migrant education services? What has been the Government's response to these representations, if any, and what measures are proposed to remedy the problems raised-in particular, the demand for adult migrant education far exceeding supply, the low provision of a permanent teaching force in adult migrant English education and the failure of Government policy to reach the Galbally targets concerning adult migrant English and on-arrival English education?

—Senator Gietzelt asked specifically about representations to the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs in regard to the matters mentioned by him. He referred also to problems generally in this area. Although I have some knowledge in relation to the problems that he mentioned, I do not have any information in relation to the specific question. I will refer the whole question to the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and ask him to give an answer.

—I preface my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Health by stating that I have been approached regarding the high cost of pharmaceutical items relating to the day to day control of diabetes. The cost of single-use syringes to diabetics is between 14c and 40c a syringe. In view of this, will the Government give consideration to allowing syringes to be made available in packages of 100 for the current standard cost of $2.75 under the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Bjelke-Petersen says that she has been approached on this matter. I recently acted as Minister for Health and seemed to sign hundreds of letters on this same subject. I take it that there is a fair amount of community interest and concern from diabetic associations and from groups representing diabetic patients. I can well understand the matters raised by Senator Bjelke-Petersen. She would be aware that under the provisions of the National Health Act the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme is limited to providing drugs and medicinal preparations as benefits and therefore at the moment items such as insulin syringes are not made available under the Scheme. To take up the point so correctly made by Senator Bjelke-Petersen, consideration has been given to seeking ways and means by which Government assistance might be given in meeting the cost of insulin syringes required by diabetics.

ANSWER.PARA: I can assure the honourable senator that the Government is sympathetic to the needs of diabetics and is aware and mindful of the costs to the patients in the management of diabetes. However, at the moment the Government is unable, in the present economic situation, to find the available money to meet the needs that Senator Bjelke-Petersen has pointed out. In view of this it is not possible for the Government at this time to commit itself to additional programs such as assistance with the cost of insulin syringes and other equipment. I am advised by the Minister for Health that this matter will be kept under review and that he is concerned to continue to see what might be done to assist these constituents.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. Could some consideration be given to the expenses incurred by diabetics being made tax deductible?

—I think Senator Bjelke-Petersen is now looking at other ways and means by which assistance might be given. This is something I will properly pass on to the Minister for Health for further consideration.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ANSETT AIRLINES OF AUSTRALIA: AIRCRAFT PURCHASES

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Transport whether he can confirm that a senior executive of Ansett Airlines of Australia has admitted that the purchase of 12 twin-engined narrow-bodied Boeing 737s was solely a marketing decision, as was claimed in the September issue of the Australian Aviation and Defence Review. Is it also true, as claimed in an article entitled 'Counting the One Per Cent' by Mr Jim Thorn, the editor of the magazine, that a senior Ansett executive has stated that the Boeing 737-200 is no more economical to run than the McDonnell Douglas DC9-30, with which Ansett is already equipped? Can the Minister confirm what the magazine describes as a strong rumour in the industry that Ansett plans to back-trade or trade-in its newly introduced Boeing 737-200s for 737-300s in 1985, only four years after the introduction of the 737-200s? Does the Minister think it proper that Ansett should be allowed to spend approximately $150m on the purchase of aircraft which offer no significant advantage over existing equipment and which the airline apparently admits are being bought solely as a result of a marketing decision? Can the Minister justify the capital expenditure of $150m at the expense of the long-suffering air traveller to maintain the market share of a privately-owned airline?

—I am afraid I have no information on the magazine article to which Senator Siddons referred. I ask him on this occasion to put the question on notice and I will refer it directly to the Minister for Transport.

—My question is addressed to the Attorney-General. Is it the case that during the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting recently a number of Melbourne radio stations, including station 3AW, which has made public allegations about this matter, had their private telephone communications monitored by one or other of the security services? May I make it clear that I refer not to calls made on air in the context of talk-back shows but rather to ordinary telephone communications to and from the various stations. If it is the case that such monitoring took place, by whom was it conducted, under what legislative authority, and why?
—I have not heard of the allegations to which Senator Evans referred. Apart from any information contained in his question, if he can provide further detail I will have the matter investigated.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry and refer him to the dumping of almonds on the Australian market by United States producers. Is it a fact that these almonds are being sold at $2.90 a kilogram, compared with $4.50 a kilo for the Australian product? Although the quantity of United States almonds represents only 5 per cent of its total production, it amounts to 40 per cent of our domestic demand. Can the Minister confirm that these United States producers agreed not to undercut Australian producers, and then reneged on that agreement? Will the Minister assure the Senate that his Department will examine this matter and take action to protect the industry in Australia? Incidentally, the major proportion of the production comes from South Australia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did seek some information from the Minister for Primary Industry with respect to the matter raised by the honourable senator. That enables me to advise the Senate that the reason for the difficulty which is raised in the honourable senator's question is that there has been a record almond crop in the United States. Production has risen to 204,000 tonnes in 1981 from 146,000 tonnes in 1980. In addition to that, production for 1981 from the three major world producers-the United States, Spain and Italy-totals a record 300,000 tonnes, an increase of nearly 50 per cent on the 1980 output of these countries. That is the explanation for the very considerable drop in the price of almonds on the world market. As a consequence of those world record crops, the duty paid price of United States almonds has fallen from $4.30 per kilogram to $2.75 per kilogram.

ANSWER.PARA: Co-operative Almond Producers Ltd, which markets the great bulk-over 90 per cent-of Australian production, sets its selling price in August each year in advance of the subsequent harvest in March-April of the following year. It bases that price on the equivalent duty paid price for United States almonds. It set its price last August for the 1981 crop at $4.50 per kilogram, which was the equivalent of the United States ruling rate in August 1980. There is, of course, nothing that the Government can do to stop the United States producers from altering their price in the light of the world production situation.

We, in turn, have managed to live up to the general world situation by also producing a record crop this year. But the figure of 1,453 tonnes indicates what a relatively small part of the world production we grow in Australia. Of course, as the honourable senator said, the bulk of our production is grown in his State of South Australia. Because of the marketing difficulties which are being experienced by the Australian almond industry in the difficult circumstances I have outlined and following representations which have been made by the industry in Australia, on 28 August Mr Nixon requested the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs to send a reference to the Temporary Assistance Authority. Public hearings of the Authority have already been held, on 17 September, and it is hoped that the Government will be able to give consideration to the matter in the very near future.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. I asked the Minister whether he could confirm that United States producers had reneged on their agreement not to undercut Australian producers. Can the Minister confirm that that is accurate?

—I have no advice on any such agreement or any reneging on any such agreement. I will seek information on that from the Minister for Primary Industry. The advice which I have from the Minister is simply that there is nothing we can do to prevent United States producers from altering their prices in response to marketing conditions. Of course, that is a frequent problem in the field of the marketing of primary produce. But if there is some additional information, I will certainly obtain it for the honourable senator.

—I direct a question to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. Are Australian veterans who served overseas eligible for a defence service homes loan regardless of their income and savings? If not, are those veterans whose income is limited to a pension because of a war disability not entitled to a defence service homes loan?

—I take it that Senator Colston must have in mind a particular case that perhaps has been considered by the Defence Service Homes Division of my Department. He might present me with the facts of that case so that we can examine them. In general terms, if he requires a statement as to the eligibility of persons in the category which he has outlined in his question, I will obtain that statement and see that it is given to him in the next day or so.

—I direct a question to you, Mr President. You may recall that I asked your predecessor, the Honourable Sir Condor Laucke, whether he would consider erecting in the Senate chamber State flags or coats of arms or emblems to remind visitors to the Senate that this House is constitutionally a States House as well as a House of review. What progress has been made on this matter? Further, would you also consider it appropriate to have the Australian flag flying in this chamber?

—All I can say at this stage is that I do not have any information or indication with regard to the progress of the request which was made to my predecessor. I will have a look at the honourable senator's question. I will see what the situation is with regard to the previous suggestion and also the honourable senator's current suggestion.

—My question is directed to the Attorney-General. I refer to the fact that, under the Parliamentary Witness Oaths Act of 1871 which is in force in Australia by virtue of section 49 of the Constitution, witnesses before parliamentary committees who give false evidence are liable to penalties for perjury. In view of the clear conflict between the statement of the Minister for Communications to the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations on 16 March 1981 and the sworn evidence given to the Committee by Mr Webster and set out on pages 146 to 199 of the Senate Committee report, will the Government consider bringing criminal proceedings for perjury in relation to the sworn evidence and thereby vindicate the unsworn statement of the Minister?
—The answer is no.
—Because you don't believe Sinclair.
—Order!
—I direct my question to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. I take no pleasure in asking this question-
—Either you don't believe Sinclair or you have abdicated your responsibilities.

— Order! I address all of the Senate. I have previously asked in this chamber that interjections not continue when an honourable senator is asking a question. I hope that my request will be respected.

—I take no pleasure in asking this question, but if inhumanity is not resisted in this country it may limp on too far. I refer to the blatant racist bigotry of the statement by Mr Lang Hancock outrageously proposing a so-called murderous solution for Aboriginal people in Australia. This statement was given wide media publicity during the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting last week. The Parliament was not sitting at the time. If it had been, the uproar of disapproval in this chamber would also have been widely heard. I ask: What, at the time, were the terms of the Minister's own condemnation of this outrage? Whilst it is now true that Mr Hancock can only hang his head in shame when in the company of other Australians, can the Minister now say whether State Ministers for Aboriginal Affairs or Premiers have joined with him in gaining a full retraction by Mr Hancock of this much-publicised statement and his apology to the Aboriginal people and all Australians?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Hancock's statements concerned people who were, as he termed them, half castes. This, of course, is a condition which people acquire by virtue of their parents and to condemn them on the ground of their racial composition seems to me to be the height of crudity and something quite abhorrent to all Australians. At the time Mr Hancock made this outrageous statement, I did indicate my view to the Press by way of response to a number of queries. This was extensively reported in the print media. I will make available to Senator Teague copies of the Press reports which set out quite clearly the disgust which I expressed about Mr Hancock's statements and his sentiments. I went on television to make it clear that this view was held.

ANSWER.PARA: I am sure that honourable senators on both sides of the House would find Mr Hancock's opinions crude and abhorrent. I am also sure that most Australians would feel the same. His views are contrary to the increased sensitivity and awareness of Aboriginal problems which exist in Australia. They are contrary to the willingness to work with Aboriginals in a constructive way which characterises Australians and Australian opinion now. They are contrary to the views and behaviour of most resource developers in this country who are displaying a positive attitude in working with Aboriginal communities. I cite there the work of the Australian Mining Industry Council and the Australian Petroleum Exploration Association, both of which have published policies which recognise the needs and interests of Aboriginals and seek co-operative solutions.

I understand that the Commissioner for Community Relations has written to Mr Hancock in terms of his powers under the Racial Discrimination Act 1975. Provision also exists for individuals to complain to the Commissioner for Community Relations if they believe that Mr Hancock's actions are in contravention of the Act. If people feel strongly, they should write to Mr Hancock. I have made my own position quite clear. I believe that what was said was quite outrageous and quite unhelpful. I can only conclude that Mr Hancock's judgment is not what it used to be.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: DEFENCE FORCES: APPRENTICESHIPS AND TECHNICAL TRAINING

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence. I refer to apprenticeship and technical training positions in both the defence forces and the civilian work force within the Department of Defence. In view of the recommendations of the Williams Committee of Inquiry into Education and Training advocating a positive approach towards equality of training opportunities, and the Government's own Equality in Employment Opportunity Guidelines, can the Minister please provide the following information: How many training positions are available in the defence forces, and in the Department of Defence civilian work force? In which trades and technical occupations are these training opportunities? Where are the positions located? How many applications have been received from women and how many of these have been successful? From which classifications are women excluded and on what grounds? I would be particularly interested to know whether both young women and young men are able to train as pilots with the Royal Australian Air Force. Finally, what steps have been taken to ensure that the recruiting material and the promotion material are designed to attract applications from young women whose training needs are too often neglected?

—In view of the detail in the question and the importance of the matters that have been raised, I will certainly refer the question to the Minister for Defence and ask him to provide a detailed answer for the Senate.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: TRANSPORT STRIKE: TRANSPORT FACILITIES FOR VETERANS

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. How will the Minister provide transport for all those sick veterans who need medical treatment today but who are denied essential and humanitarian services by the latest Transport Workers Union strike? How much longer is the Government prepared to allow the TWU to hold the Australian nation to ransom with blackmail and techniques modelled on Jimmy Hoffa and the Teamsters Union?

—Every time an event such as the one which Senator MacGibbon referred to in his question occurs it creates problems in respect of transporting veterans from their homes to enable them to receive attention in repatriation hospitals all over Australia. It certainly is a very significant problem about which we all need to have a great deal of concern. As to the situation which Senator MacGibbon outlines, these matters, as he would understand, depend upon the issue of the moment. I take it that he is referring to the stop work situation today. I am not aware of the progress or the outcome of the meetings today. However, I will refer that part of the question to the relevant Minister to obtain a reply for Senator MacGibbon.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs. Is it a fact that 60 per cent of Special Youth Employment Training Program subsidies go to existing job vacancies, that is, the subsidy is offered after the vacancies are lodged with the Commonwealth Employment Service? Is it also a fact that many employers are still not fulfilling their training obligations under the scheme? Is the Minister aware that such practices go against the original intention of the scheme? What does the Minister propose to do about such exploitation of this training scheme?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — It is the first time that I have heard that figure of 60 per cent in relation to the Special Youth Employment Training Program and the suggestion that there is some disadvantage to or exploitation of those who are using the scheme. I understood the Minister to be watching closely all training schemes at present. If some information can be provided on any employers who may not be using the scheme in the best interests of those who are seeking employment opportunities from them, perhaps that information could be given to the Minister either directly or through me. If there are any matters in the question on which the Minister wishes to comment, I will see that an early answer is given on them.

—Senator Harradine asked me a question about credit facilities to Poland. I am advised that in April the Government decided to underwrite, through the Export Finance and Insurance Corporation, Australian bank credits at commercial rates of interest and for periods not exceeding 180 days to finance purchases of wool, hides and skin by the Polish authorities up to a total amount of $40m. I understand that following some delays arrangements for the credit facility were finalised in July between EFIC and the banks. To date EFIC has underwritten guarantees valued at over $8m. In respect of letters of credit discounted by the banks the credit facility is now operational.
—How much was it?
—It is $8m already but a total of $40m altogether. That is, a total of $40m of which $8m had already been committed.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Ryan proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The failure of the Government to ensure stable administration and adequate funding for the Arts.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by sessional order having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise this matter in the Senate today because arts activity throughout Australia is in serious disarray. The Australian Labor Party and I consider it a matter of great concern that the viability of the artistic and cultural life in this country is in jeopardy because of Fraser Government policies-because of cutbacks in funding, administrative incompetence and lack of a clearly enunciated policy to assist the arts. Australian artists are finding it harder and harder to work productively and Australian audiences are being more and more deprived of access to their own culture. During the last six years Australia has experienced the most philistine government it has ever experienced, certainly in my lifetime-the most anti-intellectual and the most anti-cultural government. Yet, of course, it is willing to ride on and to exploit the successes of arts activities encouraged by a previous government.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government now is prepared to say: 'Look at the Australian film industry. Isn't it doing well?' The Government is very happy to associate itself with such successes but when it comes to providing adequate funds to ensure the continuation of the development of the sort of talent that led to the burgeoning of the Australian film industry it is quite silent. In place of a well thought out arts funding structure and adequate appropriation equitably distributed the Fraser Government has administered and funded the arts with a combination of outright neglect, erratic administrative decisions and, most significantly, by using the arts as yet another means of providing tax havens for the wealthy. Insofar as one can detect any trend or theme in the Government's approach to arts funding it has been this: To withdraw properly accountable public assistance and substitute private sector support by way of tax concessions and corporate self-promotion activities. This approach is objectionable on many scores.

One of the main objections is that assistance to the arts in the form of tax concessions for the rich is a form of assistance that is not publicly accountable. It is difficult, in some cases impossible, to assess the public revenue lost by this method. A further objection is that the method itself is open to abuse. Indeed, there have been some notorious cases of abuse. Only today the media carry a report that the Government is to close a tax loophole used by a syndicate of businessmen to claim a tax deduction of $3.7m for a donation of a collection of pre-Colombian art to the National Gallery of Victoria. The syndicate had paid only $1.2m for the collection immediately before it donated it to the gallery. But it was able to claim a tax deduction of $3.7m-three times what it had paid for it-based upon valuation of the art. The loophole is now to be closed.

The report in today's Age points out that this is not the only time a loophole has been used. In a number of less publicised cases the same loophole was used to achieve tax deductions in excess of the paid price for the works of art. An additional element has been added to the scheme whereby in some cases-we were told in today's Age-the work is donated to the gallery and the gallery then lends it back to the donor for the duration of his lifetime. Of course, the tax concession is still paid. It is abuses such as these that are inevitable when the Government's preferred means of assisting the arts is to assist the rich to minimise their tax bills. It is incidents such as these that cause the Labor Party to be quite sceptical about the substitution of tax concessions for properly accountable direct public assistance. It is incidents such as these that raise doubts about the whole question of corporate support for the arts.

I must say that these doubts extend to the appointment of Dr Timothy Pascoe as the new Executive Chairman of the Australia Council. Dr Pascoe is a person with considerable qualifications. The Labor Party does not regard the period he spent working at the Liberal Party headquarters as a disqualification for his appointment to a statutory body

However, because of his closeness to the Government of the day the question of jobs for the boys does arise and the government in its usual arrogance and negligence, has made no real attempt to answer that question. If we look at Dr Pascoe's qualifications for the specific job of administering direct Federal Government assistance to the arts, we find that his prior experience has been something less than appropriate. His previous job was running an organisation called ARTS Ltd, whose charter was to persuade corporations to sponsor the arts as a means of self advertisement. He had some modest success in this, although one could hardly say that his activities caused a massive flow of private sector money into the arts. The total figure claimed by Dr Pascoe for corporate sponsorship is $10m a year, but only $54,500 of this went through ARTS Ltd, the organisation with which Dr Pascoe has been involved for the past few years. That is a miniscule amount, I might say, and hardly one that establishes that we do not need proper public sponsorship of the arts because the corporations are very anxious to hop into the breach.

Dr Pascoe's understanding of the role of independent statutory authorities also seems to be somewhat deficient. His analogy, as reported in the Age, in an interview with Jill Sykes on Tuesday of this week, is that the relationship between Government and statutory bodies is that of the rapist and his victim. Apart from the tastelessness of the image his analogy conjures up-Dr Pascoe being raped by Mr Wilson, perhaps-the analogy hardly inspires confidence that the Government's appointment is one of a person who is determined to be independent in the administration of his function. It seems to me that the rapist victim is hardly the appropriate analogy for what we, in the Labor Party at least, understand to be the proper, independent role of a statutory body.

However, granted that Dr Pascoe may be able to make the transition from corporate sponsorship to public administration, this question still remains unanswered: Why does the Australia Council need a new executive Chairman? How is Dr Pascoe's salary of $56,000 to be justified? The Australia Council is not short of executive talent. The widely admired Dr Jean Battersby was the Chief Executive Officer of the Council for some years. Then the Fraser Government, without any real explanation of its decision, added another chief, Mr John Cameron-again a competent person. Dr Battersby was moved sideways into what one can only imagine to be the less than fully demanding area of managing the International Cultural Exhibitions Corporation. Now we have another chief at a time when the indians, that is the people who actually service the boards and administer the programs, are all too few on the ground. In the absence of any justification for this decision, it can be assumed only that, rather than face up to the task of rationalising the administration of the Council, the Government has taken the line of least resistance and has appointed yet another chief whose only real qualifications for the job seem to be his shared political philosophy with the Government of the day.

I turn now to the matter of funding. This Government's paltry expenditure on the arts since it attained office is an example of the meanness of spirit which typifies the Fraser Government and for which it will be remembered. The vigorous cultural life which flourished under the Whitlam Government was a direct result of clear sighted arts policy and appropriate funding, particularly for the new, the innovative and the Australian. By contrast, the period of the Fraser Government has been characterised by cutbacks, incompetent administration of arts policy and a lack of encouragement for the development of Australian artists and arts activities. There has been a cutback of almost 40 per cent in the last six years and the level of staffing for the Council has dropped from 167 to 102.

In this Budget $29m has been allocated to the Australia Council, which to begin with is a drop of over 5 per cent in real terms. Of course, this money is not all available for direct expenditure by the Council, as Senator Hamer, who I am pleased to see is sitting in this chamber, is very well aware. An amount of $7.6m is earmarked for the ballet, the opera and the orchestras. After administration costs the Council is left with only $17m for distribution to the arts. Of this amount the Government, not the Australian council, has decided that more than $500,000 will be spent on a Commonwealth Games arts festival. In the forthcoming year the Australia Council will have $373,000 less to assist Australian writers, painters, musicians, craftspeople and others. Whilst I am in favour of creating a favourable impression for visitors to this country, I cannot condone cuts to the Australia Council's already miniscule budget for the encouragement of the arts just so that the Government can grandstand at the Commonwealth Games.

The total funding for the arts provided through the Australia Council in this Budget is only 0.07 per cent of total government outlays, a figure which is described by Richard Wherrett, the Director of the Sydney Theatre Co., in a recent letter to the Sydney Morning Herald, as derisory. I point out that the figure has fallen from 0.12 per cent of total government outlays under the Whitlam Government. At this stage I must ask why the Government is so unprepared to give assistance to the arts. Why is the Government so unprepared to assist struggling theatre companies and other arts activities to keep pace with the effects of inflation when it is so prepared to be generous to other areas of the economy? As I said, it is indeed the most philistine government in this country that I have seen in my lifetime.

In practical terms, the Government's funding squeeze is curtailing Australian creativity and the development of an Australian culture. The Australia Council's Literature Board, for example, in 1974-75 spent $1.3m on payment to individual writers. Last financial year it spent less than $1m-a drop in real terms of 52 per cent. The result is fewer grants of smaller value and ultimately fewer fine Australian books. Meanwhile the Government does nothing about the takeover of Australian publishing by multinational publishing companies, an activity which will result in even fewer Australian books being published here and being available for Australians to read. The Government's actions have not gone unnoticed. In an editorial entitled 'Squeezing the Arts', the Sydney Morning Herald, which is hardly noted for its radical or progressive views, on 24 August had this to say:

One of the short-sighted, even shabby, dispensations of the 1981-82 Budget is its continuation, for the sixth year in succession, of the Fraser Government's squeeze on the funding of the arts . . . reversing the trend towards a growing Commonwealth role in encouraging the expansion of our indigenous culture. Following important initiatives by the Holt, Gorton and McMahon Governments, that trend became a surge under Mr Whitlam's enlightened understanding of the vital contribution indigenous arts can make to our national identity and international reputation. The policies of the Fraser Government are placing that advance in jeopardy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't lose your place.

—I am quoting from the Sydney Morning Herald editorial of 24 August. I suggest that the Minister might turn his attention to that editorial. Even the Government's own former Minister for Post and Telecommunications, Mr Tony Staley, has condemned the Government's allocation to the arts. Speaking in his new role as Chairman of the Confederation of Australian Professional Performing Arts, Mr Staley predicted that many professional arts companies will not survive the coming year unless the Government reviews its Budget allocation to the arts.
—Don't lose your place. Keep reading.

—I will be interested to see what kind of defence the Minister can offer for this appalling and shabby treatment of arts activities. I turn my attention to structural matters. As the Government is only too happy to tell us with boring repetition, it is not only the allocation of money that matters. I quite agree. We need proper structures for the assistance of the arts. We have seen a number of amendments to the Australia Council Act during the last six years of the Fraser Government. None of them seem to have been made with any clear objective of rationalising the functions of the Council. None of them seems to have brought about any real administrative improvement in the operation of the Council. None of these changes, including the downgrading in the role of the boards, the removal of board chairmen from the Council and introduction of a new and, as I have said, apparently unnecessary chief executive officer position, has been justified. The Government has not bothered to try to explain to us why these changes are in the interests of arts administration in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: To fulfil its position as a major advisory body on the arts as well as a main disseminator of government financial support to the arts and arts companies, the Australia Council requires a workable structure and an adequate number of members with expertise in the arts. On that latter point I must make further comment. The Australia Council is not a struggling arts company in need of business expertise to assist it to retain its financial viability. Therefore, its primary need is for members who have experience in the arts rather than people with entrepreneurial experience.

TALK.START.PARA: —It does need some management experience.

—However, as the Government has demonstrated in so many other areas it is all too prepared to ignore the advice of those with expertise in favour of those with the loudest voice, those who can bring the greatest pressure to bear or those who are closest to the heart of Liberal philosophy.
