I say in passing, commenting on Senator Teague's interjection, that although this Government seems to believe that a great deal of entrepreneurial skill and experience exists within the business community and has made appointments to statutory boards and bodies associated with arts administration because of this belief, we have seen a series of chaotic administrative exercises by these bodies which are supposed to be getting the benefit of all this entrepreneurial expertise. It seems that the time has come to look at people with experience in the arts rather than experience in running some kind of business enterprise if we are to get proper administration. I must remind the Senate of the continuing crises in the Australian Opera management. I think we have had something like seven general managers in the last 12 years, the most recent being Mr Patrick Veitch from New York.
—He will be a good one.

—I hope he will be a good one. I would like to see a change in this kind of administrative chaos, but what kind of soundness and stability of administration can we have when we constantly have these controversies, resignations and forced resignations? There was an inquiry into the affairs of the Opera-the McKinnon report-but the Government seems to have taken very little action in response to that report. If we turn to the Australian Ballet we find similar stories of controversial administrative situations. Two very talented artistic administrators, first Sir Robert Helpmann and then Ms Anne Woolliams, resigned or were forced to resign in a flurry of controversy. That sort of thing does not demonstrate a government that is determined to have proper arts administration in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the problems is that this Government has never shown the slightest interest in providing for the training of arts administrators in this country. We have a dearth of our own people with competence in arts administration. Very few courses are available. Very few schemes are available to encourage the development of administrative skills. We go into the cultural cringe and constantly import our arts administrators from overseas and, I have to say, to very little effect. I do not want to dismiss the contribution made by overseas administrators in this country but the picture is not a rosy one. As I have suggested, there have been constant controversies in the area of our major companies. Of course, when we come to our smaller companies, the ones that do not attract so much media attention, we find similar stories of administrative chaos and incompetence.

Yet the Government has taken no serious steps to ensure that we can start to train people in arts administration in Australia. But when we take people from overseas and provide them with jobs in a world situation of decreasing employment in arts administration-Australia is really a very good country to come to get a job-do we ever insist on reciprocal arrangements?

Do we ever say to the United Kingdom or to the United States of America: 'We will employ your people here but we insist that our young developing administrators get experience in your country'? No, of course; it is a cultural exchange that is only one way. That is typical of this Government, which has no confidence in the true independence of an Australian culture.

I see that my time has almost run out. Unless this Government seriously faces up to the funding inadequacies for the arts in this country, unless this Government is serious about ensuring a proper arts policy administrated by an independent statutory body staffed by competent people, we will see a serious decline of all forms of creative activity in Australia. The film industry, of which we have been so proud; Australian Broadcasting Commission productions, of which we have been so proud in the past; the marvellous flourishing of Australian literature, fiction and non-fiction, of which we have had many examples in just this last year, all will be in jeopardy unless the Government is prepared to abandon its philistine attitude and provide proper resources and proper thought to establishing a workable arts policy for this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating a matter of public importance. It may be worth while to bring to the attention of the Senate the way in which it is worded. It reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The failure of the Government to ensure stable administration and adequate funding for the arts.

I would like to start by making the observation that we would all agree that one of the marks of a civilised society is surely the extent to which it is involved in the arts and values its culture and cultural activity. Another of the marks is the extent to which the society will strive for excellence. I submit that we are such a society; we are a society which values its artistic endeavours, values its artists and values excellence. This Government strives for these values and my party is firmly committed to striving for these values as well. This whole debate as it was presented by Senator Ryan is neither merely an exercise in accountancy, nor merely an opportunity for some kind of socialist polemic-nor yet is it an opportunity for a character assassination, under privilege, of someone who has been appointed as Chairman of the Australia Council.

I do not believe Senator Ryan really addressed the subject of the matter of public importance. Yet again she has brought up a case which she has totally failed to address or to justify. The question we have to ask is whether we value the arts, whether we care for the arts. Senator Ryan has failed to establish either that we do not have adequate administration or that we do not have adequate funding. To dwell on a few select figures as she read away is to miss the point completely.

Let us look at the structures and networks that exist, that we do have in place and that we have developed for funding. The development has occurred since 1968, as Senator Ryan said. It has occurred under both Liberal and Labor governments. We have developed a sophisticated framework-a framework for administration, a framework for support and a framework for encouragement; a framework which does exist and which is working. I almost believe that Senator Ryan is upset that it is working. I almost think she would rather it was not working so she could make a case in the Parliament. At a grass roots level we have a range of boards. We have theatre boards, Aboriginal arts boards, literature boards and procedures for orderly dealings. We have a system under which people know where they can relate and where they can plug in. People know where to go to get involved in arts activities in an administrative sense.

I am fascinated by Senator Ryan's concern that we should want to have administrators to administer. After all, administration is, itself, a specialist activity. A coloratura may be a very good singer but hopeless at administration. It does not follow that a ballet dancer with an international reputation will have any skill at administration. In this country alone we have already set into place some courses for administration in the arts. I am surprised Senator Ryan did not want to advert to the course being run at the moment by the Victorian College of the Arts, which trains arts administrators, or to the course being operated at the moment through the South Australian Institute of Technology.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a very good course.

—Senator Teague interjects to say it is a very good course. They are courses designed to produce the administrators that can do a professional job of administration. I am not sure whether Senator Ryan was criticising us because we did not entrench for all time the incumbents at one moment on the various boards because we thought there was some virtue in opening up the positions to a wider membership so we could have a cadre of people who had been through and who had membership-a wide spectrum of involved citizens. I could mention bodies which are concerned with maintaining the excellence of the arts and which fund the various arts. These include, to mention just two, the Australia Council and the Australian National Gallery. They are administered by councils which are representative of people who have expertise in the relative and various art forms.

SPEECH.PARA: There are many levels of administration. Senator Ryan said in the words of her matter of public importance that there is a failure to ensure stable administration. I submit there are many levels of administration of the arts. At another level, in conjunction with State and local governments we are funding community arts offices in particular areas. We are carrying out funding in association with particular organisations such as ethnic groups, Aboriginal groups and the trade union movement. That is not to say that our administrative structure or administrative model is static. It is not static; it is constantly being reviewed. My party and Senator Ryan's party are involved in examining all the time whether the structure is adequate or needs some change. For example, in recent years significant changes and amendments have been made to the Australia Council Act and to the administration of other bodies. They have constantly been under review and the operations which they undertake have been provided for in the respective legislation at all times with a view to improving and to responding in an appropriate way to the needs of the organisation.

Senator Ryan talked about the failure to provide adequate funding. Again she did not establish her case. Senator Ryan is pre-occupied just with some of the narrow accountancy aspects of a minor but important part of the Government's involvement with the arts. She dwells on the fact that in one specific area Australia Council funding has been such and such. I remind the Senate that Australia Council funding is important, but it is a small part of the total picture. The Australia Council, itself, is adjusting its funding capacity. It is developing a program specifically to meet its new funding situation. It is developing what is called a challenge grants scheme-it is in the process of establishing that-for the arts organisations to try to ensure that there is adequate financial support for the arts now and in succeeding years. Maybe, as spokesman for the arts, she does not know about the challenge grants scheme. Perhaps she would like to know more about it. That scheme will give us time to review this area. It is intended to open up additional sources of income and support for organisations. This will provide an opportunity for public demonstration of support for the arts and for the community. I hope Senator Ryan does not think that is a bad thing. By adopting this scheme the Council will be able to increase its funds for individual creative artists in 1982 by 15 per cent. I hope Senator Ryan does not think that is a bad thing.

I remind honourable senators that providing for the Australia Council represents only a small part of the money commitment that goes into arts in Australia. Senator Ryan is concentrating on a small, though important, aspect of the whole picture. I remind honourable senators also that well over $1 billion goes into arts, including pop and classical, crafts-including craft based industries and activities-and into the Australian Broadcasting Commission, et cetera. There seems to be some view that it is only the commitment that goes through the Appropriation Bills that is real, that exists. There is a total failure on the part of the Australian Labor Party and its spokesmen to understand the wider commitment of a mass of Australian people to involvement in the arts at a whole range of levels and the commitment of financial resources, human resources, time and interest which exists in the community today and which we are busy supporting.

The Australian Council provides funds for national organisations such as the Australian Opera, the Australian Ballet, the Australian Elizabethan Theatre Trust and many more, but the funds that go to the Australia Council are not the only funds for the development of the arts in Australia; far from it. Let me list just a few of the significant contributions this Government makes to the arts. Firstly, this financial year the allowance to the Australian National Gallery is $15m. That is an increase of about one-third over expenditure in the previous year. Did Senator Ryan set that out to give a nice, balanced picture? Secondly, last financial year and this financial year Government support for Artbank in each year was $425,000. I remind honourable senators that the purpose of Artbank is the acquisition of works by living Australian artists and the exhibition of art works in public buildings by acquiring a collection of Australian arts and crafts. Is that not a significant and worthwhile activity?

The third point is that the Government makes contributions to the International Cultural Corporation of Australia Ltd to the Australian Film and Television School, to the Australian Film Commission, and to the Public Lending Right, where payments to authors and publishers exceeded $1m last year. There is also the Australian Ballet Development Foundation and the National Institute of Dramatic Art. In talking about NIDA I just mention the provision of $3m--

TALK.START.PARA: —About time, too.

—About time, too. Why did Senator Ryan not mention that contribution, that $3m? Perhaps she did not know about it. It is a contribution of $3m for the construction of a building adjacent to the Seymour Centre for the purposes of NIDA. Either the honourable senator did not know about it, which would represent incompetence in the representative job she has to do, or she did know about it but had no intention of presenting a balanced picture to this Senate. In addition to the Government's contribution to NIDA's running costs, that $3m will be of immense value. Then, of course, there are things such as the Australian Broadcasting Commission orchestras, which are funded through the ABC. Even if we were to engage in Senator Ryan's accounting exercise and look at total funding covered by the Department of Home Affairs and Environment, if we took the total contribution to the arts through the Department we would see that the Government has fully maintained its real contribution in total funding. Whereas in 1974-75 funding of these areas totalled $40.6m-that was a Labor Government year-the allocation this year through Home Affairs is $84.3m. Let me repeat that. Under a Labor Government in 1974-75 just over $40m was provided and this year just under $85m is being provided. Funding has more than doubled in just over eight years.

SPEECH.PARA: We should not forget the contributions of State governments to the arts in Australia and the co-operative activity that takes place between different levels of government. Even if we look at the activities supported by the Australia Council we see that between them the States provide roughly the same level of financial support as does the Australia Council. That is a very significant contribution to arts activity in Australia, and that is in addition to the States' contributions to their own film corporations, their own galleries, their own museums and their own libraries. Why did Senator Ryan not mention those things? She did not mention them because they would have helped give a balanced picture to the Senate. The honourable senator talks about only a very narrow part of the picture, only a tip of a very large iceberg, a very large commitment of support, a very large commitment by people, a very large interest in arts activity in Australia, a very large and complex set of networks, and a large number of administrations. To confine the debate to the narrow tack taken by Senator Ryan is, of course, to make it meaningless and to devalue what a lot of people are doing. It ignores, as a recent survey showed, the level of corporate support for a whole range of arts organisations across Australia. It ignores the fact that this corporate support has increased tenfold over the last five years. I had hoped that Senator Ryan would encourage, support and welcome that support. I did not hear her doing so. Corporate support has increased from $1m a year to $10m a year. That is a valuable commitment from another part of Australian society.

Of course, this raises the question of government support through a variety of tax support schemes. Is it such a bad thing? What about all these matters? What about total support? What about total funding? What about bringing together all these kinds of activities? If we are going to look at art in Australia then why do we not look at it from all sources? Why did not Sentor Ryan consider all these things? Either she does not know about them or she chooses to ignore them.

I must say something about Dr Timothy Pascoe. I imagine that the Australian Labor Party would welcome the employment of administrators to do administration. The Australian Labor Party has welcomed the work done by McKinsey and Co. Inc. It has told us what a fine job McKinsey has done in producing the Telecom report. In fact the Opposition tabled it on Tuesday. Dr Timothy Pascoe is an administrator who is trained as one, trained to make things work and run, with a Cambridge Ph.D. and a Harvard M.B.A. He established the McKinsey office in Sydney and is, if he is nothing else, a person to make things work and run. Again I put it to honourable senators that to have a person whose expertise has been in management, in making things work to their best ability, brought into the arts and arts administration in Australia can only be a good thing.

I make one final point. The question of funding from the Federal Government Budget in the end comes down to a question of priorities. It comes down to a question of how funding for this function is related against funding for that function, which one is valued more highly. Do I take it Senator Ryan is saying that the Budget should have been recast to provide greater outlays and expenditure in this area of the arts? She is Labor's spokeswoman for the arts. Would she say that activity in the arts should have a higher priority than welfare, a higher priority, say, than Aboriginal advancement? I would have thought that, for example, our concentration, with all the available funds we have, on lifting Aboriginal advancement by a significant amount-she is the spokeswoman for this area as well-is something she would have valued. In terms of these competing priorities, I thought she would have understood that it is necessary to make these choices. The Government has made these choices to place the value it does on the needy, on the weak, on Aboriginals, on welfare.

I point out that, if Senator Ryan goes back and examines the Budget, she will find those priorities reflected. The Government is concerned in a multitude of ways with the arts and with the administration of the arts in Australia. There is stable administration. Networks extend throughout the community. We have adequate funding. We have adequate structures. We have adequate administration. Once again Senator Ryan has brought up a matter of public importance and totally failed to sustain her case. We value the excellence of the arts, and we value the contribution being made by our enormously talented artists. We look to the development of these artists and to activities in a whole range of ways. I believe the structures we have provided will allow this to happen. Accordingly, I move:
That the business of the day be called on.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Robertson Sen E.A.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the papers.

I would like to make a couple of brief comments on the subject of studies of tertiary student finances. The three volumes of studies highlight the inadequacies of the current Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme. In particular they recognise that the level of assistance currently provided is totally inadequate for full time students living away from home unless they can find part time jobs. Of course, I should not have to point out to the Senate at this stage that the part time job market is shrinking very drastically and that students are not nearly as easily able to subsidise themselves in this way as they used to be before the Fraser Government took over the administration of this country.

The reports comment on the declining living standards of full time students. For example, the small expenditure on food by students in rented accommodation suggests that financial hardship may be preventing such students from having adequate diet and nutrition. The third volume of the reports suggests that the position of such students is steadily growing worse. In comparison with others relying on government assistance, such as pensioners and the unemployed, assistance to students is declining. I point out that such a picture of declining living standards amongst tertiary students is unacceptable to the Federal Opposition. The Australian Labor Party has called for an immediate increase of at least $9 per week in the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme allowance, the immediate indexation of TEAS and the liberalisation of the means test. The aim of current Government policies is to push as many students as possible off TEAS and into poverty. The recent Budget Papers estimate that the failure to adjust the means test in 1981-82 will result in a reduction of the number of students eligible for TEAS by 200. The Tertiary Education Commission's most recent triennial report has demonstrated that the declining number of students in Australian universities is directly attributable to the Government's unwillingness to provide a proper level of tertiary assistance.

It seems to us in the Labor Party and I think also to the Australian Democrats that the Government's strategy of forcing students out of full time study and onto the dole is totally irrational and totally indefensible. At a time when the Australian economy needs all the skills and all of the expertise that it can possibly have to recover from six years of Fraser administration we are actually forcing people to abandon proper courses of study. We are forcing them to abandon the acquisition of skills which this economy so desperately needs. Whilever there is such a disparity between the level of payment available for unemployment benefit and the level of assistance available for full time students, students from modest backgrounds will from time to time be forced out of universities and tertiary institutions and on to the dole. How the Government can possibly defend and maintain that system really defies rational understanding.

Although I could say much more about the inadequacy of the tertiary student finances, I conclude by pointing out that the Opposition welcomes these reports because they reinforce what we have been saying. They document beyond any possible area of argument or disagreement that the scheme is inadequate, that students are suffering, that student numbers are declining and that the whole question of education and the development of skills and knowledge in this country is being put at risk by an inadequate scheme.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe that the three volumes concerned with the studies of tertiary student finances are very useful documents because for the first time we have some basis for reasonable discussion about the extremely important subject of the ability of students in our tertiary institutions to maintain a reasonable living standard while they are engaged in their studies.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to make a number of comments about the reports. Firstly I would like to make a comment in passing about volume No. 1, which is a review of recent literature and research. I believe it is quite a good review, but unfortunately it contains some fairly serious anomalies and omissions. I would like to point to one of those. My comments should not be taken as a criticism of the author of the report. He sought to do an extremely difficult job in reviewing literature across a wide range of disciplines. As anybody who has been engaged in a review of literature knows, once one tends to wander outside one's field of expertise one enters an absolute minefield and the most pertinent information can be left aside. As I said, this is not to be taken as a criticism of the author, whose review of the literature I think is a very good one. Nevertheless, he has left aside a couple of relevant documents that I believe would have altered quite considerably that review. I refer to page 32 of volume No. 1, in which a comparison is made of two items-the consumer demand theory in relation to tertiary students and the human capital theory in relation to tertiary students. I hope at some stage in the future to elaborate on the comments on the human capital theory if indeed we ever get the chance again in this chamber to discuss the Budget Papers. But in the meantime, may I make some comments. I think that the author has missed the point almost entirely when he talks about human capital theory.

This is because he relies on one source of information on human capital theory. In this respect I draw the attention of honourable senators to footnote 52. The major work that has been done in that area to date has been carried out by Edward Denison of the United States of America. His work established the technical base of human capital theory and provided a vast amount of documentation. I think that if the author had relied on the work of Edward Denison a completely different type of construction would have been put on his report. We would have then seen the extreme importance of support available for tertiary studies. Unfortunately, the author thinks that human capital theory has something to do with whether or not there is an investment on the part of the student. Human capital theory is posited on the basis that it is an investment on the part of a country. That difference, I think, then tends to vitiate some of the comments that he goes on to make. I believe that is unfortunate in an otherwise very interesting review.

TALK.START.PARA: —It should be based on a different view-on the funding.

—Yes. It should be based on the funding and not on the individual student. I make that point because I believe that to take that at face value would indeed be a destruction of one of the major arguments that one would want to raise in this area.

SPEECH.PARA: I pass now to volumes 2 and 3 and make some comments about the actual study. I reiterate the point that unfortunately here again while we have a worthwhile and useful study there are fundamental flaws in the conclusions which the study drew in relation to student incomes and expenditures. I will mention briefly a couple of these conclusions. The first point is the serious flaw in the failure to account for the value of the in kind and direct financial assistance given by parents and others. This is understandable because the actual study was undertaken mainly in terms of questionnaires. But it is not merely a minor problem; 40 per cent of the respondents reported receiving in kind assistance in food; 37 per cent reported receiving in kind assistance in accommodation, 42 per cent reported receiving in kind assistance in clothing, 28 per cent reported receiving in kind assistance in the use of a vehicle and 41 per cent reported receiving in kind assistance for medical and dental purposes. The in kind assistance which is given by parents, relatives, friends or by some system of sharing that is fairly typical of tertiary students is really an extremely important area. What we find is that about half the students surveyed receive in kind assistance for those items which make up a very large proportion of average expenditure. There is an unfortunate aspect to the survey. Students were asked to estimate the cash value of this particular assistance. The report states:
. . . in a large proportion of cases, respondents were not able to give an actual amount, and hence no attempt was made to analyse this component of the data.

While in an academic study that may be acceptable, when one wants to make a policy decision based upon this particular item and a report actually says that no attempt was made to analyse the component of the data particular students could suffer greatly. Let me give an example. As it stands we could have a situation of two students living in identical accommodation with one receiving free rent from parents and the other paying $1,300 per annum in rent to a group household. The average annual rent expenditure is thus $650, a figure which gives a completely misleading impression of what students spend and what is the cost of accommodation. I believe that that is a matter of grave concern in that report.

The areas of expenditure are likely to be affected by failure to take into account the in kind payments that can be derived from the various expenditure tables contained in the report. I hope that the people who undertook the report will do a re-analysis of the data. That data obviously is available and it could be re-analysed to take account of those particular methodological problems. If we eliminate those people who were not able to respond because they could not give a cash value we may then have a closer estimate of the remaining number in the study. Since this study has in fact a fair data base, I do not believe there would be any problems in suggesting that it might be unrepresentative. There would be no problem in a runback through the data in a computer to put in validating mechanisms to make sure that our sample remains representative. I believe that if we do that, and I hope that these authors will do a follow-up paper on that particular point, we will find that the accommodation figure, instead of being relatively low, will be a lot higher. That particular point goes for all of the other six items.

It seems to me that we have an averaging report and not a true reflection report. That is of grave concern, I think, to people who want to make sure that we can get a fair and clear picture of what is happening in the area of student allowances. I hope that the Government will request the authors to do that type of work again. I am quite sure that the authors would be interested to enter into a debate on that particular issue.
I make one last point on volume 3, the validation studies. Again, I do not wish to raise problems about the competence of the author. I quote from the actual validation study report, which states:

Our examination was based on ascertaining whether students' answers to the September 1979 survey of their financial position showed any evidence of systematic overstatement of their expenditure-possibly in order to strengthen the case for a subsequent increase in TEAS allowance.

That type of validation is thoroughly reputable. Any validation study must look at the veracity of the answers of people to questionnaires. That part of the study is very well done. Unfortunately, the validation studies do not enter into the adequacy of the survey questions and the method of analysing responses which also ought to be done in any validation study. I am suggesting that we have one-third of what would be a very useful validation study. I believe that that study is very well done.

We are getting a good response in terms of the veracity of those answers. What we do not know at this particular point is the adequacy of the survey questions. It surprises me, in some sense, that the authors have not given that information in the report. It is a normal part of a validation study, so I believe that it is somewhere around. I would like to be able to see that element of the study. It is a normal way of doing such a study. I do not know whether the authors looked into the validation of the method. In other words, one method in a study such as this would be to have an evaluation person from outside come in and make sure that a method of analysis was done. The validation study people would be the correct people to do that particular analysis of the methods. Again, as it is not in the report one can only raise doubts as to whether it was done.

Saying those things in a sense, I think, leaves me to point out that we have a good data base but we do not know what the real conclusions are. They are not contained in these reports, but I believe they would be contained in the data. I look forward, at some time in the future, to our getting that further information which will allow us to have a reasonable and rational debate on this matter. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN NATIONAL PARKS AND WILDLIFE SERVICE

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Robertson Sen E.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.
I seek leave to continue my remarks at a later stage.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

In doing so I congratulate the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) and his Department on the production of a clearly and attractively produced and informative and, for the most part, comprehensive annual report. When one is confronted by a report of this kind, touching as it does on every single thing that the Department and its various satellites do or should be doing, one of course is tempted to make a speech of Castro-like dimensions and, with respect to the Attorney-General's Department, at least in some respect, with Castro-like invective. But I will for the moment resist that temptation and comment only that it does continue to be a matter of profound disappointment to me and indeed to the Opposition that a department which does contain within its ranks so much expertise and so much real capacity for performance, as was amply demonstrated during the period of administration of this Department by Senator Lionel Murphy-he is now Mr Justice Murphy-should have such a poor record when it comes to actual substantive achievements of the kind that are retailed in this report. The hard truth of the matter is that the reform process, which must be of the essence in the administration of any Attorney-General's portfolio if he is to be doing his job and exercising his responsibility to the nation, has simply almost ground to a halt during the tenure of the current regime. I do not stop to give chapter and verse on that because I do that almost every day of the week in this Parliament in the context of Australian Law Reform Commission reports and in the context most recently of the sluggishness demonstrated by the Department in formulating a response to the very apt and very sensible proposals of the Joint Select Committee on the Family Law Act. There are many other such examples which we of the Opposition are constantly raising.

The point I make is the obvious one, that is, that all departments do derive a great deal of momentum, or the converse of momentum, from their Minister, the ministerial head of the department. The reality of the matter is that so long as Senator Durack, for whom I have the greatest affection as an individual, remains in office as this nation's Attorney-General which, according to recent rumours, it must be said, may not be for very much longer, it will--

TALK.START.PARA: —Not more than two years, anyway.

—It certainly will not be more than two years. I endorse the prescience of my colleague, Senator Colston, in that respect. So long as Senator Durack does remain in office the Department will be a lethargic one not realising its true capacity and its true potential.

SPEECH.PARA: The only other brief comment I make relates to the timing of this report and indeed other departmental reports. I simply make the fairly obvious point that it would be a great advantage not only to the community at large but also and more particularly to this chamber and to individual senators within it if these reports could be made available prior to Estimates committee hearings at least perhaps in some unprinted draft form.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did, with some difficulty.

—The Minister is reminding me increasingly of the junior George Washington-unable to tell a lie, incapable of any immorality, squeaky clean. I do not know how the Minister can survive very much longer in this chamber. I simply make the obvious point that it is advantageous to the committees to have these reports available to them in some form, whether they are printed or not. I do not underestimate the difficulties in their compilation and certainly in their production. But the Attorney-General's Department is a well-managed department. Whether it is a well-led or a productive department is another question. I simply hope that this can be an area that will be the subject of some improvement in the future. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

In doing so I make some really rather serious comments. The situation revealed by this very short report would be farcical if it were not so serious. We are talking of the report of the Security Appeals Tribunal that was set up, with a great deal of fanfare and a great deal of legislative detail backing it, under the Australian Security intelligence Organization Act 1979 to review adverse or qualified security assessments issued by ASIO on persons in government employment, persons employed by Commonwealth contractors who have access to security classified matter or secure areas and also persons who come within the provisions of the Migration Act, the Passports Act, the Citizenship Act and the associated regulations.

The Opposition, at the time of the establishment of the Tribunal, welcomed it. It had no objection at all to the concept of it or to the membership of the Tribunal when it was appointed. The four members, under the chairmanship of Mr Justice Samuels, did seem to be as well chosen as one could expect from this Government, and certainly we had nothing adverse to say in that respect. But we did have a number of objections to the jurisdiction that was vested in the Tribunal and the scope of the Tribunal's authority. In particular we had a very strong objection, which of course we maintain, to the fact the Tribunal has no capacity to review adverse assessments made prior to the commencement of the operation of the new ASIO legislation and the new powers associated with that legislation. So, going right back into the distant past and the more recent past as well, in respect of those who have reason to believe that their employment prospects have been prejudiced or their applications for citizenship have been denied or their applications to migrate to Australia or to have a passport issued to them have been denied for security reasons, no one of that numerous class of people who feel so aggrieved, for better or for worse, is able, under the terms of this legislation, in fact to do anything about it to ensure that their appeals are heard and determined by this highly qualified Tribunal under the elaborate procedures that were set up to govern the hearing, largely in camera, of such appeals.

Equally, we had profound reservations about and we expressed profound objections to the sort of catch-22 provision, if I can use that rather overworked expression which again is perfectly apt here, which is embodied in the legislation whereby there is absolutely no guarantee that someone who is the recipient of an adverse security assessment will in fact be able to have that adverse assessment tested before the Tribunal, the catch lying in fact that under section 38 of the ASIO Act the Attorney-General is vested with the power to certify that it is inappropriate for a person to be given knowledge of the fact that the adverse security assessment in question has been made. So there can be a situation in which, if the Attorney-General is satisfied that on the grounds of security the person ought not to be told that he has been the subject of an adverse security assessment, the preconditions for the operation of an appeal against that assessment are simply not satisfied. Therefore, the Attorney-General is able to cut off at the knees without the person in question, whatever the suspicions might be of having been dealt with in this way, being able to do anything about it. That seemed very unsatisfactory in principle and we said that loudly and clearly at the time.

If we look at the report of the Tribunal to see what has happened since it came into operation on 1 June 1980, I think it was, we find that our fears in that respect have in fact been significantly confirmed because since the establishment of the Tribunal on that date it appears that the Tribunal has done precisely nothing except to conduct one preliminary conference and to engage in a rather bizarre game of musical chairs so far as the staff and the composition of the Tribunal are concerned, but it has not actually heard and determined one single security appeal. In the 12 months, which covers almost the entire period of the Tribunal's existence, the 12 months that are the subject of this one and a half page report, it appears that just three applications to review an assessment have been received-one on 7 November 1980, one on April Fool's Day 1981 and one on 9 June. The progress in respect of those three appeals has been non-existent. There was, we are told, a preliminary conference in respect of one of them, one of them sought an adjournment and the other has not been heard or determined at all. So, in fact, we have a situation in which in fact three appeals have been instituted and none has come to any kind of fruition.

A number of unsatisfactory features which may lie behind the text of this report although it is difficult to appreciate the significance of them at the moment. One of them concerns the denial of legal assistance which is supposed to be available under section 72 of the Act. We were told by the Attorney-General this was denied in one of these cases but we were not told why it was denied, whether it was on the ground of insufficient need or for some other reason. That apart, the main point I want to make is that there has been an absolutely derisory output from the Tribunal. Presumably, not so much as a result of any defalcation of duty on behalf of the members of the Tribunal itself or their hardly overworked staff but rather simply because no business of any significant kind is coming before them.

I notice that one of the, I think, two staff members allocated to serve-presumably part time-the Tribunal has thrown in the towel altogether. The report says that a Miss Leslie Ann Davidson resigned from the staff in February 1981 but her position has not been filled. As to the other staff member, the existance of whom we know about, I remind the Senate of the report that appeared in the Sydney Morning Herald on 3 June this year which prompted a question from me in this chamber to the Attorney. It concerned Mr Fred Hawkins-who was the professional permanent staff member of the Tribunal and himself a principal legal officer in the Attorney-General's Department-who was reported as saying that the lack of work was close to driving him 'up the wall'. That was the situation so far as the Tribunal was concerned.

It is very much a matter for us to be asking now, on the occasion of this report being brought down, why that is so. Is it the case that there are simply no security risks around Australia any more and that nobody is getting an adverse assessment either within Commonwealth employment, within the class of Commonwealth contractors or among people applying for citizenship or passports or applying to migrate to Australia? Is it the case that there has been a remarkable increase in the cleanliness and godliness of applicants and employees of these various classes such that it is just not necessary for there to be adverse assessments? That is one possible interpretation. A second possible interpretation is that there has been no such increase in the necessity to make such adverse assessments but that there has been an increase in ASIO's incapacity to make such assessments; that it is not doing its job properly, not weeding such people out and not making the assessments. That may or may not be the case but it does not sit too closely with the other kind of data-that I will come to in a moment-available about ASIO's role these days.

The third possible interpretation seems to me to be the much more likely one; that is that ASIO in fact is working quite actively, as it always has in this area, and is making a large number of adverse security assessments but that the Attorney-General is exercising his statutory powers under section 38 of the Act-that I have referred to previously-not to make available to the persons who are the subject of those security assessments the information about their receipt of such adverse assessments. Of course, it may be the case that lots of people are being advised of adverse assessments and are choosing not to do anything about it. We have not any figures to enable us to make such a judgment. It may be the case that the Attorney-General is not making many such certifications. But he will not tell us.

We sought to question him about this in this chamber three of four months ago, on 3 June in fact, the day that report about Mr Hawkins's anguish in his trade was revealed. The Attorney-General then said he did not propose to make available that information about the number of times-not the individual cases-he had exercised that power to record an adverse assessment. So we just do not know what is going on beneath the surface. Of course, that mirrors our ignorance that is so apparent in so many different aspects of the way in which this Australian Security Intelligence Organisation actually works. That is an unhappy state of affairs. The leaked annual report of ASIO is, I imagine, a fairly sanitised report because after all it was only the one going to the politicians and a copy was to be made available to the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden). So one would expect that it would not contain too much that was especially sensitive. But even the presumably sanitised annual report of the Organisation revealed in the National Times of 28 June made it clear not only that the budget of the Organisation-as indeed we know from the one-line appropriations that we see in this Parliament-has increased by nearly 300 per cent since the Fraser Government came to power but also, it appears from the scant information we have, that three times as many wire taps were also in operation in the last year as were in operation in 1973, which is the last year for which we had comparable information put on the public record-in that instance by the then Attorney-General, Senator Murphy, making it publicly available.

What is worse, we learnt from this annual report-it has not been subsequently denied that this is so by anyone in government-that many new classes of organisations seem to have come under active surveillance by ASIO 'with increased attention', to use the language of the report, in particular being given to monitoring of anti-uranium and unemployment groups. There was no attempt in the text of the report to justify that happening. That is the situation. We have an increase in ASIO activity and allegations continuing to be made about the overreach by ASIO of its activities; by Scientology organisations, for better or for worse, in the context of the case now before the High Court; in the matter I raised two days ago about the indiscriminate interception of telexes and telegrams in whole postal areas even though only one individual within such postal areas is the subject of the warrant in question; and we now have the allegations brought to the attention of the Attorney today in Question Time about the monitoring or interception of telephone conversations passing to or from radio stations during the course of the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting.

I make the point that if the Government is really serious about civil liberties and if it is confident that ASIO is acting within a reasonably civilised charter and acting effectively in that way then it should open up the jurisdiction of this Tribunal in the way that was earlier urged by the Australian Labor Party and make it a genuine forum for people who are the recipients, for better or for worse, of this kind of assessment to have the quality and accuracy of that assessment objectively tested. I seek leave to continue my remarks at a later stage.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

The Australian Institute of Marine Science is of great value to Australian science, and in particular to the science faculties of the Queensland universities at Townsville and Brisbane. Therefore, honourable senators from that area have viewed the progress of the Institute with great interest. In addition to wishing the Institute well, I want to attract attention to one paragraph of the statement by its Chairman. Perhaps if I read it that will truncate my remarks. The Chairman said:

The past two years have been very important in the further development of the Institute and its research program. Following the decision of the Government in 1979-80 to increase the number of research scientists from eight to nineteen, approval was given in 1980-81 for an additional twenty-one support positions. The Council acknowledges the strong support given by the Australian Science and Technology Council (ASTEC) in these developments.

The implementation of these two decisions brought the total full-time staff of AIMS to 105. However, this approved complement has recently been reduced to 103 in line with the Government's staff ceiling policy.

Even though that is a reduction of only two staff members, in a developing Institute of this sort, which is merely in its foundation-building stages, it represents a retreat from fulfilment of the original intentions of the previous Government, under which the Institute was created, and this Government, which has supported it by considerable funding. The Chairman stated further:

. . . One consequence of this and the accompanying constraint on future funding is that it became necessary to defer the appointment of a senior scientist as Assistant Director which had been planned following international advertisement.
In fact, the position was advertised but the appointment was not proceeded with. The Chairman added:

DEBATE.TITLE: SUPERVISING SCIENTIST FOR THE ALLIGATOR RIVERS REGION

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Report on the Unauthorised Release of Water at Nabarlek on 7 March 1981

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator MASON
TALKER.ROLE: Acting Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I propose to make some brief comments on this significant matter because the importance of the Supervising Scientist's role in what has been called the uranium province is vital. His authority and right to suggest standards, based on the knowledge he has acquired throughout the world-knowledge to which we know he does have access-ought to be applied. The way for it to be applied is by the Commonwealth Government, whose arm the Supervising Scientist is in this regard.

The late reporting of the escape of water at Nabarlek was disquieting in itself. I am prepared to accept, on what we have heard so far, that no great damage was done. That does not alter the fact that a great deal of damage could in fact have been done. We have to consider that this happened at Nabarlek, which is one of the richest uranium mines in the world, an undertaking which is making enormous profits, far greater than was ever visualised. I would have thought it possible for that organisation to have guaranteed a situation in which it could abide by its word, and what was required in that regard-that there should be no release of water, under any weather circumstances, from uranium mines.

This is a key question-that is why I want to raise it-that must now apply to both existing uranium mines in Australia, particularly those where the weather patterns are extreme, as is the case in the Northern Territory, and future mines, if any. I say 'if any' because there is such doubt about the future of uranium, and nuclear power generally, that I question whether any real purpose is to be served by having additional uranium mines in Australia. That view is increasingly supported by world opinion. However, in the case of existing mines and projected mines-if they should go ahead-there must be adequate containment of contaminated water, which includes contamination by heavy metals. Of course, in that part of the world the heavy metals include radium.

The weather patterns of the Northern Territory are well known. Its climate is unpredictable and very heavy rain can and does occur regularly. Therefore, it is essential that any uranium mine in that area should have sufficiently stable, and large, pondage to contain all contaminated water that might be released under any circumstances. Anything less than that, is not good enough. I say that because we are associating uranium mining in Australia with the co-existence of the Kakadu National Park, which is one of the most remarkable, unique and beautiful national parks in the world. As has been conceded by the Government, it is a world asset and, as I have predicted before, and will predict again, it will be one of Australia's most valuable economic resources in terms of tourism, into the indefinite future. Unlike uranium mining, which will fizzle out in a foreseeable time, the Kakadu National Park will be of enormous and continuing importance.

In view of the world oversupply of uranium and the doubtful prospects for these mines now, I would say that very few other nations would even consider allowing projected uranium mines to be continued with, much less that there should be any further depredation of that area. I say 'depredation' advisedly, because the Nabarlek incident has shown us that the uranium miners are not levelling and that the Supervising Scientist does not have enough power to do what he should do in this regard.

I would like to speak of the applications of this incident and the shadow that it casts on the future, particularly in relation to the proposed Pancontinental mine at Jabiluka. This is proposed to be one of the largest uranium mines in the world. It is being placed in a position on the banks of Magela Creek. When the Senate Standing Committee on Science and the Environment, on which I have the honour to serve, last visited the area it found that as a result of a cyclone-cyclones occur regularly in that area-the No. 1 ore body was in fact under water and the buildings there had to be hastily evacuated. This is the place where it is proposed to have an underground uranium mine of considerable proportions. What I am saying is that if we proceed with this folly, at least the Government has a responsibility to see that sufficient money is provided and that sufficient plans are drawn up. If the mining at Jabiluka proceeds, at all times-including times of cyclones and floods-there must be sufficient pondage to hold any waste products and any flood waters which might enter the mine. If flood waters enter the mines they will be entering areas of radioactive mineralisation. It is essential that those waters should not under any circumstances escape into Magela Creek.

Why Magela Creek? Magela Creek has an important geographical significance. It is a tributary of the East Alligator River, which is the most beautiful, unique and interesting part of the Kakadu National Park region. It is distinctive and it is a very fragile environment. Its future tourist potential will depend absolutely on its being pristine and unspoiled. It is an asset to the country in that regard. Already water from the Ranger uranium mine is going into that creek. The two mines are very close together. I suggest that the Government have a good look at the figures. More than we would like is escaping into Magela Creek through seepage from the holding dams at Ranger. The point about this is that the effectiveness of those holding containers around the holding ponds is related directly to the amount of money that the uranium company can be persuaded to spend on the impermeability of them. This is something that has to be looked at very carefully.

Why is Magela Creek particularly important? It is important for this reason: Particularly in flood times water from Magela Creek does not escape to the sea. When the tide is rising in the lower reaches of the East Alligator River, water which is backing up from Magela Creek is carried upstream into the whole of the rest of the East Alligator River region. I repeat that this is a national park area of vital importance. We are not just talking about some backwoods area. We should regard the risks to it as extreme. I ask that the Government immediately consider going to the miners as they exist now-I hope that nobody will deny that enormous profits have been reaped from the Nabarlek mine; fantastic dividends-and insisting that if any further uranium mine is to be developed in the East Alligator region of the park, especially if it is anywhere near Magela Creek, adequate funds should be provided in advance by Pancontinental Mining Ltd, if it intends to go ahead, to ensure and guarantee that there will be no release of water under any circumstances whatsoever. It should insist also that penalties against the company responsible be provided for in the contract in the event of any release. I think it is reasonable that if a company goes into a national park of importance and is prepared to exploit it, it should also be prepared to accept full responsibility for any damage that it may cause. That is all we are asking the Government to do.

What I am saying now is that the Government immediately ought to authorise the Supervising Scientist to view the matter in that light, to get world opinion on it and to draw up a system of water pondage and storage at Jabiluka which can be presented to Pancontinental. The system should be regarded by the Government and the Supervising Scientist-not by Pancontinental, which is an interested party, but by outside sources-of being capable of making sure that there is no release of contaminated water with heavy metals or radioactive substances from that mine under any conceivable circumstances. I would like to see that proposal presented to Pancontinental, which can then do a costing on it. I think we can proceed adequately on that basis.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —It appears to me that the remarks passed by the previous speaker, Senator Mason, need some endorsement. There was a spillage of wastes from holding ponds at the Nabarlek uranium mine which the company concerned was late in reporting to the Supervising Scientist. We are now told that the problems caused were not all that grave. It would seem that the Supervising Scientist should have been notified earlier. Indeed, the company should not have allowed that spillage to occur.

SPEECH.PARA: It has occurred to me that the same sort of situation is developing at the Ben Lomond mine in Queensland, where already there has been leaching and seepage from a stored ore body. The situation will be aggravated by heavy rain in the wet season in January and February. I do not believe the Commonwealth has looked at what is happening in that area. The Supervising Scientist or Commonwealth scientists should look at what is happening in that area. The Supervising Scientist or Commonwealth scientists should look at what is happening in that region as well. I believe the undertaking given by the company is not sufficient to ensure that mining operations will not put into jeopardy the Burdekin River system. If seepage or leakage occurs in that area it will cause problems. If the Federal Government intends to allocate money for the development of the Burdekin River system, I believe the Supervising Scientist and his Office should look at what is happening with uranium mining in that area. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Reference to Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Scott) agreed to:

That the following matter be referred to the Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence: Australia's defence co-operation with its neighbours in the Asian-Pacific region, with particular reference to the present scope, purpose, effectiveness and flexibility of such co-operation.
Motion (by Senator Durack) agreed to:
That leave be given to introduce a Bill for an Act to amend the Crimes Act 1914, and for related purposes.
Bill presented, and read a first time.
Standing Orders suspended.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill will update and revise a number of the provisions of the Crimes Act 1914 to take into account modern concepts, particularly in the area of sentencing, and to remove anomalies and defects revealed in the recent administration of the Act. The amendments will firstly require courts to consider whether some form of non-custodial punishment may be imposed instead of imprisonment on offenders against Commonwealth and Australian Capital Territory laws and the laws of prescribed external Territories. It is provided in relation to offences described in the Bill that a court is not to pass a sentence of imprisonment unless the court, after having considered all other available sentences, is satisfied that no other sentence is appropriate in all the circumstances of the case. This accords with modern thinking that imprisonment should be imposed only as a measure of last resort. The amendments will also make available to the courts, when dealing with Commonwealth offenders, sentencing options such as community service orders now available in relation to State and Territory offenders.

The provisions of the Act dealing with the conditional release of Commonwealth offenders have been remodelled. Conditions upon which an offender may be released include the condition that the offender make restitution or pay compensation to the victim of the crime and the condition that the offender will submit to probationary supervision. In addition, the court may order that the offender is to pay a pecuniary penalty in a lump sum or by instalments. This condition and the condition relating to restitution, when combined with probationary supervision, will provide a practicable alternative to imprisonment. The legislation additionally revises and updates pecuniary penalties in the Crimes Act. Provision is also made to enable offenders on whom a fine has been imposed to apply either for time to pay the fine or for payment of the fine by instalments.

In line with the laws of several States provisions are to be inserted into the Crimes Act under which a court, when sentencing a Commonwealth offender, will be empowered to take into account, for the purpose of imposing sentence, other offences in relation to which the defendant has admitted his guilt. Where a defendant before a court on one charge has also pending against him charges in relation to other and less serious offences in respect of which he admits guilt, the amendment will remove the need for the defendant to be convicted in relation to all the offences and enable the court when sentencing him for the primary offence also to take into account the commission of the other offences provided the defendant consents.

The legislation also effects amendments to the bribery provisions of the Crimes Act as recommended in the report of the Committee of Inquiry concerning Public Duty and Private Interest known as the Bowen report. As recommended by the Committee, the amendments will remove present uncertainty as to application of the criminal law to bribery of members of parliament. The amendments will also, as recommended by the Committee, extend the application of the Crimes Act to Commonwealth officers obtaining or attempting to obtain a bribe for a third party or agreeing to accept a bribe.

I have been aware for some time of the need to revise the Crimes Act to provide the courts with a better range of options when dealing with Commonwealth offenders. The need to stress to the courts that they should regard imprisonment as a punishment of last resort when sentencing Commonwealth offenders has also been apparent. At the first conference of Australian magistrates held in Sydney in June 1978 a number of deficiencies in Commonwealth law in relation to sentencing were aired in considerable detail. I pointed out to the attending magistrates that I had a major personal interest in the whole policy of sentencing and in providing alternative punishments to the punishment of imprisonment. I undertook to initiate a review of the relevant sections of the Crimes Act, particularly those relating to the conditional release of offenders.

In 1978, the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General considered a paper submitted by me, in connection with preparations for the Sixth United Nations Crime Congress, on the subject of sentencing. That paper recommended, among other things, that consideration be given by a law reform commission of the Commonwealth or the States to the revision of the laws with respect to sentencing to promote the greater use of alternatives to imprisonment, having regard to the costs and other unsatisfactory features of punishment by imprisonment. The paper also stressed the need for legislation to be introduced to provide that no person be sentenced to imprisonment unless the court is of the opinion that, having regard to all the circumstances of the case, no other sentence is appropriate. The Standing Committee agreed that the matter be submitted to the Commonwealth's Law Reform Commission. On 11 August 1978 I referred the question of the sentencing of federal offenders to the Commission and in 1980 the Commission delivered an interim report on the reference. Certain of the Commission's recommendations are given effect to in the present Bill and other provisions of the Bill reflect the experience of my Department in the day to day administration of the Crimes Act.

Another important question is the development of sentencing guidelines. The development of guidelines on a systematic basis to provide a greater consistency and uniformity in sentencing should, in my view, be encouraged. I have therefore written to the States and Northern Territory Attorneys-General proposing that a sentencing council consisting of Federal, State and Territory judges be established administratively to discuss sentencing guidelines. The present Bill does not represent a complete revision of the Crimes Act. A number of other aspects require review and these will be undertaken by my Department next year. The Bill does, however, deal with the more pressing matters requiring attention and effects practical reforms of real worth and significance. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

Upon which Senator Grimes had moved by way of amendment:

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Townley Sen M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Senator Jessop I seek leave to amend the motion to read as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: That the following matter be referred to the Standing Committee on Science and the Environment: The use of pesticides, particularly phenoxy chemicals and chemicals containing dioxin with reference to:
(a) their ecological effects; and
(b) their effects on human and animal health;
and that in considering this matter the Committee deal first with the possible effects on Vietnam veterans of exposure to herbicides.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-In moving this amendment to the terms of reference for this inquiry, the Standing Committee on Science and the Environment is ensuring that all pesticides, both herbicides and insecticides, to which Vietnam veterans were exposed can be examined within the scope of the inquiry. Specifically, the term 'pesticides' will allow such chemicals as agent blue, a mixture of cacodylic acid and sodium cacodylate, and malathion to be included. While both these substances were used in Vietnam, neither is a phenoxy herbicide or contains dioxin.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to point out that it is the intention of the Committee to focus firstly on health problems of the Vietnam veterans as they relate to this inquiry. To this end, evidence will be heard firstly from the Vietnam Veterans Association of Australia, secondly from the Commonwealth Institute of Health, which is conducting the epidemiological study into the possible links between exposure to herbicides and current health problems, and thirdly from the Department of Veterans' Affairs.
