PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 9 September, on motion by Senator Peter Baume:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Epidemiological Studies (Confidentiality) Bill 1981 provides for the protection of the confidentiality of information provided for epidemiological surveys conducted by the Commonwealth. Through the usual method of fines and penalties the privacy of such information is protected, with an added retrospective provision to cover the pilot study on Vietnam veterans which is in progress. The Opposition does not oppose the legislation. However, we will move an amendment expressing a view we have about the situation of the Vietnam veterans and their problem with herbicides. We will not delay at all the passing of this legislation because the success of such surveys depends on an adequate response which, in turn, depends on the guarantee of privacy and confidentiality given to those who are being surveyed.

SPEECH.PARA: The survey which has brought this matter to the Parliament is, of course, that applying to Vietnam veterans. It is necessary as part of the investigation into the claims and fears that veterans have for themselves and their offspring as a result of exposure to the herbicide 2,4,5-T and its contaminant dioxin and exposure to other herbicides used in that unfortunate conflict. The predictions of the results of the pilot study being conducted make it obvious that the full epidemiological survey to be conducted will take much longer than was previously suggested and further delay providing some basic knowledge necessary to any rational assessment of the situation as it affects the veterans. If we proceed at the present rate in dealing with the investigation of these claims and if we insist on a high degree of scientific proof, as the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner) seems to insist, which is something we do not do for veterans in other circumstances, then I believe we will never make a decision.

There is no argument, except, from the most blind, that 2,4,5-T and, in particular, dioxin are toxic in various ways. The world has known that since the late 1940s. What we need at the moment is an assessment of the evidence that is available and the facts as they are known. That would be done in any claim for compensation and it should be done in this claim for compensation by the veterans of the Vietnam war. The Opposition believes, and I think many of the Vietnam veterans believe, that the best way to assess the information and the evidence which is already available is to do what one would do in any claim for compensation, that is, conduct a judicial inquiry. We persist with out belief that that should occur, despite the fall-back position we have now with the Senate Committee on Science and the Environment investigating the effect of these herbicides. It is for that reason that, on behalf of the Opposition, I move:
At end of motion, add
', but the Senate is of the opinion that the Vietnam Veterans Study referred to in the Bill should be supported by a wide judicial inquiry.'

We do so not to delay the Bill but to express again our view that the veterans cannot consistently and persistently be left in the position of uncertainty and anxiety caused by their lack of knowledge of what has happened to them through their exposure to these herbicides, through their lack of knowledge of what has happened to their offspring, and through their inability to get full assistance and compensation for serving our country in that war.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Giles Sen P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Labor Party would not deny the need for confidentiality in studies of this nature, and the importance of confidentiality of individual information on individuals is certainly not to be denied. There are questions in the minds of a number of Vietnam veterans about whether the results of the pilot study can be made use of or whether they may be witheld from other organisations or associations of ex-servicemen prior to what has been stated as being the very long period that will be needed for the full-scale study. In fact, a recent statement from the National President of the Vietnam Veterans Association of Australia includes these words:

SPEECH.PARA: If you would care to contact any expert in the field of epidemiological studies you will find as I have that what the Australian Government proposes will take up to or even more than a twenty year period.

We also hope that the aggregate results will be made available for responsible scientific use. One wonders, too, whether the associations themselves had been consulted about the need perhaps for such stringent measures to maintain confidentiality. One might draw the Senate's attention to the fact that it is paradoxical, I suppose, that veterans have been prepared to go very public in order to draw attention to their plight and the plight of their families and offspring.

The questionnaire that has been distributed and available for some months is in itself a very daunting document. Amongst its 70 sets of questions there are many with 10 to 14 parts. Question Nos 22 to 23 focus on the veterans's recollections of his service in Vietnam. Some of those questions have eight, nine or ten parts. Social scientists tend to reject the validity of a study which depends on the memories of the participants. In this case we are asking people to remember very fine details of what occurred to them 10 or even 15 years ago. Many of the veterans complain, amongst many other things, of a loss of memory, of loss of concentration and of problems with recalling details. The thoroughly horrifying experiences that they have had in their years in Vietnam are such that many of them would have deliberately sought to erase them from their memories. Surely the records of operations of the Australian Army are available officially. Surely it is possible from those records to tell who was where and why on what dates. Surely this would be better to do this plan that to jeopardise the validity of an important study such as this by requesting the Vietnam veterans themselves to provide such details, a task which I suggest is completely beyond the capacity of very many of them. In fact, it has been suggested to me that the veterans themselves while on service in Vietnam knew very little about the nature of the operations apart from their own individual place in those operations. Obviously, in the case of capture, the dictum was 'the less you know the better'.

The fact that this study is relying upon information from veterans themselves may very well make the results considerably more questionable than would otherwise be the case if they were backed up by hard data. The results may very well be inaccurate and incomplete. In the event that the information is among the Army records, will the recollections of the veterans be checked against the records? As I say, for some of the veterans the questions they are being asked are impossible to answer. It seems to me that the fact that the questions are there may make the difference between whether the ex-serviceman responds to the questionnaire and whether he does not, especially if he feels that his memory is suspect, that his answers may be checked against Army records and then discarded. This exercise also may add only to the cynicism and the frustration of many of the veterans who feel that there is developing very rapidly a tendency to diagnose their problems as neurotic, psychosomatic and hysterical. They are being disignated as psychologically disturbed because in many cases of the multiplicity of their clinical reactions.

The Returned Services League national solicitor, Mr John Button, prepared a background paper well over 12 months ago in which he listed 48 different types of clinical reactions being complained of at that stage by Vietnam veterans. Eleven of those 48 might be categorised as the types of symptoms very likely to lead a medical adviser to diagnose neurosis or psychosis. Much of the publicity around the scandal, if I may put it in such strong words, of the herbicides and pesticides to which Vietnam veterans may have been exposed has concentrated on agent orange and its contaminant dioxin. The effect of agent orange on humans, as Senator Grimes says, has been well known for quite a long time. Many of the other chemicals which were used have also been well known for a very long time because of their adverse effects upon human beings. One of those was agent blue-cacodylic acid. The first shipment of herbicide blue was received in Vietnam in 1962. Between 1962 and 1964 5,000 gallons of this chemical were used. Between January 1965 and February 1971 over 1.1 million gallons were used. Symptoms of acute poisoning from cacodylic acid are well known as the symptoms of arsenical poisoning. In fact, cacodylic acid is an organic compound of arsenic yielding inorganic trivalent arsenic in the body. That is the arsenic which is highly toxic to human beings. Symptoms of this type of acute poisoning are headache, vomiting, diarrhoea, dizziness, stupor, convulsions, general paralysis and ultimately death. Amongst the non-fatal symptoms would be many which would be familiar to Vietnam veterans.

Malathion was used in significantly large quantities. This substance has widespread effects which are in accordance with its effect on the central nervous system, including vomiting, diarrhoea, pin-point pupils, sweating, elevated blood pressure, weakness, anxiety, fever and, in very severe cases, coma. Acute toxic episodes are not infrequent and severe systemic disturbances caused by their muscarine-like and nicotine-like actions have been widely reported. The psychiatrists tell us that there are two types of psychiatric sequelae of chronic exposure. These are schizophrenia and depression. Effects on the central nervous system of malathion include giddiness, fainting, tremor, paralysis, speech difficulties, memory defects, insomnia, lassitude and weakness. Once again these are very familiar symptoms amongst those Vietnam veterans who have made their plight known. Other developments amongst a group of subjects who were studied very carefully include depression, irritability, lassitude and apathy. The subjects looked dejected and felt unhappy.

Dieldrin was another one of the most unpleasant chemicals used in considerable quantities in Vietnam. Most of us would have used this chemical in our homes. We have perhaps read the Shell booklet on the safe handling and the toxicology of dieldrin. Eleven symptoms of poisoning are listed and include headache, dizziness, blurred vision, abnormal sweating, loss of appetite and nausea. Paraquat-grammoxone is another of the extremely dangerous toxins which were spread about with great abandon in Vietnam during this period. Paraquat is highly toxic to man and there have been several reported fatalities. Literature which I have seen documents at least 200 deaths. If a man spends much of his time walking through spray drift which is prevented from dispersal by overhanging foliage there may be a risk of lung damage from fine particles and also of irritation from coarser particles trapped in the upper respiratory tract, possibly leading to nose bleeding. In such circumstances, a filter respirator should be worn. Paraquat must be handled carefully for it possesses toxicity to man, the nature of which is only gradually becoming evident. In particular this chemical, which has been widely used in suburban gardens, can be dangerous because there is no known antidote and restrictions on its sale have just been introduced.

Paraquat is a very interesting member of this family of chemicals. It was used first, as far as we know, by Australian troops in Vietnam in the week spread from Sunday 3 December 1967 to Friday 8 December 1967. The servicemen using this chemical were apparently using no protection whatsoever. At the end of the week's spraying they were asked to report whether they had any problems. They all reported with symptoms of breakdown in mucous membrane which included nosebleeds, ulceration of lips and conjunctivitis. From then on more stringent regulations were introduced and the servicemen were instructed that they should use rubber gloves, respirators and clothing which covered them from head to toe.

Although the servicemen are being required to state in the questionnaire whether they believe that they and their clothing had been contaminated, they are not being asked about the use of protective equipment or clothing. A set of regulations for the use of pesticides by Australian forces in South Vietnam emphasises time and again in the course of its seven or eight pages the danger of handling these particular substances carelessly. It gives detailed instructions for the use of full face respirators and gloves in relation to all procedures including mixing chemicals and preparation for spraying. It indicates how the servicemen should be careful to avoid spillage and splashing and points out that only those actually required for spraying should remain on the vehicle being used. It states that respirators and gloves are to be worn by all team members, and that sleeves are to be rolled down and long trousers worn. The officer in charge during the spraying procedure has to ensure that the team members are wearing respirators and gloves, and to be absolutely certain, among other things, that wind blown spray does not drift back on to the vehicles and operators.

There is a section on afterspraying procedure which is also quite detailed. The document concludes with an instruction that 10 gallons of fresh water is to be sprayed from the spray guns and that any spillage should be cleaned off using clean water. I have been assured that it is highly unlikely that on more than a very few occasions during the handling of these pesticides and herbicides in Vietnam the equipment was being used as instructed. Given the climate under which these people were working, the conditions and the general approach to hygiene, and, in addition, the shortage of water, it seems highly probable that in most cases the servicemen were being exposed to hazards which should have been appreciated but obviously were not.

Perhaps one of the most alarming parts of this set of regulations is the instruction which insists that empty containers should be carefully handled. The instruction says that empty containers can be a hazard. For example, drums and barrels converted into water storage tanks become sources of contamination of water. It has been suggested to me that it was a fairly common practice to use empty drums for the storage of water and for the storage of other foodstuffs and that it is highly unlikely that they would have been cleaned beforehand in accordance with the instructions that were issued but which were not seen and certainly not followed by the majority of ex-servicemen.

Records of the chemicals which were taken to and used in Vietnam have been made available, mostly through the United States authorities. We know the names of most of them and we have some idea of the quantities. The American Herbs Tapes tell us that there were something like 17 million gallons of herbicides of various types accounted for within those years in Vietnam. But nobody is quite certain what happened to another two million gallons which were transported to Vietnam and which are unaccounted for. I suggest that we are all reaching the point now where we believe that there is criminal neglect. There is no other way to describe it. A recent report in Australian newspapers tells us what happened to at least some of the two million gallons of herbicides which were previously unaccounted for. An article in the West Australian under a New York dateline of Thursday, 24 September, states:
The US has found new evidence that large numbers of American and allied troops in Vietnam were exposed to the defoliant Agent Orange.

Quoting 'just discovered records', the Reagan Administration's Secretary for Health and Human Services, Mr Richard Schweiker, said that there may have been as many as 41 Agent Orange sprayings of friendly troops.
The new information lists 90 US chemical spraying missions in Vietnam which were aborted either from aircraft engine failure or enemy fire.
Agent Orange being carried was dumped in at least 41 of these, Mr Schweiker said.
The chemical was dumped near US or allied military installations 'some directly over or near air bases.'
The Defence Department is now said to be trying to isolate the exact locations and is tracing weather patterns on the days the defoliant was dumped.
Until today the US admitted to only 1200 aircrew and ground staff being exposed to Agent Orange.

In addition to the extremely long, detailed and complicated questionnaire required to be completed by male ex-servicemen who were in Vietnam and, of course, the pilot group who were not, each wife or partner of an ex-serviceman is also required to complete a questionnaire, not quite so lengthy but certainly requiring of her a great deal of recall in relation to her own obstetric and gynaecological history over the past ten years. My criticisms of the questionnaire for the male are just as valid for this one. People's memories are notoriously unreliable in relation not only to their illnesses but also to unpleasant occurrences in their lives. Just as an ex-serviceman from Vietnam may very well not wish to recall the unpleasant details of his time in Vietnam, so it may be very difficult for a woman to recall the unpleasant and in some cases heartbreaking details of children born deformed or children who have died soon after birth.

I certainly hope that the counselling services for Vietnam veterans and their families that have been promised before the end of this year will be able to provide the sort of support and encouragement that those families will require. The results of this epidemiological study will not be of any assistance whatsoever for this generation; they probably will not be of any use until the next. There will be precious little comfort from biochemists, from epidemiologists or from geneticists for the wives and families of ex-servicemen in relation to the likelihood of their bearing more children with deformities. There will be very little proper information available to them, and certainly none as a result of this epidemiological study.

People in Atlanta in the United States of America are just a little more fortunate. The Sunday Times of 11 October reported that a large study is to be undertaken to determine the cause of birth defects in Atlanta and that the cost will reach $1.5m. The article reads:

Thirty investigators using telephone and city directories, voting lists, post office forwarding addresses . . . are tracing the parents of 7,000 infants born since 1968 with major birth defects. The parents of another 3,000 normal children will take part as controls.
The study is being done in . . . Atlanta . . . where the National Centre for Disease Control has been compiling a register of malformed infants for more than a decade.

The Atlanta parents are just that much more fortunate than any of the parents in Australia because there is no such information in Australia which would give a data base from which valid comparisons could be made at this stage.

In Western Australia a small study was initiated three years ago by a geneticist, a woman doctor, with a grant of $25,000 to start a congenital malformation register. This has been operating very well and continuously as of course, it must. The money, which was Federal funding, was sufficient to pay for the salaries of a part time geneticist and a part time nurse and for some help from a clerical assistant. The funding will cut out in 1982, which will make the register completely worthless. The study must be continuous if this register is to be of any value. Its value will not be apparent to any particular group or individual in the community until a record has been able to be compiled over a considerable period. The very nature of a study of this sort means that several years are needed to establish such a register. So little is known about congenital malformities in the community that when we are told that there is something like a 10 per cent rate of congenital malformity in the children of Western Australian veterans we have nothing against which to compare that rate in the population at large. We are told that the rate of serious, severe malformities may be 3 per cent or 4 per cent. If we are looking at moderate or not quite so severe ones it may be up to 7 per cent or 8 per cent. That is no comfort whatsoever to the Vietnam veterans and their families.

If we had had a register for any length of time there would be available evidence on which to assess the scares that have been rife over the last few years. The sort of data that that sort of register could provide is priceless, but we do not have it. The information would have provided to a small extent some peace of mind to the young families of young Vietnam veterans. That sounds like a contradiction in terms. They are certainly not veterans in the sense of being geriatrics. Most of them are less than 40 years of age. Most of them would be younger than the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. Many of them would be hoping still to have children.

It seems to me that many lessons should be learned from the debacle of Vietnam, and the particular horror of exposure to herbicides is certainly one of them. I hope that the message will be taken around Australia about the necessity to have public registers of congenital malformities so that in the future we will not be faced with no alternative other than to conducting a vastly expensive, extremely lengthy and probably useless epidemiological study.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Nobody will doubt, I am sure, the sincerity of any Australians who have taken part in this debate on behalf of Vietnam veterans, whether within or outside the Parliament. However, we do have some specifics to attract our attention in the Senate this afternoon. One of the specifics is the amendment moved by the Opposition which is in these terms:

SPEECH.PARA: At end of motion, add ', but the Senate is of the opinion that the Vietnam Veterans Study referred to in the Bill should be supported by a wide judicial inquiry'.

I mention that because Senator Giles has made an interesting contribution to the debate and mentioned a number of the issues that have been debated surrounding the total issue of agent orange. However, we are not going to pass judgment on the sincerity of Senator Giles or the validity of what she has said. We are here to pass into law a Bill which will enable the Government to forward its studies into the effects of agent orange on Vietnam veterans and at the same time to indicate our opinion on the amendment moved by the Opposition.

At the outset I would like to say a couple of things about my general attitude on the subject of agent orange. When this subject first claimed publicity it raised some alarming possibilities but, at that stage, the possibilities were pretty cloudy and one could not make any sort of judgment. Right from the beginning one had to recognise that if the allegations relating to the effects of agent orange on Australian veterans from Vietnam were well-founded they should properly have been taken very seriously. I know that in the past there has been some criticism of the actual conduct of the Vietnam Veterans' Action Association. As I watched rather bemused from a distance what very loosely then could be called a debate I had a growing sympathy for that Association. If its fears were well-founded one could understand its alarm. Unfortunately, rightly or wrongly, that Association clearly thought that its fears were not being paid very much attention. That thought might have been stirred by the alarm and fears that its members individually felt. Nevertheless the Association was ultimately successful in gaining the attention it wanted and in achieving movement on the issue.

I well remember a conversation I had at about that time, about 18 months ago, with a member of the United States Congress who happened to be visiting Australia at the time and who remarked on the fact that the issue of agent orange was occupying a large area of newspaper space. His comment was that he was surprised it had come so late to Australia because in the United States it had been an issue for some little time and at that stage had died down to some extent. In any event, it came to Australia. It was taken seriously and the Government moved very seriously to deal with the issues. The issue of birth deformities in children is an enormously emotive one. The issue of the potential for some sort of permanent psychological impairment of veterans is a very emotive one, and issues relating to other physical disabilities as a result of service in the name of our country are also very emotive ones. We recognise the strength of that emotion and at the same time how important it is that a country take its veterans seriously if there appears to be a well-founded fear in the minds of the veterans. I believe the Government is doing that and is approaching the problem in a very reasonable and sensible way and in a way which is designed to bring satisfaction to its veterans if their claims prove to be well-founded in fact. This leads us into many aspects of difficulties in the debate.

Recently I had the opportunity of visiting the United States of America. One of the subjects which I sought to study while I visited there was the issue of agent orange and how studies on the effect of agent orange on the United States veterans were being handled in that country. I discussed the issue with members of the Congress and the Senate who are involved in the issue and with members of the government both federal and of one State-from one of the States which is very involved in the studies. I am pleased to say that I came away with a reassurance of the assessment that the Australian authorities are trying very hard, indeed are well to the fore. We are well regarded in the United States in terms of the sort of progress we are making, the prospects of our success in the issue we have tackled and the way we have tackled it. In fact, on a couple of occasions some envy of Australia's position was expressed to me by American officials if only by virtue of the fact that we seemed to have a very much more manageable situation in terms of the number of veterans, and the information we have on the movements of our troops and on their exposure to the dioxin chemicals.

The problem in the United States is infinitely more difficult because of the numbers of people potentially involved, the sorts of records kept and, frankly, because of the sheer facts of war. It is not normal for an army when in a theatre of war to keep detailed information and to fill in forms in a highly bureaucratic fashion about just where it is dropping a drum of chemical. One might have some general ideas and perhaps in some instances very detailed records but to be specific about exactly where all that chemical went and in what quantity when waging war-not spraying a sugar cane field-is not easy. The scale on which the United States was involved in Vietnam gives that government particular difficulties. We are at an advantage because of the relatively small number of Australians involved and the small geographical involvement of Australians in Vietnam. The officials I talked to in the United States believe that Australia is making very good progress-in a couple of areas superior progress-to that which they are able to make-and that we have excellent prospects for a successful pursuit and conclusion of inquiries.

All that is relevant when the Opposition raises the issue of a judicial inquiry. I will say a few words about that. The central issue about a judicial inquiry-not a new issue; it has been raised by others-is how one can possibly move to a conclusion in a judicial inquiry. I think it is fair to accept the claim that has been made that probably to get the best result we could expect from a judical inquiry, before it could draw a factual conclusion, someone would need to have successfully pursued and concluded the sort of scientific inquiries that the Government is undertaking now. Judicial inquiries cannot of themselves discern facts that are not available to them. Scientific facts are required in this case.

I want to emphasise that I can understand the anxiety of the veterans and the very strength of feeling they must have about the issues raised for them. I do understand that, given some of the background to the issue, it is difficult for them to be patient. But I say to them that one must accept that there is evidence of good will and proper intention on the part of the Government. The programs announced in relation to investigation of the effects of agent orange are very thorough. Nobody can objectively say that any other government is trying harder or has a better prospect of success in what it has undertaken than the Australian Government in its undertakings in relation to this.

The Government has undertaken to survey the possibilities of birth defects among children of Vietnam veterans. This is probably the easiest area of inquiry. It is very difficult to forecast and to say to veterans who are yet to have children whether they should go ahead and plan to have children because objective evidence of the likelihood of birth abnormalities is not yet available. They must recognise that the evidence is not available. Certainly there are birth defects occurring among the children of Vietnam veterans. What we must attempt to determine is whether the incidence of those defects in some way is not consistent with the incidence of the same sorts of defects in the community at large. That has a very particular application to my State. I wish to say more about that later in my speech. I emphasise that the significance of this examination of birth defects is well beyond just the Vietnam veterans; it reaches into other areas of Australia and other areas of concern. I shall come to that shortly.

The Commonwealth Institute of Health in Sydney is undertaking preliminary work for a major epidemiological survey on the health of Vietnam veterans. It is exploring urgently the feasibility of carrying out a case control study. When one gets into the area of science-that is, looking for scientific evidence which is figures-which appears to support a thesis one cannot anticipate the results of the investigation. The situation must be surveyed. We must find a reasonable basis on which to proceed. Because we do not rush willy-nilly into it does not mean that our intentions are any less than the best. The Government has the best possible advice on the best way to proceed. Obviously it is taking advantage of the best possible advice and nobody is suggesting that in this area it is doing anything else. The Opposition's amendment asks before the Government receives the benefit of that advice it should act, or have some other body act, regardless. That is not a reasonable suggestion.

The question of the incidence of carcinomas is a far more difficult one. Over a period-before decisions were made in relation to what investigations would be taken on agent orange-I became more and more disquietened by the sort of private information I was being given by people either currently or formerly associated with our armed Services and their own personal opinions and conclusions in relation to their experiences or the experiences of their comrades in service in Vietnam. It has been very interesting for me to have had continuing conversations with the same army personnel, or ex-army personnel, on this subject. I was enormously moved just recently to have a conversation with one of these individuals who throughout has vigorously attacked any suggestion that agent orange was responsible for birth deformities; understandable perhaps in view of the fact that that individual fathered a child while on service in Vietnam. Recently he had the very sad experience of one of his close friends dying of cancer at a very early age. He is now sufficiently shaken by the circumstances to question what were previously, in his opinion, what were well and firmly held beliefs. The personal impact of the issue cannot be underestimated. When young men in their 30s and 40s die of cancer then of course it has a shattering impact for their families and friends.

However, I think we have to face one fact on this matter, which is that unless the surveys that we are currently undertaking quickly show some incredibly dramatic variance from the community's average incidence of malignancies, we will have to be prepared to keep on taking such surveys for a number of years. It may well be quite some years. We will have to have a commitment to the issue for a long time-10 or 15 years-before we have the reasonable evidence that one would need to have to conclude that agent orange causes cancer, as has been claimed. People in their thirties and forties do die from cancer. Indeed, children under the age of 10 die from cancer. It is not unknown at younger ages. What we must attempt to determine is whether the incidence of death from carcinoma amongst those who served in Vietnam, and who appear to have been exposed to the dioxin chemicals, is higher than the community norm in some scientifically significant way. Unless there is some extraordinary departure from the norm we have to recognise it as an issue that we will have to settle in and want on over a number of years. There may not be, with the best will in the world, quick answers with which to allay very deeply felt worries and very real fears on the part of a number of Vietnam veterans.

I hope nobody would suggest that the Government wants to do anything other than the best for veterans. Certainly, my personal view is that those who obey the command of their country to serve in a theatre of war, who risk their lives in obedience to that command, are entitled to the very best possible consideration from their country.

The whole issue of the dioxins is, of course, an enormously emotive one. As I mentioned earlier, it has a particular significance in my own State. In Queensland there has been in the north of the State for some time a controversy about the connection between dioxin herbicides and birth defects; so the outcome of these surveys will be very interesting to Queenslanders. A report produced on the subject by the Government of Queensland tends to discount the claims of increased incidence of birth deformities. The situation, if I might explain it to the Senate, is that dioxin-based herbicides are sprayed aerially in Queensland for the control of weeds and other matter encountered in the growing of sugar cane. Sprays with this chemical base have been used for some time and there have been over a period now-fuelled by the agent orange controversy-suggestions of a resultant higher incidence of birth defects in Queensland.

I want to be very careful concerning what I am about to say. I want no one to misunderstand my intent. I emphasise that I have as open a mind on the issues as it is possible to have. From the time that I heard that this chemical may be responsible for increased birth defects I have had great concern. To all who came to be expressing particular concerns I listened carefully and gave an assurance that what they had said to me was of the utmost importance. However, there is a little hypocrisy in an omission from the public debate on this issue and it ought to be faced. I do not attach the charge of hyprocrisy to those who have expressed concern about birth defects and certainly not to those who have experienced it or to their medical counsel. We should be aware that dioxin sprays, which kill plants of a particular leaf configuration, can have other effects other than killing the weeds on which they are sprayed.

In the United States I encountered another piece of information which I learned was no secret but one that no one dares mention. The issue was raised, not in relation to Australia but in relation to the United States and an area of the United States where there has been a controversy about the aerial spraying of dioxin-based herbicides and the matter of birth defects. Coincidentally, it happens to be an area which it is alleged grows a large amount of marihuana. It occurred to me when I heard that startling suggestion that the significant claims that aerial spraying of cane with dioxin based herbicides resulted in an increased rate of birth defects had come from north Queensland. It may be that there are those in central Queensland, southern Queensland and northern New South Wales who have a concern but have not expressed it. I cannot know that. However, we ought to be aware that dioxin sprays have a potential to do things other than defoliate jungles in Vietnam or kill weeds in cane fields.

In conclusion, I welcome the statements that the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner) made when he returned from the United States of America. I believe that the Government is proceeding properly in all areas. I was heartened to hear the comments that had been made, not for the purpose of just saying nice things about Australia but at a number of levels in the United States, on the real progress we had made and how they looked forward to receiving some of the results that would flow from the studies being undertaken, because they believed they would be assisted in their scientific studies by what we had done. It is recognised that Australia is ahead in some aspects of this matter. So I do not think it is fair to suggest that the Government is being slow, holding back, dragging its feet, or being unwilling in any way in this matter. One must recognise that the Government has moved fairly and well, with a reasonable expectation of reaching a satisfactory conclusion in those areas where one can hope for a short term conclusion, to which I referred earlier in my speech.

I suggest to the Opposition, whilst in no way detracting from its bona fides, its good intentions, or the effort that it has put into this debate or into consideration of the issue, that its suggested amendment is not appropriate and would not be a reasonable alternative to proceeding along the lines outlined by the Minister. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Keeffe Sen J.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I hope to keep my remarks fairly brief, but I would like to support Senator Martin's statement regarding the honesty of the Opposition's approach to this Bill. However, let me say that right from the beginning of the debate on this matter, which goes back over a considerable period, there has been a vast difference between the attitude adopted by the Opposition and that adopted by the Government. In other words, the Opposition has forthrightly and consistently supported the holding of a judicial inquiry. We believe that is the only method by which the whole matter will be brought to a somewhat more speedy and probably much more satisfactory solution.

SPEECH.PARA: The epidemiological study that has been advocated by the Government, which it has been just as consistent in pushing through, will be very lengthy. In the meantime hundreds, probably thousands, of Vietnam veterans are suffering as a result of their contact with chemical and related sprays. In World War II we saw what was probably the beginning of aerial spraying to destroy enemy crops. However, in those days we did not have sophisticated and highly dangerous sprays in the quantity that the Australian and American troops were able to practise with in Vietnam. In our case, in World War II it was mainly a matter of spraying sump oil on vegetable crops in areas occupied by the Japanese. It was sufficient to kill the foliage and it is doubtful whether it produced any adverse health effects at all. The end result was that food supplies were cut back by the destruction of the leaves on the vines.
The Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner), in the first paragraph of his second reading speech, stated:

By this Bill the Government seeks to provide for the confidentiality of personal information collected during the conduct of the epidemiological study of Vietnam veterans and when necessary other Government sponsored epidemiological studies.
The Minister went on to say:
Some of the questions being tested in the pilot study and which might also be asked in a later major survey are on personal subjects such as drug abuse and interpersonal relations.

I guess the Minister achieved headline publicity when he suggested very early in the piece that some of the problems from which the veterans were suffering probably had nothing to do with agent orange. I know that has been repeated on several occasions. The Minister can shake his head, but the evidence from the published version of what he said left no other conclusion to be drawn. The Vietnam veterans were amongst the first people to pick it up. One would hope that the Department of Veterans' Affairs, and indeed any other government department, would treat any information of a medical nature confidentially.

Any survey which might be carried out should be carried out by experts. The information should not be made available to any ordinary stickybeak who wants to look at it. The drafting of the Freedom of Information Bill-I am not talking about the bobtailed one which went from this place to another place and which will undoubtedly be back here again but about the recommendations of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs-was carried out by experts in the field who studied the matter in depth. They decided that some things ought not to be disclosed. Whilst I am not quarrelling with the right to tighten legislation to ensure that certain information does not get out, I believe it will have a tendency to highlight certain aspects of the whole problem which should not exist.

Vietnam is a special case. The Whitlam Gvernment recognised that people who served in Vietnam should receive special entitlements, including what we usually refer to as war service homes and other types of pensions and repatriation treatment. The excuse of the Government in those days was that there was not a war, but we did send many thousands of people into Vietnam on a war-like basis. Something like 1,000 lives were lost and many more people were injured. The Australians of that generation are still paying the price of our illegal involvement in Vietnam. I fail to see why the Government does not treat the problems associated with the use of agent orange and similar chemicals in a much more urgent manner. That is why the Opposition has moved an amendment to the Bill. We feel that the matter is of great importance and that what is proposed by the Government represents further stalling. By the time the final inquiries and data have been gathered and analysed it will probably be too late for many, particularly those veterans who have developed suicidal tendencies. It will fail to save the breakdown of marriages in which there has been quite heavy conflict between families, particularly between husband and wife, as a result of the suffering of veterans engaged in the Vietnam conflict.

On 20 August I asked the Minister a question regarding his failure to make contact with a congressional group of people in America during his American visit. The Minister very kindly said that when he replied to the Vietnam Veterans in Congress group he would table a copy in the Parliament. I want to set out a series of events that will form a historical record of the general trend that has occurred over the last few weeks. The Minister later wrote to Mr Daschle as a result of the question which I asked. At a later stage I will seek leave to incorporate in Hansard five or six pages of the House of Representatives Hansard. I have shown it to the Minister and he has no objections to its incorporation. The material sets out in detail a number of tables and facts which where incorporated in Hansard by my colleague in the other place, Mrs Joan Child. I return now to the reply of the Minister to Mr Daschle, who is the Chairman of the Vietnam Veterans in Congress. This committee comprises members of both the Democratic Party and the Republican Party in the American Congress. The letter stated:
Dear Mr Daschle,

Thank you for your letter of 31 July 1981, signed jointly with Mr Panetta, concerning my visit to the United States earlier this year. It was unfortunate that we were unable to consult during the visit. My time in Washington was extremely limited, and some of the meetings with Government officials and veterans' organisations had to be fitted in during visits to other cities, as I needed to include in my schedule an examination of important research projects and practical programmes being conducted outside Washington to help veterans.

In the time available during my visit to Congress offices, I was able to have discussions with members of the Veterans' Affairs Committees of both the Senate and the House of Representatives. In requesting these meetings, the Australian Embassy made it clear to the staff directors of the two Committees that I would be pleased to meet any other Committee members who were in the position to join the meetings with the Chairmen. Those who did attend the meetings were the Chairman of the Senate Committee and the Chairman and the ranking minority member of the House of Representatives Committee.
The Australian Ambassador endeavoured also to arrange for me to meet representatives of the Vietnam Veterans in Congress by inviting Mr Bonior and you to join us at an evening function on 18 June.

There is one point on which I would like there to be no misunderstanding. While the Australian Government gives no undertaking to base decisions on the opinions of any particular body, it does endeavour to consider the widest possible range of views relevant to veterans' issues in determinging its policies. In this context, I would be happy to examine any submission you care to make which you feel would be of value. The Government is glad to have available information relevant to this aspect of its policy-making, the aim of which is to contribute, within the Government's economic possibilities, to the well-being of Australian veterans.

I would now like to read a fairly short document into the Hansard record. It is a letter written by Dr Harry Pope, a general practitioner, who is the National Medical Advisor and Co-ordinator for the Vietnam Veterans Association. Dr Pope was quite frank in his statement and he distributed copies to members of the Federal Parliament. He states:
Dear Sirs,

It is with dismay that the Vietnam Veterans' Association (VVA) notes that Senator Messner and his advisors have shown how misinformed they are in the scientific area of the 'Agent Orange' issue. This can be our only conclusion as any other would imply that the Senator was misleading parliament.
I think I said that about the Minister when dealing with some aspects of the matter in a previous debate. The letter continues:
In Senator Messner's letter to members of parliament, dated 21st September, 1981, he alleges certain points which are inaccurate.

Firstly, the VVA has not 'ignored a large body of literature'. Indeed the Senator's reference, the 1977 IARC report is a briefing article that the Association gives as a reference for interested medical and scientific personnel. It aptly surmises the then current literature and concluded that there was not sufficient information to evaluate these controversial chemicals. This is not an article which 'does not suit' our argument.

Secondly, the issue is not which veterans were exposed or whether exposure was sufficient to place the veterans at risk. The issue is whether the significant problems of Vietnam Veterans are related to chemical exposure.

Exposure in Vietnam cannot be quantified at this late date. Records are too incomplete, and to imply that the veterans merely walked 'through an area which might have been chemically defoliated days or months before' belies the fact that the veterans were showered by a mist of chemicals and that they breathed, ate and drank the chemicals from contaminated local foods and water.
I will come back to that paragraph when I have completed reading the next two paragraphs of the letter. The letter goes on to say:

Thirdly, one fortieth of the total number of veterans are claiming disabilities, but this does not mean that they are the only ones with problems. Many are suffering, distrustful of government institutionalism and prefer to go it alone.

Finally, the Department of Veterans' Affairs has not readily sought, to try to resolve the question as soon as possible. In fact the VVA is powerless to motivate the DVA. Media pressure was and is the only motivating factor of the DVA in the 'Agent Orange, chemical warfare and poisons' issue.
I will refer to the third last and second last paragraphs of that letter. Dr Pope states:
Exposure in Vietnam cannot be quantified at this late date. Records are too incomplete, . . .

This seems to be a general pattern that is showing up in a great many ways in complaints veterans have made to me and to other persons. When the veterans first complained about suffering some disabilities very few people took any notice of them. In many instances doctors put it down to heat rashes or something else when the veterans showed skin diseases. It was only when these things kept reappearing that the more consistent people wanted to look at the whole matter in depth, whether those people were qualified doctors or other concerned persons.

The Senate will recall the case I mentioned earlier this year regarding a veteran named Graham Scarce who had repeated outbreaks of rashes, whose children were not well and who had other disabilities as well, all of which could be attributed to some unseen agent and possibly the chemical known as agent orange. The reference made by Dr Pope to some of the veterans' problems being dismissed on the basis that they had walked into a mist of chemicals is, in fact, quite true. Scarce related to me on several occasions how, when he was operating in the field, he and his comrades in his unit were in fact sprayed on many occasions. If that is not sufficient evidence-this evidence has been and will be repeated again-obviously the Government is not really fair dinkum about trying to solve the situation. In the second last paragraph Dr Pope states:

. . . one-fortieth of the total number of veterans are claiming disabilities, but this does not mean that they are the only ones with problems. Many are suffering, distrustful of government institutionalism and prefer to go it alone.

A veteran living in my region refuses to register for medical treatment. His wife has endeavoured to persuade him that he needs medical treatment. Others have endeavoured to persuade him that he ought at least to have a medical examination, but he is totally distrustful of what the Government or anyone associated with the Government is likely to do. Perhaps, more correctly, he is distrustful of what they will not do after cross-examining him. That is one example I know of and it is a clear-cut case. As Dr Pope says, there are probably many others who are in similar situations.

To complete the historical record I will refer to the statements made by my colleague in another place, Mrs Joan Child. Among the documents to which she referred is a section of a Press release issued recently from the Vietnam Veterans' Action Association. She referred to a table setting out the disabilities being suffered by some 30 veterans and their families. The next document she referred to is an article published in the Canberra Times on 11 January 1980 explaining the problems of a Vietnam veteran and his two-year-old son. Also, on 26 January 1980 the Sydney Morning Herald carried an editorial about a Mr Bob Gibson of Sydney. Mrs Child is recorded in Hansard as saying:
It is most unusual for a major newspaper to editorialise in this way about one individual who is not a public figure.

She referred also to correspondence which took place between Mrs Voltz and the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser), as well as two short letters from the permanent head of the Department and a statement about this Victorian lady whose husband committed suicide as a result of his suffering. I seek leave to have those documents incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The documents read as follows-
All Vietnam veterans are extremely disappointed that neither Mr Hodgman nor Mr Goodluck honoured their written undertakings to support a judicial inquiry into our claims.
There undertakings were given in October, 1980, prior to the last election.
On the first parliamentary opportunity to honour their commitment-debate on the Epidemiological Studies Bill in the House of Representatives yesterday-they voted against a judicial inquiry.
How they are suffering

''You go there and do your bit for your country and this is what you get for it. It's not good enough''.
Vietnam veteran Michael Woods, of Kambah, put down the plastic tube through which he has had to feed himself for the past six months and sat by his two-year-old son Mark, who has a hole in his heart.
He spent two years on active service in Vietnam, and it was during this time that he first complained of acute pains in his chest while and after eating.
''When I came back, other symptoms developed and, after tests, the doctors diagnosed an ulcer in my oesophagus'' he said.
In 1971, after two operations, Mr Woods made a claim for compensation, but he has not received any, for this claim or for the others he has made since.
He has not been able to work since the middle of last year and will soon have to have another major operation or remain on a liquid diet for the rest of his life.
He said he had come into contact with Agent Orange in Vietnam, and blames it for his conditions and his son's.
Mark, like his father, has had to have surgery.
Neither Mr Wood's family nor his wife's has any history of such coronary disorders.
In a year's time ''when he is strong enough'' Mark will have to undergo open-heart surgery to try to rectify his condition.
Meanwhile, his father is going to keep making claims on the Government.

Bob Gibson was a fit, healthy young man when he went to Vietnam in 1967. Mr Gibson was conscripted but he went into the army without complaint. For a country boy from Warren in western NSW, the army sounded like an adventure. That adventure cost Mr Gibson dearly. At 33, he is no longer healthy. Like some other veterans, he is plagued with rashes, insomnia and hypertension. Mr Gibson sprayed defoliants for the Australian army. He lived and worked beneath the American planes which dropped the 'withering rain'-Agent Orange-on the jungle.

Two months ago, he had never heard the name Agent Orange. Like the others, he believed his illnesses were his own, individual problem. When he heard that other veterans had similar symptoms, he joined their campaign for an inquiry into the effect of Agent Orange. Mr Gibson is concerned for his job but he believes he has an obligation to tell his story and to look for evidence from other men whose families have been affected.

Mr Gibson and his wife have given up the idea of having children, now that the link between Agent Orange and birth defects has been postulated. He feels he has been shunted around by the Government and he has been through two unsuccessful appeals for an entitlement for nervous disorders. It was left for the veterans themselves to draw the link between their cases and the similar cases of veterans in the United States.

Now, an investigation has been announced. Research will be undertaken. These are welcome moves. The research should establish whether men such as Bob Gibson are entitled to compensation. If they are they should receive it, promptly and ungrudgingly. If there is any doubt, they should be given the benefit of it.
Flat 1/1447 Dandenong Rd Oakleigh 3166 Victoria 24.7.80 To the Prime Minister,
Mr Fraser,
Dear Sir,
I am writing to you, out of sheer exasperation; hoping that you may be able to help.
My ex-husband, REX VOLTZ; (a New Zealander) was conscripted into the Australian Army, and sent to Vietnam late '68. Discharged at Watsonnia Barracks '70. He came back, a changed man.
My belief, has always been; that the Heidleberg Repatriation Hospital, is for Returned Service-Men.
My problem, (or Rex's!) is that I cannot gain admission for Rex; to the Repat. Hospital. I find it incredible!

This is the first application, that he's ever made; and although it is acknowledged that he has a psychiatric problem amongst others; he is continually turned away; whilst Veterans Affairs decide whether to approve, or not to approve; that his problems are War-related.

Rex; served in the Nui Dat base camp area; and of course, we are now aware, of the Agent Orange chemical damage. On this point and of this moment, that is not foremost in our minds; although it does answer, for numerous events, that have taken place in Rex's life; (?) since his return from Vietnam.
The upper most relevant decision at this time, is that Rex needs help; and is being continually turned away.

He spent 5 weeks in Larundel, (State Mental Health) of which provided fruitless. They admitted that they, 'could do nothing for him; and had achieved nothing'. So he was discharged from there. To where?!! There is nowhere left, for Rex to go; the doors continually close one after the other.

I am fully aware, of the Political issues involved; but surely that should not even come into account, when the man concerned is a Veteran; one whom was sent overseas to defend Australia. Then; when he breaks down, obviously suffering psychologically, from his service in Vietnam; he is not looked after by, the same Government, which sent him to War. An unreal and astonishing parallel; wouldn't you agree?!!

Our marriage and home life; has been shattered. We are now divorced, as quite frankly; I could not take any more of the violence, rages, suicides, (or attempts at!) and the underlying tension. The children, we have 3; were too young to understand, thank goodness; and now, all they know is that their Dad is sick. Could you, yourself; cope with a situation, that so many of the Vietnam Veterans wives, and families; are faced with. I think not Mr Fraser; or else, you would have helped out the Veterans.
The only people; that can fully understand the Veterans (Vietnam) plight, are the Vietnam Veterans themselves!!

For this reason; those bunch of good hearted guys, formed Vietnam Veterans Action Association! Without any funding whatsoever! Even if you decide not to help Rex, Mr Fraser; how about Government funding, for the Vietnam Veterans Action Association? The same guys, that were sent overseas, to fight for Australia; the same country that in the Veterans time of need, does not want to help the Veterans themelves.

I've endeavoured to gain admission for Rex to Repat. for months; it seems like years! He; as many of the other Vietnam Veterans are; is going through a private Hell, and there is no help; through all of the Red tape involved.

I've tried, with the help of the VVAA; approaches to many, and supposedly influential 'top' people; all to no avail. My last plea of perhaps hope; is to you, Mr Fraser. Please can you help at all?!! You see Mr Fraser, I stand to gain nothing from this; I only wholeheartedly believe; that as Veterans, all of these guys deserve the best. It's not only on a Personal level; they (VVAA!) have helped Rex, in his time of need. So why; shouldn't you re-examine their need, for funding? To provide the best; for their fellow Veterans!
If, you have read this letter; and considered all aspects regarding Rex, himself; and funding for his fellow Veterans; then I thank you.
And if, you decide to act positively; regards the above mentioned funding, and for Rex; then I am indebted to you.
You'll find that quite a few people know of REX VOLTZ's name, and situation; because as I said before, I have tried all other avenues!! Being:
Mr Adermann-Minister for Veterans Affairs.
Dr Keith Fleming-Sir Richard Kingsley-Holt McMinn talked to these 2 men.
Senator Dame Mary Guilfoyle-Social Security.
Mr Pace Mathews, M.P.-Member for Oakleigh.
Mr Bernie McPhee-Deputy Commissioner Veterans Affairs.
Drs Rose & Gidley-Medical Supt & Chief of Psychiatry at Repat.
Dr Barlow-Medical Supt of Larundel, respectively.
So as you can see, 7 to 2; the odds are against Rex.
Why? Mr Fraser, why; is it all so damn hard?! As you've said before, quote: 'Life, wasn't meant to be easy!' But; is it supposed to be so hard?!
There are people's whole lives involved here; the suicide ratio is terrifically high; as the Viet. Veterans, just cannot get help! It takes so long, for the 'System,' to see the light!

No-one; is prepared to take Rex in, as a boarder, nor keep him in Larundel; until the Repat. & Veterans Affairs decide just what, they will do! So I had to let Rex stay here; what or where else can he go?

But believe you; it is having it's effect on myself, and the children. When will someone see; that your 'System', is off-loading it's problems onto the Community, or relatives in general?! It is as totally unfair to us, and the Veterans; as they cannot help their reactions.
My ex-husband, knows his limitations; and has appealed for help, continuously; never receiving it psychiatrically.
Mr Fraser; sure, your can dismiss my letter and appeal; but sooner or later, as the suicide rate rises; you'll have to answer to someone. If not here, then to God.

I am a christian; and was brought up to respect authority, and people in status generally. But; after having ground myself down, to earth level; trying to achieve Peace, and help for Rex; I too, will now re-think my living code.

Rex; is not even the same man, that I loved and married. I may see the 'old Rex', in flashes; but since his return from Vietnam, there is a 'new Rex'. Rex; as he is now, is totally confused and lost. He can not relate to your Society; and neither can your Society, relate to him.

Yet; for the man he once was; I fight on, Mr Fraser. And for all the other, Vietnam Veterans; especially the ones that could no longer take the pressure, and therefore suicided. I hope and pray, that Rex and his fellow mates; can hang on, until a humanitarian decision is made for them, in their favour.
Yours Sincerely, Paula I Voltz.
Prime Minister, Canberra, 13 October 1980 Dear Mrs Voltz.
Thank you for your letter of 24 July 1980 concerning your ex-husband's situation. I apologise for the delay in replying to you.

The Government is aware of, and sympathetic to, the problems faced by Vietnam veterans who believe they and their children are suffering from exposure to herbicides and other chemicals used in Vietnam.

The Minister for Veterans' Affairs announced in Parliament on 31 March 1980 a major epidemiological study, to be carried out by the Commonwealth Institute of Health, into the effects of herbicides and other chemicals on Vietnam veterans. The Government believes that the epidemiological study is the only way to resolve the uncertainties about whether exposure to herbicides and other chemicals used in Vietnam has affected the health of Australian veterans and their children.

I am advised that the decision not to admit your ex-husband to the Repatriation General Hospital, Heidelberg, was based on the advice of medical officers who believed he would not benefit from admission to Heidelberg.

The request from the Vietnam Veterans' Action Association for a grant-in-aid to establish a welfare program for Vietnam Veterans was carefully considered. In deciding not to accede to the request, the Government recognized that existing health and welfare programs adequately covered the needs of veterans.
Thank you for writing to me on this matter.
Yours sincerely, (Malcolm Fraser) Mrs P. Voltz,
Flat 1/447 Dandenong Road,
Oakleigh, Vic 3166
21 October 1980 Dear Mrs Voltz,
Mr Robert Coleman of the Melbourne Herald spoke to me last week about your husband's claim for compensation and suggested I should ring you.
I tried to telephone you on Friday and failed, and tried again yesterday, Monday, and today, with no success yet.
And on Monday and Tuesday I tried to contact you through the Vietnam Veterans Association of Australian office in Melbourne.

If you would like to have a word with me about your husband's case I should be pleased to hear from you. You might like to telephone me to suit your convenience on 89 6736 in Canberra, reverse charge, if I don't manage to contact you before this letter arrives.
I am sending a copy of this note to Mr Coleman.
With king regards, Yours sincerely, (R. Kingsland) Secretary 31 December 1980 Mrs Paula Voltz,
Flat 1,
1447 Dandenong Road,
Oakleigh, Vic. 3166
Dear Mrs Voltz,
I was very sorry indeed to learn of Mr Voltz's death.

Having spoken to you on those occasions when you tried to get some help for him you must take some comfort in the fact that you did all that you could to lead him towards the psychiatric treatment which we were offering at Heidelberg and which may have helped his unhappy condition.
I hope time will soften your grief.
Yours sincerely, (R. Kingsland) Mrs Paula Voltz,
Flat 1,
1447 Dandenong Road,
Oakleigh, Vic. 3166
1-1-81 To the Prime Minister,
Mr Fraser,
Dear Sir,
I wrote to you, quote; ''out of sheer exasperation,'' on the 24th July 1980; to try to obtain help for my ex-husband (Vietnam Veteran), Rex Edward VOLTZ.
You answered my letter; and I received it, on the 14th October 1980; 2 1/2 months later!

My ex-husband, Rex Edward Voltz; is now DEAD! He hung himself from a tree. Because of your total apathy, another Vietnam Veteran is now dead. How many more, do you want Mr Fraser; before, you realize just what these Veterans went through, and are still suffering from?

You speak of, ''existing health and welfare programs;'' ''in your decision not, to accede to my request for a grant-in-aid.'' There are NO health and welfare programs. And unless the Vietnam Veterans Association of Australia, receive a grant-in-aid soon; you will have more deaths to answer for.

I find this all unbelievable! I appealed for help everywhere; and finally, to you Mr Fraser; but Rex never received it, and now he is DEAD! 32 years old; and yet so tormented, by Vietnam Service for Australia; he killed himself! How much more, do you want?!

What's even more a disgrace; is that Australia couldn't even bury him! I've been told, that from Veterans Affairs, if I'm lucky; we may receive $300! Big deal! The funeral costs; and by no means, as expensive as yours would be when the time comes; amount to $1053!
The Government conscripted these guys, to fight for Australia in Vietnam; and then the families and or relatives have to bury them! It really is a shameful disgrace; and I'm not proud of Australia.
Do you know Mr Fraser; that in New Zealand (Rex's birthplace), the Government bury their returned servicemen. Why, is Australian so mean?

I've gone over and over; the things I did to try and help Rex, Mr Fraser. And although I did my hardest; it can not have been good enough, or else he would be alive. I can't sleep; as I see Rex hanging from a tree, whenever I close my eyes. Our children are broken hearted.
Surely Mr Fraser; that it has been proven to you, first hand; you must be able to see and acknowledge, the Vietnam Veterans Association's need for a grant. They need help!

Please; do not let any more Veterans feel as though they have nothing left for them, and they then therefore Suicide. These Men defended you! I loved Rex; and now I have nothing. For God's sake, make his death at least worthwhile; and let no more follow him! There have been too many, already.
Christmas and New Year, will hold very little for us ever again. Our children and I, are crushed.
The Vietnam Veterans helped me, to make arrangements. Mr Fraser please help them.
My beloved Rex is gone; and I still cannot believe nor accept it. I also now, have nothing to live for; we ask for nothing of you, other than to help his fellow Veterans.
Yours sincerely, Mrs Paula Voltz, Flat 1/1447 Dandenong Road,
Oakleigh 3166
Victoria
'WAR SPRAY DROVE MAN TO SUICIDE'
A woman claims her husband, a Vietnam veteran, was driven to suicide after being exposed to defoliants during the war.
The woman said her husband died on Boxing Day after suffering severe bouts of depression and savage violent outbursts since returning from Vietnam.
Melbourne police found Rex Edward Voltz, 32, hanging from a tree in a park on Boxing Day.
His wife Paula said last night: 'Before leaving for Vietnam, Rex was a quiet gentle guy-but after he got back the attacks started.'
Mrs Voltz said many of her husband's attacks were directed at her.
She said that before their divorce in 1978, her husband told her of an experience at his camp in Nui Dat when a spray was used to kill mosquitoes.
Her husband said: 'There was a blue smoke haze. There was a horrible taste in my mouth and at the back of my throat-it was green and slimy.'
'I felt nauseous dizzy and wheezy. There was no getting away from the spray.'

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. I conclude by referring to something that was touched on by Senator Martin, and that is the use of 2,4,5-T and similar chemicals for the destruction of weed patches in many local government areas and for the destruction of weeds in crops, including sugar cane. Dioxin, which is used in Australia in much lesser quantities than it was ever used in Vietnam, is sprayed particularly in the sugar cane areas. Of course, dioxin is a constituent chemical of the herbicide. There have been instances where crop dusting has been carried out. I understand that before a plane goes out to spray chemicals or any obnoxious type of spray, whether it be in powder or liquid form, it is supposed to get permission from the Department of Primary Industry. There is supposed to be a check made of which way the wind is blowing and planes are supposed to keep a certain distance away from occupied areas or farm houses.

SPEECH.PARA: As happens in cane growing areas in tropical Queensland many of the assignments are on farms which run right up to the edges of small country towns and provincial cities such as Cairns, Mackay, Innisfail, Tully and a whole host of small villages north and south of those areas. I suppose winds do change sometimes. Unfortunately, we know of instances when the crop spraying planes have gone out, apparently without the knowledge or consent of the relevant authorities, and chemicals have been dropped over occupied areas. This has led to a whole flood of complaints about problems for children. I know there appears to be some inconclusive evidence about how much effect this really has. But the circumstantial evidence is certainly very substantial, so much so that quite a large number of local authority organisations in Australia now forbid the use of these herbicides.

Even though we are not happy about this survey I hope that when it has been carried out no stones will be left unturned in the endeavour to collect the information. I respectfully suggest to the Government that such an investigation should not be allowed to drag on over a period of many years. If any even mildly conclusive evidence is turned up in the first few months that ought to be sufficient to make the Government act. In the meantime, the ex-service organisations, particularly the Legion of Ex-servicemen and Women, have suggested that, pending any finality of any such investigation, veterans ought to be given the benefit of the doubt. The amount of money involved would not be great and would not break this Government. We could afford to pay compensation when we decided to abandon the Moscow Olympics. Compensation, as the relevant Minister said yesterday, is already in the vicinity of $7m. If we can afford to put on all the frills at the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting, overreact in relation to security and pay compensation in a couple of other areas for disabilities suffered by people one would think that, if we add to these things the numerous overseas trips of the Prime Minister, we could afford to pay compensation for the veterans who are unable to work. Some compensation ought to be paid to them until finality is reached in this investigation.

In the meantime, my party shall continue to press for a full judicial inquiry with wide terms of reference. We believe that is the type of inquiry that would help to clean up quickly the so-called grey areas in the claims made by these veterans. When the conclusions are reached I think it will be the Vietnam veterans who will be proved to be correct. This Government will be proved again to have been stalling for time. It is a bit like the Government's sales tax Bills: They are here today and gone tomorrow but they will be back next week. The Government will continue with the ad hoc types of policies which it applies not only to the financial and economic sections of the Parliament of Australia but also to veterans who ought to be given the benefit of the doubt. Everything ought to be done for them in the shortest possible time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish firstly to make a few general remarks on this matter and then to come to a few of the points that have been made by the various speakers in the debate. I draw the attention of the Senate to the fact that the Epidemiological Studies (Confidentiality) Bill relates to the provision of certain material that is provided in the course of epidemiological studies undertaken by the Commonwealth. I point out that it does not restrict itself specifically, although it is mentioned in the Bill, to the study which is currently being undertaken by the Commonwealth Institute of Health in respect of Vietnam veterans. The Bill encompasses a mechanism which provides that information given in the course of various studies will be kept confidential. We ought to consider the broad principle of that even though that, in itself, might apply to Vietnam veterans and various other health matters relating to that area.

SPEECH.PARA: The point I am trying to make is that this study, which has been the feature of so much discussion and debate today, may in itself not specifically be the only study which is ever made in respect of Vietnam veterans. As honourable senators would know, I have announced in recent weeks the undertaking of another study by the Commonwealth Institute of Health in respect of birth defects. It is hoped that that particular study will touch on perhaps the most emotional area of concern in this whole debate and give us answers somewhat more quickly than we might otherwise have expected from the major epidemiological study which is now in the course of preparation. I mention that because it was clear to me that one or two Opposition speakers had not appreciated the extent of the Government's approach in this area and had not realised-I think Senator Giles was one and perhaps Senator Keeffe was another, although he may know of the existence of that inquiry-that the Government has a multi-pronged approach to this question and is not relying wholly and solely on the one major study which is the major concern of this Bill. It is important to recognise that.

TALK.START.PARA: —But should not those two studies be conducted together?

—They are. They are going forward concurrently at this time. That is the way in which we hope to get answers somewhat more quickly from the birth defects study. I now address my remarks to one or two points made by Senator Keeffe. He has done it before and I suppose he will continue to make the point that I have somehow always denied that there is any connection between disabilities and herbicide exposure. I have told him ad nauseam that that is not so, that I have never stated that and that in fact I have been misrepresented by the Press in regard to that matter on many occasions. I have made that clear from time to time. Nor have I attributed other reasons as the sole causes of the disabilities of Vietnam veterans, even though the Press has sought on some occasions to attribute other reasons. The honourable senator has placed his own interpretation upon some particular remarks I have made from time to time and I can only leave it to him to continue to make those points. But I wish to put it on the public record that in no way have I made the kinds of remarks which Senator Keeffe has attributed to me.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Keeffe also mentioned a letter which came into his hands, addressed to me, from a Mr Daschle who represents an organisation known as Vietnam Veterans in Congress in the United States. I do not have a copy of that letter with me but from memory it claimed I had been discourteous in not seeking to contact Mr Daschle and his organisation while I was in the United States. In fact, the happenings were such that I had very limited time. Through my officers in the Department of Veterans' Affairs and the officers in the Embassy in Washington we had some contact with that organisation and invited it to send representatives to an evening function. I think I referred to that in my reply. I did hope to be able to contact that organisation on that occasion but unfortunately no representatives attended. I do not believe, given the exigencies of the particular timing and of being in Washington at that time, that much can be made of that complaint. However I would be anxious to hear from that organisation by way of submission as to the various issues to which it would like to address itself.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will send it a copy of your speech.

—I am perfectly happy for the honourable senator to do that since what I have said has already been incorporated in the letter which went to the organisation some six or eight weeks ago. I have not yet received a submission from it, to the best of my knowledge. With regard to one or two other matters that were mentioned, I noted that Senator Keeffe referred to a letter sent by Dr Harry Pope to members of parliament in the last few days. Without wishing to labour this matter, I just draw the Senate's attention to the fact that whilst Dr Pope does talk of the toxicity of various chemicals-no one disagrees with that, least of all myself; certainly I have not disagreed with it in the letter I have circulated to members-unless a connection can be established between the level of exposure of Australian soldiers in Vietnam to the chemical which was sprayed, or with which they might have come into contact in Vietnam, it is extremely difficult to assess the actual effects, in the way that Senator Keeffe seems to think is automatic, from a scientific standpoint.

SPEECH.PARA: I would not like honourable senators to think, as it is from time to time represented in the Press, that Vietnam veterans are somehow totally ignored by the Department of Veterans' Affairs. Of a total number of approximately 41,000 troops who had service in Vietnam, roughly 7,000 receive treatment and/or pension benefits or payments of some kind or another from the Department of Veterans' Affairs. It is important to recognise that soldiers from Vietnam are receiving the same kinds of benefits, the same kinds of treatment and care, that have been available to a very satisfactory degree over many years to the veterans of other wars.
