I refer now to one or two other matters mentioned particularly by Senator Giles. She referred to the fact that there had been no consultation with the Vietnam Veterans' Association of Australia in respect of the preparation of the questionnaire circulated amongst Vietnam veterans for the pilot study for the epidemiological study. I should point out that it was the request of the Vietnam Veterans' Association and other organisations that the highest degree of confidentiality in the preparation and collection of data from that questionnaire should be maintained by the Institute of Health in formulating its answers to the inquiry. They did request that a Bill of the kind that has now been presented, and which we hope will be passed into law shortly, be prepared. I think that is a very important factor. Certainly it is a key factor in the ultimate success of any epidemiological study in this area.

Without going into any more detail in relation to the many points Senator Giles made, perhaps the one other area that bears mentioning is her reference to the Atlanta birth defects study. During my trip to the United States in June I visited the Centre for Disease Control in Atlanta to determine the state of progress with relation to the birth defects study in that area. It was a most interesting visit and we were able to establish that it would be some considerable time before the Atlanta organisation could produce meaningful results. In that respect it was disappointing because we were not able to get a clear answer as to whether there could be established quickly any linkage between birth defects and defoliant exposure.

I come to the major point, the amendment moved by Senator Grimes on behalf of the Opposition to the motion for the second reading of this Bill. It requires that the Senate states an opinion that the Vietnam veterans study referred to in the Bill should be supported by a wide judicial inquiry. The Government's position on this has been consistently made plain. Indeed, Senator Martin in her speech made both her position and that of the Government very clear in that regard. We do not see that a judicial inquiry could come down with any other opinion than that there ought to be some kind of major scientific study to establish the linkages between veterans' disabilities and their exposure to chemicals. Therefore, it seems to us that the quickest and most effective route to establishing the rights and wrongs of this situation is via the gathering, sifting and assessment of scientific information in such a way as to establish conclusively one way or another whether there are these linkages as claimed. It is for that reason that the Government opposes the establishment of a judicial inquiry. Notwithstanding the fact that the Senate Standing Committee on Science and the Environment will be looking at these matters very closely, and has very considerable powers to examine those questions and may well produce its own results--

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate Standing Committee inquiry is not exactly with the Government's blessing.
—We are supporting it.
—Yes, you did not have much option. You did not have the numbers.

—That is quite irrelevant since it was passed through the Government parties room with the full support of the parties and has been brought forward by Senator Jessop, as Chairman of the Committee, and proposed and accepted in the Senate today. I have no other remarks to make in that respect. Finally, it is our view that a judicial inquiry would not produce the results which the Vietnam Veterans' Association of Australia and other supporters of that organisation, and the Opposition are seeking. In fact, the route the Government is following, that is, a solid scientific inquiry, we believe will finally produce the goods in this matter. For that reason the Government opposes the amendment. I wish the Bill a speedy passage.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the words proposed to be added (Senator Grimes's amendment) be added.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Original question, as amended, resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

DEBATE.TITLE: MEAT EXPORT (PENALTIES) BILL 1981AUSTRALIAN MEAT AND LIVE-STOCK CORPORATION AMENDMENT BILL 1981COMMERCE (TRADE DESCRIPTIONS) AMENDMENT BILL 1981CUSTOMS (UNLAWFUL EXPORTATION OF FOOD) AMENDMENT BILL 1981

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 17 September, on motion by Senator Chaney:
That the Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —These four Bills seek to increase where possible penalties under various Acts for mislabelling export meat. Of course, the legislation has been prompted by the recent meat export scandal. It could be said that it is a bit late in the day for the Government to be acting in this area because almost two years ago W. Pope and Co., a firm in Western Australia, was convicted of an offence very similar to those with which other firms have since been charged. The offence by Pope was to mislabel as beef meat which was in fact mutton. Other firms have since mislabelled horse and kangaroo flesh as beef in export cartons.

SPEECH.PARA: The situation which was exposed in recent months is, among other things, a function of the years of dithering in official circles, in particular by the National Country Party Ministers who have been responsible, over the establishment of a single efficient meat inspection service. One of the many ironies raised by these Bills and the Government's attempt belatedly to increase penalties for offences of this nature is that some of the offending firms have been simultaneously receiving Government funds in the form of export incentives. This prompted Senator Primmer to ask in Senate Estimates Committee last Monday whether there was any mechanism under which the Government could recover money paid to these offending firms in the form of export incentives. The Chairman of the Export Development Grants Board, Mr Daly, gave a characteristically windy and irrelevant reply in which he concluded:
I think the time has so passed on that in October 1981 we have moved a long way beyond 30 June 1979, and so the question may have more than a little of a hypothetical element in it.
Fortunately, Senator Primmer was not satisfied with that evasive reply and put the question again in this form:
Is some form of false pretences in the export of certain goods feasible? If so, is there any provision under the Act to retrieve funds so granted?

Mr Daly replied that under section 40 of the Export Market Development Grants Act and section 19 of the Export Expansion Grants Act 'specific provisions are available where a grant has been made in good faith but on the basis of subsequently shown false information moneys can be recouped'. Certainly the customers have been provided with false information by offending firms. I also expect that the firms have made declarations to the Department of Primary Industry that they have exported beef whereas they have exported a mixture of beef and/or kangaroo and horse or perhaps donkey. I hope that action is initiated by the Attorney-General (Senator Durack), if the Export Development Grants Board is too inert to do so, at least to recover those public moneys which these firms have received while simultaneously misleading our export customers.

I followed Senator Primmer with a question relating to Statutory Rule No. 127 which was gazetted on 30 May 1980. I asked what additional financial obligations were incurred by the Commonwealth because of gazettal of Statutory Rule No. 127. I received an evasive and irrelevant answer along the lines of the answer supplied earlier to a question asked in the Senate by Senator McLaren. After several more attempts to establish whether the Commonwealth's liability was increased due to Statutory Rule No. 127 had been foiled by Mr Daly I asked a question which concluded:
. . . was it not possible under the legislation in the form it was in then--
That is originally-
to calculate the entitlement of meat exporters?

Mr Daly, having previously asserted that there was no additional financial obligation thrust upon the Commonwealth as a result of Statutory Rule No. 127 because there was no obligation additional to that which was intended at the time the legislation was passed, then implied it was not possible to calculate it anyway. In answer to my question whether it was possible to calculate entitlement as the Act was originally worded, Mr Daly said:
Yes. It was obviously possible to calculate the entitlement of meat exporters who were not engaged in the trade which involved quota meat with the United States and Canada.
That was an ambivalent answer which forced me to follow up with the question:
Is Mr Daly saying that it was not possible to calculate the entitlements of exporters who were engaged in trade with Canada and the United States under the Act as it originally stood?
That specific question produced another rambling, irrelevant and misleading reply, the first phrase of which I will quote, which had nothing to do with the question. Mr Daly said:
The Export Development Grants Board is charged with the administration of the legislation--
And so on. I was forced to put the question again. After a couple more futile endeavours to extract the truth from Mr Daly, I said:
I will assert that it was possible to calculate entitlements under the original Act.
I asked Mr Daly either to confirm or deny that. Finally, he said:
I accept that it was possible to make a calculation of a grant entitlement which, if it had been strictly on the wording of section 4 (2)--

That was a reference to the original Act. Having established finally and with great difficulty that entitlements of individual exporters could be calculated before Statutory Rule No. 127 was gazetted, and whether Statutory Rule No. 127 was ever gazetted or not, I asked whether, having established that it was possible to calculate this figure as a result of Statutory Rule No. 127 having been gazetted, the Commonwealth had incurred an additional financial liability to exporters of the order of $20m. After another rather evasive answer and the rephrasing of the question, Mr Daly said that no, that could not be done. He said:
. . . because at no stage did it seek to do other than what it understood the Government's intention to be. It--
'It' being the Export Development Grants Board-
Never sought to make any calculations as to what might have been the determinations without or with Statutory Rule No. 127.
I repeat. Mr Daly said:
It--
that is the Board-
Never sought to make any calculation as to what might have been the determinations without or with Statutory Rule No. 127.
That conflicts with a statement made a few minutes prior to that by Mr Daly who stated:
In the adjustments which have been made by the Board in these redeterminations--
I stress 'in these redeterminations'-

There have been pluses and minuses to claimants but usually of fairly small amounts. The suggestion that the end result of bringing in Statutory Rule No. 127 would be to give a further entitlement of $20m has no basis in fact.

I ask the Senate to contrast Mr Daly's claim that at no stage did the Board seek to calculate what the entitlements would have been without Statutory Rule No. 127 with his earlier statement which reads:
In the adjustments which have been made by the Board in these redeterminations there have been pluses and minuses--

Either he was very careless in the way he expressed himself or he was misleading the Committee. His references to redeterminations cannot mean anything other than that the Board had calculated entitlements for at least some exporters before the gazettal of Statutory Rule No. 127 and that as a result of Statutory Rule No. 127 those entitlements were recalculated afterwards.

I then asked whether, with regard to the 53 firms which, according to Mr Daly's information, had had their entitlements finally assessed, there was any difference between the original entitlement under the Act and the ultimate entitlement following the gazettal of Statutory Rule No. 127. I asked:
Could the Committee have a list of those 53 firms with their entitlements as finally assessed and their entitlements as they would have been if the Act had been applied as it was originally written?

Audible to those nearby but not audible to Hansard, and therefore not recorded, was Mr Daly's advice to the presiding Minister, which was: 'I strongly recommended not providing that information'. The reason for not providing that information, which a close scrutiny of Mr Daly's evidence reveals could technically be provided and indeed much of which ought still to be lying around in the Export Development Grants Board, is that as a result of Statutory Rule No. 127 having been gazetted a $20m gratuitous restrospective handout was made to meat exporters. It was gratuitous and retrospective because the rule itself was gazetted 11 months after meat, or at least beef, mutton and lamb, had ceased to be eligible at all for export grants.

If, as I expect, the request that I made to have the before and after entitlements of those 53 firms provided to the Committee or to the Senate is not met, the only remaining conclusion is that the Government does not want those names to be publicly revealed. Mr Daly, on several occasions, denied that there was a $20m additional entitlement. He did so firstly in an evasive and obfuscatory way and, secondly, in a more direct way. He also claimed that no assessment had been made. The figure of $20m was supplied to me some two years ago from within his department, apparently by one of the rare creatures in that department, someone willing to disclose the truth. It should also be noted that Statutory Rule No. 127 was written in language which was incomprehensible and that no statement of the extra financial obligations it entailed or even of the intention of that rule was made by the Minister at the time.

Mr Daly's evidence before the Committee maintained the standard of Statutory Rule No. 127 and the language in which it was written. As I said earlier, he was obfuscatory and evasive. I have no doubt that he intended to withhold the truth from the Committee, and to some extent he succeeded. Equally, I have no doubt that requests for information to be supplied regarding the difference to the entitlements of those 53 firms whose claims have been finalised before and after Statutory Rule No. 127 will not be officially supplied. the excuse will be that it cannot be determined, which leads me to emphasise again Mr Daly's reference at page 665 of the Hansard of Estimates Committee H of 12 October:
In the adjustments which have been made by the Board in these redeterminations there have been pluses and minuses-

Mr Daly is, of course, a graduate of a department which has been maladministered for decades by National Country Party Ministers. He was not made chairman of the Export Development Grants Board to provide information to taxpayers about how their money is gratuitously handed out to favoured clients of that party. Lest it be thought that I have consciously or otherwise distorted the evasive and misleading nature of Mr Daly's replies, I seek leave to incorporate into Hansard pages 664-668 inclusive of Estimates Committee H Hansard dated 12 October 1981.
Leave granted.
The pages read as follows-

Mr Daly-It is not a question specifically for a person on the Board to answer. However I will attempt to assist you. The Government determines its appropriation. The Board administers the grants schemes and makes grants up to that amount of appropriation in a year. Government policy determines how much goes into any appropriation item. An estimate was made of the number of claims the Board expected to receive in the financial year. The value was carried over from the previous financial year at 1 July and determination made that the amount available this year would be increased so that additional moneys would be paid out to exporters in that time. Frankly, government policy determines how much is made available there.
Subdivision 1-Salaries and Payments in the nature of Salary, $1,992,000.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is it expected that there will be any changes in item 01 following the implementation of the Government's new policy at the end of June next year? Is it expected that the new policy will require fewer staff?
—Is this a question concerning staffing numbers and staffing establishments?
—Yes.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Hall-Are you referring to the decisions the Government will take following receipt of the report of the Industries Assistance Commission?

TALK.START.PARA: —No, I am referring to the Review of Commonwealth Functions and the halving of the rate of payment as from 1 July next year.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Daly-The fact that the grant rights for the export expansion grants scheme will be halved in respect of 1982-83 and those claims will come to the Board for determination from July 1983 onwards will not reduce the amount of work on the Board because the same number of claims or indeed more or less can be expected, but it will not be dependent on the grant right. It will mean only that the payout will be somewhat less.

TALK.START.PARA: —I expected that there would not be any significant change in staffing levels. I just wanted to confirm it.

—Is any mechanism available within the system for export development grants to recoup from an exporter where that exporter is proved to have exported goods that do not come up to standard? For example in 1978-79 amongst the many export grants made available was one of $245 to Steigers Meat Supply (Aust.) Pty Ltd. It is not a very large amount. I do not wish to do anybody any harm. My memory is that this firm may be one that has been involved with meat rackets. If we turn to the later year we find the company Edward Sovery & Co. Pty Ltd, which received $60,712. I think in the same year we find the names Protean (Holdings) Ltd and Protean Trading Pty Ltd, and I think later the same firm is mentioned again. I am not saying that the companies did so, but I believe Mr Hammond, the follow who is up on charges, took meat out of Protean (Holdings). I am wondering whether it is proved that some of this meat may have come from any of those establishments which are later proved to have been less than honest in their dealings. Is there any mechanism for that money to be retrieved?

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Daly-I think one would have to recognise that some of the content of the question is really sub-judice, so I will answer in principle. Exports of the principal classes of meat were made ineligible for grant purposes after the 1978-79 grant year, that is, from 1 July 1979. Some other meats remain eligible. Without being facetious, I know that horse and kangaroo meat remain eligible for export expansion grant claims. I think the time has so passed on that in October 1981 we have moved a long way beyond 30 June 1979, and so the question may have more than a little of a hypothetical element in it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is some form of false pretences in the export of certain goods feasible? If so, is there any provision under the Act to retrieve funds so granted?

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Daly-Yes, there is ample provision for the recoupment of funds which may have been unwittingly paid on good faith when further knowledge comes to the Board. That is referred to in section 40 of the Export Market Development Grants Act, where there is a specific provision for the recoupment of such moneys, and also in the equivalent section-section 19-of the Export Expansion Grants Act 1979. Specific provisions are available where a grant has been made in good faith but on the basis of subsequently shown false information moneys can be recouped.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer to Statutory Rule No. 127, which was gazetted at the end of May last year. An answer was supplied to Senator McLaren relating to a question without notice asked on 11 June. I am not sure when the answer was supplied to him. The basis of Senator McLaren's question arose from the additional eligibility for grants created by Statutory Rule No. 127, and he asked whether it was expected that about $20m additional cost would be incurred. The answer said:

SPEECH.PARA: Statutory Rule No. 127 confers no benefits other than those intended at the time the legislation was enacted in 1978.

This does not really answer the question because the question does not refer to the intentions which may have existed in someone's mind at the time it was enacted. It is whether the effect of Statutory Rule No. 127 had incurred additional liabilities of the order of $20m. Could I have that question answered now? Is it correct that the additional liabilities created by Statutory Rule No. 127 amounted to about $20m?

Mr Daly-The senators had before them the Board's sixth annual report which was tabled in the Senate on 10 September. I would refer them to paragraph 58 in that report and perhaps it would be useful for me now to read that paragraph because it will, I think, assist Senator Walsh to understand what was behind, and what has been the result of the particular statutory rule that he speaks of. I quote from the Board's annual report at page 12:

The Board is engaged in the particular endeavour of making the ultimate determination of claims by claimants in the meat exporting industry whose exports were necessarily caught up in the application of Statutory Rules 1980, No. 127, where meat was exported under quota to the U.S.A. and/or Canada. In August 1979 when the administrative problem involving section 4 (2) of the EEG Act 78 became apparent, the Board determined to defer for consideration exports to U.S.A. and Canada of both quota and non-quota meat. When the Board established its guidelines and procedures for the application of Statutory Rules 1980 No. 127, the involved claimants were recontacted so that the necessary data could be assembled for investigation. A total of 105 claims were seen to be involved. At its meeting on 16 June 1981, the Board was advised that of the particular 105 claims, revised determinations had been finalised or submitted for approval for 53; 26 continued under investigation, while the necessary data for adjustment were still to be provided for the remaining 26 claims. The Board, for its part, established a task group of senior investigation officers to carry through the complicated procedures involved in the adjustment of grant entitlement as provided for in the particular Statutory Rules.

Let me explain that the administrative problem that arose was in the wording of section 4 (2) which overlooked the fact that on 1 December 1977 the Australian Meat Board changed into the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation. It was the intention of government, as I understood it, that any quota arrangements which flowed from the Meat Board through to the Meat and Livestock Corporation would automatically be covered by the wording of section 4 (2). Advice from the Attorney-General's Department was such that there was a particular paragraph in the Australian Meat Board Act which prevented that interpretation. That was the whole basis of the need for bringing out what has transpired to be a most complicated regulation because the regulation, being retrospective to the enactment of the legislation itself, could not be brought in to disadvantage any particular claimant. But on the same score, it was not intended to give a particular advantage to any particular claimant. What the Board did when it was aware of this problem, was to advise Government of it but then it kept in reserve some claims or possible claim entitlement by setting aside both the quota and non-quota meat and saying it would not determine those until it had the proper regulation in place so that the thing could be done properly, in the way the Government intended. That has been the result. In the adjustments which have been made by the Board in these redeterminations there have been pluses and minuses to claimants, but usually of fairly small amounts. The suggestion that the end result of bringing in Statutory Rule No. 127 would be to give a further entitlement of $20m has no basis in fact.

TALK.START.PARA: —I dispute that. The effect of Statutory Rule No. 127 was to reduce the base from which an entitlement to a grant would be determined. Is that correct?

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Daly-The effect of Statutory Rule No. 127 was to enable the Board to make the determinations in the way in which the Government intended when the legislation was enacted in November 1978.

TALK.START.PARA: —I come back to that question of intention. Am I correct in stating that the effect of Statutory Rule No. 127 was to reduce the amount of money in the base period for the firm involved below what it would have been if Statutory Rule No. 127 had not been gazetted? If so, and given that the entitlement to a grant was assessed as the difference between the value of exports in the base period and the value of exports in the qualifying period, how could it have failed to incur a greater financial liability?

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Daly-Let me reiterate that the principal problem in the wording of section 4 (2) was the fact that the Office of the Parliamentary Counsel had sought to use a form of words which overlooked a small section in the Australian Meat Industry Act. This section did not, on the advice of the Attorney-General's Department, confer the intention of the Government that all meat, both under the Australian Meat Board and the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation, would have been ineligible for grant purposes under section 4 (2). The Board did not provide any moneys to any meat exporter in respect of quota or non-quota meat until the proper legislation and Statutory Rule No. 127 was in place. So the effect of this was that no additional entitlement was provided to any of the meat exporters.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can I put the question in another way? That does not answer my question any more than the reply received a couple of months ago answered Senator McLaren's question. Whether it met the alleged intention of the people who framed the legislation or not, was it not possible under the legislation in the form it was in then to calculate the entitlement of meat exporters? I realise that it would have been calculated in a different way because of the exclusion of certain exports.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Daly-Yes. It was obviously possible to calculate the entitlement of meat exporters who were not engaged in the trade which involved quota meat with the United States and Canada. Quite a number of claims were determined where there was grant entitlement which did not involve section 4 (2).

TALK.START.PARA: —Is Mr Daly saying that it was not possible to calculate the entitlements of exporters who were engaged in trade with Canada and the United States under the Act as it originally stood? Leaving aside the question of whether it was the intention, was it technically possible to calculate what the entitlements of those exporters would be? If not, why not?

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Daly-The Export Development Grants Board is charged with the administration of the legislation, which is the Export Expansion Grants Act. It seeks to administer that legislation in terms of the wording of the legislation and its understanding of that legislation and also of its understanding of the Government's intention in respect to that legislation. It is aided by the legal authorities of the Commonwealth where problems arise. Before it determines claims it has to be reasonably certain that those claims, those grants, are in accord with the legislation and the facts. I am saying to Senator Walsh that we deliberately put aside finalising the determinations of those meat exporters' claims until the proper regulation was in place on the advice of the Commonwealth law authorities so that we could then proceed to determine the grants as was intended.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that the board made a decision not to finalise those claims pending the gazettal of Statutory Rule No. 127, but I also understood Mr Daly to assert earlier that it was not possible to calculate their entitlements prior to Statutory Rule No. 127 having been gazetted. Was it said, or did I misunderstand it?
—I thought Mr Daly said that it was not possible to calculate them in accordance with what they understood to be the Government's intention.

SPEECH.PARA: ACTING CHAIRMAN-It was a matter of establishing it, was it not?

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand Senator Walsh's point.
—I will assert that the entitlements could have been calculated under the Act as it originally stood. Did Mr Daly dispute it?

—I also understand Mr Daly to say that he thought the entitlements might have been lessened by section 4 (2) from what they had been and they were restored by Statutory Rule No. 127. Have I understood it incorrectly?

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Daly-To safeguard myself, I would need to have a look at the transcript to see the particular words. But let me reiterate that where meat exports were underquoted to the United States of America and Canada the Board did not determine the ultimate grant entitlement of any of those claimants until Statutory Rule No. 127 was in place.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that point, but I still want to clear up this other matter. I will assert that it was possible to calculate entitlements under the original Act. I know it was decided not to do so. I am asserting, however, that it was possible to calculate the entitlements because the procedures were quite clear cut. Does Mr Daly accept that it was possible, or does he dispute it?

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Daly-I accept that it was possible to make a calculation of a grant entitlement which, if it had been strictly on the wording of section 4 (2) and as advised to us by the Commonwealth law authorities, would have been a calculation outside the intention of government in the formulation of that legislation. The Board shrank from making any of those determinations until everything was in place to make an appropriate determination.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have now established that it was possible to calculate the entitlements under the Act in its original form. We go back to the question I asked some time ago. As a result of Statutory Rule No. 127, was the ultimate liability of the Government increased by approximately $20m above what it would have been had the payments been made strictly in accord with the original Act?

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Daly-I assert and I think there were some questions on notice and the Department of Primary Industry was attributed with the figure of $20m-that of that there is no basis on which that Department could have made any assessment of that size and I think that Department also advised that was the case.

TALK.START.PARA: —My understanding is that the estimate was not made by the Department of Primary Industry. I know Senator McLaren's question said that, but I understood that an estimate of $20m had been made within the Department of Trade or possibly within the Board, I am not sure which.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Daly-Certainly the Board made no such attempt at any estimate of that size. I cannot speak for the Department of Trade but possibly Mr Hall would like to.

Mr Hall-From the point of view of the Department of Trade the answer is no, the Department did not make such a calculation and, as with the DPI, there is no way in which any Department could make such a calculation. The Grants Board is the sole repository for claims made and that information which is in a claim is not available to anyone else.

TALK.START.PARA: —So no estimate was made or recorded, anyway at the time, but surely the Board must have some idea-at least by now-of the likely additional liabilities incurred as a result of Statutory Rule No. 127. Does the Board have such an estimate now?

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Daly-I have to suggest on the part of the Board that it would not consider that question appropriate in the circumstances, because at no stage did it seek to do other than what it understood the Government's intention to be. It never sought to make any calculation as to what might have been the determinations without or with Statutory Rule No. 127. Indeed we have not at this point completed all of those 105 claims, because some of the claims are still providing data, to be able to tell you the total outcome of those readjustments made after the quota and the non-quota meat were reassessed. But at no stage did the Board see it appropriate to make any calculation of the sort the senator is suggesting.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who did divine the intention of the legislation?

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Daly-It is government policy, so Mr Hall may be the more appropriate officer to answer.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Hall, was any statement of government policy made by a Minister?

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Hall-Not as such, but I think one should bear in mind what the effect of not making the regulation would have been. If the Board were forced to make its determinations on the basis of the Act as it was written, it would have meant that meat exported to the United States of America and Canada in the grant year would be ineligible and yet meat exported in the base years would have been . . .

TALK.START.PARA: —I was wrong when I said it affected the base. It affected the figure in the grant year.
—If that was made known to the Minister, I imagine he would have sought a government policy decision based on that advice.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Hall-The intention at the time of drafting that clause was, as Mr Daly pointed out, made without research having been made into the provision of the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation Act which related to the transition from the Australian Meat Board to the AMLC. It was thought at the time that a reference to the AMLC quota would include that of the body that the AMLC took over from.

TALK.START.PARA: —I still think we are entitled to something a bit more specific. We are told that the intention of the Act was something different from what was actually written in it. Somebody must have made the decision that that would be so. Is it known who made that decision? Was it someone within the Department of Trade and Resources, someone within the Board?

—The decision to introduce the statutory rule was a policy decision. I understand that the rules for Committee witnesses include a rule that they are not asked to indicate advice which they may have given in the formulation of policy. I think we are moving close to that.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Daly-Let me state in addition to that that the Board has no role in the formulation of government policy; it administers the legislation with which it is provided.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Daly, was a decision within the Board not to process these claims made by the Board spontaneously or was the Board asked not to process them either by the Minister or by the Department until Statutory Regulation No. 127, or something like it, had been gazetted?

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Daly-I can state firmly and categorically that the Board, in seeking to make guidelines in respect of each of the provisions, foresaw the difficulty. Perhaps for persons here not conversant with this section, it ought to be stated. Section 4 (2) says that for the purposes of sub-section (1), where meat is exported to the United States of America or Canada, by virtue of a quota allocated under a scheme prepared by the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation, that meat shall not be taken to be eligible goods. The Board, in seeking to make guidelines, foresaw the difficulty which eventually emerged. Without any external prompting, it approached the Attorney-General's Department, which is the appropriate Crown Law authority, for advice. The Attorney-General's Department, in looking at the wording of that section, saw a defect, in its view, arising out of a particular section in the Australian Meat Industry Act, the forerunner to the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation Act. I understand that defect was not foreseen by the Parliamentary Counsel at the time. On receiving this advice from the Attorney-General's Department, the Board immediately advised the Department of Trade and Resources, which immediately was in touch with the Minister. My understanding is that the Minister said that a regulation should be prepared for gazettal.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer once more to the intention, or what we have been told about someone's assessment of what the Government intention was. We are not too sure whose assessment it was. Let us bear in mind the price of beef, which was the major export and which roughly doubled in price in the financial year 1978-79, over what it had been in the previous year. It seems to be postulated that because the grants to particular firms would be less than the Government had intended at the time the original Act was passed, it is reasonable, fitting and proper that the regulation should effectively amend the Act. Did the Government also anticipate, at the time it drew up the conditions, that the price of beef would double in that second year for which the product was eligible for a grant? A dual standard seems to be operating. A belief seems to be held that the firms ought to be compensated for some unintended loss which they may incur, and that it is quote acceptable for them to pick up a huge windfall gain because the extent of the grant was determined not by the volume of the product but by its value. When prices doubled, as they did in that year, was there not enormous windfall gain, as well? If the firms are going to be compensated for their windfall losses, would it not be reasonable to argue that some account should be taken of the windfall gain-unless the Government at the time it framed the Act anticipated that meat prices would double in the financial year?
—I do not know that the Government anticipated any such rise, but I do not think the question is appropriate.

SPEECH.PARA: ACTING CHAIRMAN-It is just a matter of opinion. I do not think we are going to solve anything by furthering that sort of investigation.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has been finally determined that it is possible to calculate the entitlements as the Act was originally written. If I remember correctly 53 firms have had their entitlements determined under the Act as effectively amended. Could the Committee have a list of those 53 firms with their entitlements as finally assessed and their entitlements as they would have been if the Act had been applied as it was originally written?

—Such information does not exist, as Senator Walsh will appreciate from the discussion that has gone on. Deriving that information will involve an exercise. I can pass Senator Walsh's question on to the Minister for such determination as he may care to make.
—The grants paid to the 53 firms will ultimately be published in the Board's annual report.
—That is not the issue; the issue is the other exercise you want carried out. I will pass that onto the Minister.

—From the data the Board must have available to it, it would be quite a simple exercise to calculate it. If the information is not forthcoming I assume it is because the Board and/or the Government does not want us to know the degree to which particular firms benefits from Statutory Rule No. 127.
—I am not sure that the assumptions Senator Walsh makes are necessarily correct at all.
—I have two more questions. Firstly, is Mr Allgrove still the Commissioner in Jakarta?

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Anderson-Yes.

TALK.START.PARA: —Secondly, does the Department have the average price at which the tobacco leaf to which I referred earlier is exported? If so, can that be supplied to the Committee?

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Anderson-We do not have that information.

TALK.START.PARA: —Would Business and Consumer Affairs have it?

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Anderson-We cannot answer that. We do not know whether it has the information.
ACTING CHAIRMAN-I thank the Minister, officers of the Department, the members of the Committee and Hansard for their presence today. I declare this meeting of Estimates Committee H closed.
Committee adjourned at 4.36 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —These meat Bills which are currently before the Senate draw attention to the costs of the National Country Party's maladministration to which I have referred. They are a cost to the nation and they are a cost, especially in this instance, to the very people which the Country Party claims to offer special representation. The long term damage which this scandal will do in particular to the Australian beef export industry on the United States market is incalculable. The attributes of Country Party administered departments are inertia, incompetence and a propensity to set up sleazy backroom deals. The departments have acquired the character of their Ministers. Country Party inertia and incompetence in ministerial positions have been responsible primarily for the lack of prgress in the establishment of a single and efficient meat inspection service of the type which could have prevented from happening at all the scandalous behaviour which has surfaced in the last couple of months.

SPEECH.PARA: These Bills are an incomplete attempt to do what should have been done years ago. The Opposition, however, despite these criticisms, is bound to support them because they do represent some progress, albeit at Country Party pace.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the opportunity to say a few words in the debate on these meat Bills which deal with penalties for fraudulent activities in relation to the export of meat. I particularly welcome the fact that this legislation is before the Parliament so soon after the issue of horse meat and later kangaroo meat substitution for beef in meat exported from Australia was raised. I remind the Senate that it was in mid-August that the first reports were given that in San Diego meat which had been discovered in cartons purporting to contain Australian export beef was discovered not to be beef as it should have been. The Government moved quickly but at that stage needed evidence to confirm the suspicions, and some species testing had to take place. Immediately, meat was impounded in Australia and species testing took place in Australia. On 19 August it was confirmed that among that meat which had been impounded meat other than beef had been detected following species testing in Australia. At that time many stories were circulating about what this all meant. Many allegations were being made privately about people involved in a meat fraud and about the scope of the fraud itself. On 20 August in this chamber I asked a question of the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) who represents the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon). I asked whether the Government would consider setting up a judicial inquiry into this matter. The reason I asked the question in the way in which I did was that at that stage none of the allegations had been made publicly and there was no way of discerning whether the very serious allegations were in any way well justified. I supported the call for a judicial inquiry on the grounds that a judicial inquiry can move quickly and it gives people the opportunity publicly to make their allegations, which allegations can be either proven or disproven. Subsequent events led to the setting up of a royal commission into the whole meat scandal. At the same time the Government also moved quickly to increase the penalties that apply to fraudulent practices in relation to the labelling and export of meat.

SPEECH.PARA: I ought to say at this stage that it is incumbent on us to remember that it is not only export meat that we need to be concerned about. The domestic meat market is a significant one for those involved in the meat industry and there is evidence of a decline in the consumption of meat in Australia. The ramifications of this meat scandal could be very serious for the meat industry in regard to the consequences within Australia as well as the United States. We ought not to forget that the Australian consumer is a major consumer of the meat that our producers need to market.

I visited the United States at the time that this scandal was at its height and I was there when the Minister for Primary Industry announced that there would be a royal commission and that the Government was moving to levy severe penalties on those who had so fraudulantly acted and so abused Australia's good name and integrity in the international meat trade. I had the opportunity to speak on the issue to officials of the United States Department of Agriculture and the Department of State, to members and staff of congressmen and of Senators as well as to our representatives in the United States. I spoke also to others associated with the meat lobby in the United States. I was therefore surprised when I returned to Australia to find that there was quite some complacency here about how seriously we ought to regard the impact that this scandal has had on our integrity and standing in the United States. I am not suggesting for one minute that the Government had that view but I was surprised to read news reports quoting people who purported to be spokesmen for those interested in the beef industry in the United States saying that it was not a large issue in that country. I found it to be a very large issue. Wherever I travelled in the United States I encountered people not involved in the industry at all who were aware of the fact that there was a scandal current and that kangaroo meat and horsemeat had been sold in the United States masquerading as beef.

This fear of mine was borne out by a story in today's Australian Financial Review headed 'New threat to US beef market'. The article outlined moves made in the United States Congress which could severely restrict Australia's beef export trade to America. While I was in the United States I had the opportunity to discuss this very legislation with those associated with it. The report in the Australian Financial Review indicated that the legislation in question has been passed by the United States Senate in the United States and that it may well be passed by Congress. We need to be very concerned indeed. When speaking to one of the supporters of the legislation no bones were made at all about the fact that the horsemeat scandal had given this legislation just the fillip it needed to be passed by Congress. The legislation had been before Congress twice and had been twice defeated. This time it looks as though it will be passed.

The reasons for the legislation are not based in Australia. The reasons are the protection of United States beef producers and also there is some concern about some of the processing procedures which are used in countries other than Australia which export beef to the United States. In the past the criticism that has been levelled at the methods of inspection, inspection standards and so on in meat processing plants has not attached to Australia. Australia has been a well regarded supplier of meat to the American market. However, this scandal has effectively destroyed our credibility with a large number of the members of the United States Congress and the Senate.

I have to say to the credit of the United States Government officials who were involved in the discussions that they were entirely fair and they did all that they could to ensure that Australia's meat export trade to the United States was not unfairly jeopardised. The Government of course moved very quickly, as I said earlier, to impound meat from the Profreeze processing works, and as a result of the prompt action by the Australian Government the United States officials were able to reassure some who would have wanted instantly to stop all further shipments of meat from Australia to the United States and to persuade them that was not reasonable or fair.

We ought to recognise that the United States Government has been very fair and reasonable with Australia in this matter. However, the Government cannot control what legislation will pass Congress. Under those circumstances one can understand the outrage felt by Australian beef producers and others involved in our meat industry at the effect that the actions of these perpetrators of fraud have had on their industry. As I said earlier, it is important that the allegations that have been made-some of them publicly, some of them not publicly-come out into the open and that those who have allegations to make, make them to the royal commission.

One of the issues I discussed with those interested in the United States was the significance of the Government having decided to appoint a royal commission and of its having to move quickly to increase penalties to show its bona fides. It is very important that we handle this whole issue properly now. One of my great fears about allegations that are made-but not made in the proper channels-is the potential for future damage to our meat industry. If we reasonably overcome this present difficulty and legislation which would enormously disadvantage our meat producers, processors and exporters does not pass through the Houses in the United States then we can be grateful. However in just a couple of years time, because of cyclical problems, exports to the United States will be more difficult anyway for our meat industry. We must ensure that when that time comes it will not be possible for those who would try to stop the import of our meat into the United States to say there is something wrong with the Australian meat industry that has never been cleared up. We must ensure they will not be able to refer to this scandal to raise vague fears about its significance. The allegations must be made publicly now and they must be proven or disproven and those who are implicated must face the consequences of their action.

If, after the hue and cry has died down and after we have these much higher penalties, we do not as a government move as severely as we can to bring to bear the penalties applying to the actions of any who have been involved in aiding and abetting this swindle we will have betrayed our entire industry. In September Mr Nixon said:

Without in any way trying to play down the gravity of the situation, the facts at present indicate that the great bulk of Australia's meat export industry is carrying out its trade honestly and fairly.

For the sake of that great bulk of the meat export industry, for the producers, processors and exporters, and for the sake of the livelihoods of all who depend on that industry and who trade and work honestly and fairly, we must make sure at all times as a government that our actions in relation to those who have jeopardised this industry are as clear and as severe as we can make them.

In conclusion, I think a very special tribute should be paid to those who represent our country in Washington. Mr Nixon, in his statement, said that actions by the United States Department of Agriculture and its co-operative attitude on our problem confirmed these two significant points:
The confidence of the US Administration in the Australian meat export industry, and
The success of close co-operation and consultation between US and Australian government and veterinary authorities.

I add that the efforts made on our behalf by our officers, particularly by our trade officers, in our embassy in Washington, ought to be publicly acknowledged. The contribution they made in assisting our case and in the understanding of our position when this scandal arose was enormous. It was not something they could do on short notice. Their effectiveness largely arose because they are very professional people who are well regarded and who always work very hard in our interests. It was to the benefit of all Australians that they so ably assisted in averting what could have been an instant disaster for our meat industry. As it was, the meat market instantly declined with a softening of prices and our beef producers received a lower return. Some indications now are that that market is firming up and that our meat producers can look forward to a reasonably stable future in the short term. One can only hope that those who have the power to make law in the United States will recognise that the Australian Government has moved resolutely and firmly and is determined to ensure that those fraudulent actions which have come so close to sabotaging such a vital industry will not be tolerated in this country, and that they are indeed only a small minority of our total industry and that our meat industry is one of integrity and deserves to be treated as such.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I feel I should apologise because I wish in fact to speak to the Bills directly and not on the general issue of the meat scandal!
—They are related to the meat scandal.

—Definitely. The major thrust of the Meat Export (Penalties) Bill 1981 and associated Bills, as the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon) pointed out, is in fact to provide for severe penalties to be imposed on any person who contravenes the provisions of the Bills. The Bills seek to impose increased penalties, which are welcomed by the Australian Democrats. However, in relationship to these increased penalties, section 12 of the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation Act 1977 states:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Where the Corporation is satisfied that a licensee has contravened or failed to comply with a condition to which the licence is subject, the Corporation may cancel the licence on and from such date as it thinks fit or may suspend the licence-

Sub-sections (2), (3) and (4) make similar types of provisions. It strikes me that the penalty of suspension or cancellation of a licence is one of the most important of the penalties that the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation may impose. However, although we have these Bills before us to increase penalties and although that quite severe penalty was contained in the original Act of 1977, the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation had never exercised that power until September 1981. In other words, merely setting Bills down in this House is useless and increasing penalties is useless unless indeed the Corporation becomes more active and actually makes use of its powers in the protection of the industry.

It seems to us that rather than imposing the financial types of penalties contained in these Bills, which we support, the Corporation ought to direct itself quite specifically to exercising its muscle in terms of the power already given to it under the original Act of 1977. It should actively suspend or cancel the licences of any of those companies or individuals found trespassing on the provisions of their licence. We believe that only in that way can we protect the rest of the industry and our major export markets. There are examples of companies that have been subjected to fines under previous Acts and have then received grants from the Government for a variety of developmental projects.

If the Corporation had acted firmly since 1977 and made full use of its powers we would not be in the situation that has been revealed in the last few months. Any company that is found to be involved in the type of operation that is currently being revealed, and no doubt will be revealed by the Royal Commission, should have its licences cancelled and should not again be allowed to apply for a licence. While that may seem draconian, I believe that it is the only fair and proper course for the Corporation to pursue if the livelihood, good name and reputation of other companies, which abide by the law in going about their business and exporting, are to be protected. If the Corporation is not willing to use the power granted to it under the 1977 Act to suspend or cancel licences, I see absolutely no reason why it should be interested in using the types of penalties to be imposed under this legislation. Merely gathering income by imposing a financial penalty on an individual will certainly penalise that individual but it will do absolutely nothing for the confidence of the industry as a whole. What will find a great deal of support within the industry, and I am sure that the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) who represents the Minister for Primary Industry in this place would agree with me, is that people in primary industry, and the meat industry in particular, are of one mind in believing that the existing provisions ought to have been used and ought to be used regularly in the future against any company found guilty of such offences. We believe that the stringent application of the power the Corporation already has would be sufficient to regulate the problem that has arisen. By that means, and by the use of additional provisions-because of the complexity of the company law-we would ensure that those who had been directors and were in any way involved in those companies' nefarious activities would not be allowed to regain a licence under some other company title. If such matters were looked into and the Corporation exercised its muscle with the powers that it already has, the provisions of this legislation to which I have referred would not have been necessary.

The Australian Democrats will be supporting these Bills. We believe that they form a useful adjunct to what we are doing, but we do not believe that they contain the major power available to the Corporation. I hope that we will not have to wait another four or five years before the Corporation uses the power it has had since 1977.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-Unlike Senator Macklin, I hope that we will have to wait more than four or five years before there is any call for the exercise of this power, but perhaps I have lost the zest for battle that he, as a more recently arrived senator, still has. In any event, I thank all honourable senators for their support of this legislation, which is but one reaction to the problems which beset the meat industry and which have received a considerable amount of attention in this chamber since they were first brought to notice. There has also been the question of a police investigation. There have been suspensions of licences. New procedures with respect to the handling and testing of meat have been instituted, and we have in process a Royal Commission which will be examining matters of concern in this area.

SPEECH.PARA: This legislation, which imposes very heavy penalties for offences, is but one of the steps to be taken in the matter. Although Senator Macklin observed that he believed this was not the effective area of penalty, he too indicated that in general he supported the legislation. The importance of the industry to Australia is a matter on which there is general agreement in the Parliament. The concern expressed about the damage that might be done to our trade reflects that view, and I commend the legislation to the Senate for speedy passage.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time, and passed through their remaining stages without amendment or debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak briefly to the motion, which of course I do not oppose. On 24 September, which was the last day of the session before the fortnight recess for the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting, the Government Whip said:

SPEECH.PARA: I refer now to the reports that have been tabled. That is hardly time enough for comment on more than one of two. That is not a satisfactory arrangement. It does not bear out the words of Senator Kilgariff, which I am sure were uttered in all sincerity, on Thursday, 24 September. I suggest that plenty of things are hidden; that there is every indication of trickery, not by Senator Kilgariff but by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Carrick) and those who run the affairs of the Government in this place. In the circumstances, I wish to register the protest of the Opposition at the treatment it has received.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-There was certainly no intention to indulge in what has been described as trickery. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The annual report of the Trade Practices Commission for 1980-81 raises quite fundamental questions about the functions, and the capacity to function, of the Commission. It is now seven years since the Murphy Trade Practices Act was introduced, changing as it did the face of restrictive trade practices and consumer protection law. This report highlights the continuing retreat of this Government from the objectives of that Act. It is a simple truth that there is no better way to frustrate the operation of regulatory legislation such as this than to withhold funds from the body set up to administer it. The evidence is overwhelming that Australian industry and business do not spontaneously eradicate restrictive practices or place consumer protection above profit, without legislative direction. Such legislative direction must be capable of enforcement by a suitably equipped and funded supervisory body. Yet this Government seeks to perpetrate another sleight of hand on the Australian public by publicly supporting the legislation while secretly, away from the public gaze, making the Trade Practices Commission progressively impotent by cutting back its funds and staff. The reduction of the Commission's staff by 30, or 16 per cent, over the last eight months of the immediately concluded 1980-81 financial year can only be described as savage in the extreme.

SPEECH.PARA: There is one optical illusion, this time perpetrated by the Trade Practices Commission itself, which I believe is deserving of some comment. I refer to the assertion in the report that the thrust of the competition provisions of the Trade Practices Act 'is not at all regulatory but indeed is deregulatory'. Whilst it is true that restrictive practices are a form, in a sense, of private regulation, which this legislation seeks to remove, it is simply incorrect and indeed misleading, for reasons which I spelt out in some detail in a recently published article in the Australian Financial Review, to characterise the Trade Practices Act as being 'deregulatory'. It was instituted as and must remain unashamedly a form of business regulation-that is, a form of government interference-in the operations of the market and in the decisions and the practices of non-government enterprises. That is exactly what regulation is all about. It has the capacity to be defensible regulation, regulation that is to be applauded, to the extent that the object of this kind of regulation, as it is with other categories of defensible regulation, is to ensure the achievement of widely desired social and economic objectives which the unregulated market does not necessarily achieve.

The Trade Practices Act is concerned with two broad matters: Restrictive trade practices on the one hand and consumer protection on the other, although they do obviously overlap to the extent that restrictive practices are themselves detrimental to consumers. Those matters are dealt with separately in the annual report. Restrictive trade practices, which are prohibited by the Act, include contracts, arrangements or understandings which substantially lessen competition, including price fixing agreements; monopolisation or the misuse of market power to exclude or damage competitors; exclusive dealing or commercial blackmail; resale price maintenance; price discrimination between customers; and mergers which place a corporation in a position of market dominance. These practices are objectionable for a number of reasons. They involve the misuse of market power by powerful corporations against smaller competitors, the maintenance of prices at a higher level than they would otherwise be, and the functioning of an economic system on a basis of discrimination, unfairness, inequality, and self-interest to the exclusion of the general interest.

In economic terms these practices are objectionable because they inhibit competition. This is hardly the time or place for any kind of detailed analysis of the concept of competition, but it is sufficient to say that we regard effective competition as being a pre-condition for the Australian economy to operate in the interests of all Australians instead of in the interests of private sector economic oligarchies. Unregulated monopolistic and collusive practices are almost always contrary to the best interests of Australian citizens, whether they be employees, self-employed businessmen or consumers. The classical theory of perfect competition holds that competition in a market maximises the efficient allocation of resources. Even if one could ever find a perfect market in the real world to test the theory, which of course one never can, the Australian Labor Party does not believe that economic efficiency is in any event the paramount goal or that the market alone provides any real solution to the complex economic and social needs of Australia. We deplore and will go on deploring the acts of social barbarity committed by the Reagan and Thatcher administrations in the name of freedom of the market, just as we also deplore the naivety of the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, Mr Moore, who said in the House of Representatives on 9 September, as recorded at page 1070 of Hansard:
. . . self-regulation is the best way in which any industry can provide for the consumer.

We readily acknowledge-indeed it was a motivating force behind the Murphy Trade Practices Act-that to the extent that we have a market economy in Australia, maximum competition is essential to ensure that the economy functions in the public interest. What has happened to the restrictive trade practices work of the Trade Practices Commission? I come squarely to the nub of this report. At paragraph 4.2.1. the report states:
The Commission is giving effect to the Government's RCF decision that the Commission should be more selective in restrictive trade practices complaint investigation . . .

In short, the enforcement of the Trade Practices Act is being wound back. We wholeheartedly endorse the comment of Commissioner Pengilley in what is described as 'additional comments appended to the report-which appears to be the current euphemism for a minority report-when he said:
Litigation is now of the essence of the credibility of the Trade Practices Act . . .

The Act is a paper tiger unless it is enforced. Yet, as a result of this Government's calculated undermining of this legislation, the Commission is being compelled to be even more selective than it has been up to date and to prefer administrative action over court action, administrative action being, in the words of the Commission as set out on page 7, 'much more acceptable to those who are alleged to be in breach of the law'. The Commission has also been compelled to rely heavily on private action which has all the numerous limitations alluded to by Commissioner Pengilley. I refer to paragraph 1.7 of his additional comments which appear on page 137 of the document now before us.

If litigation is the essence of the Act's credibility then its credibility is, I am afraid, in serious jeopardy. The Trade Practices Commission has instituted only one new case under the restrictive practice provisions since the beginning of the 1980-81 financial year. It was pointed out at the Senate Estimates Committee A meeting on 21 September last that certain of the present cases are of far-reaching significance and demanding of extensive resources. Whilst that is a partial answer, I suppose, to the point I am making, it is really no answer at all to the wholly inadequate level of active enforcement which these figures reveal. There just has to be more to the eradication of restrictive trade practices than taking on a few big cases.

I make these comments while being really quite fully aware that within the last week the Commission has had a major victory in the Federal Court of Australia with five glucose manufacturers being found guilty of collusive price fixing, each being fined $50,000 and ordered to pay the Commission's costs. That is a most welcome result and it is a resounding endorsement of the legislation and of the Commission's capacity, when it has adequate resources, to enforce the legislation. I repeat that if the prohibition of restrictive practices is to be enforced more than just symbolically, more than just selectively, the Commission must have resources to engage in investigation and enforcement on a wide range of cases, large and small.

The other main concern of the Trade Practices Act is consumer protection. It may be of some interest to honourable senators to be reminded that when the Trade Practices Act, as it now is, was introduced into Federal Parliament in 1974 the then Opposition, now the Government, opposed the inclusion of consumer protection provisions which were yet another Labor innovation. Of course, all the right sentiments were mouthed about agreeing in principle with the need for greater consumer protection but, in a manner all too prophetic of the 'co-operative federalism' in which this Government would like to see any Commonwealth legislative leadership drown, Mr Ellicott, as he then was, stated that the Opposition preferred to encourage uniformity between State consumer protection laws and hoped to see the establishment of consumer affairs bureaus and tribunals at that kind of level. The Labor Government stated then, and we reiterate now, our belief that consumers have a fundamental right to fair and honest dealing in business and that this right must be enforceable in law. It simply cannot be left to the erratic inclinations of the various States around Australia to generate the kind of consumer protection laws, which historically they have been so unwilling systematically to do.

The consumer protection provisions are set out in Part V of the Trade Practices Act. They prohibit, as we all know, unfair business practices such as misleading or deceptive conduct, false representations, bait advertising, coercion and harassment, pyramid selling and unsolicited goods or credit cards. They require compliance with product safety and information standards. They establish statutory warranties of quality, fitness, description and title in respect of goods supplied. In other words, they give consumers a shield against unacceptable practices and a sword with which to enforce their rights in transactions with those who possess greater economic power.

What is the Trade Practices Commission now able to do about consumer protection? The answer is: Precious little. By a ministerial direction, binding in law, which was issued on 25 May 1981 and which is reproduced at paragraph 2.2.2 of the report the Commission is actually prohibited from investigating a possible breach of the consumer protection provisions in Division 1 of Part V of the Act unless it raises issues of national importance and the matter is brought to its attention by another person other than someone operating on the staff of the Commission. This directive obviously has the most serious consequences for the functioning of the Commission in this consumer protection area. As the Commission acknowledges in paragraphs 2.2.5 and 2.2.6 of the report the Commission must now be 'even more selective' in consumer protection investigation and enforcement and will not be able to engage in such activity on its own initiative. Reference to the schedule of cases currently being prosecuted-that is set out in Schedule IV, Part C of the report-shows how limited the activity already is.

Perhaps worst of all, this directive means a retreat down the road to non-uniformity of consumer protection. Put simply, the individual consumer whose case does not raise matters of national importance-me can imagine what a large percentage that will be-will be at the mercy of the State administration to which he is subject. As Commissioner Pengilley points out again in his minority report, State law in some cases is simply inadequate and, on any view, there is a substantial degree of non-uniformity between the law of the respective States. That ministerial directive effectively marks the abandonment of the goals of certainty and uniformity of consumer protection law generally which the 1974 Act sought to achieve.

We note that this fundamental reordering of the Trade Practices Act has taken place by the back door; not by the Government publicly declaring its hand and amending the Act but by a ministerial directive. It is a miracle, I suppose, that the existence of that ministerial directive has at least come to light. It is also interesting to note that what is being achieved by this back-door method is precisely what the Opposition had in mind in 1974 when it opposed the consumer protection legislation. What it has resulted in is exactly what the now Government, the then Opposition, wanted it to become, namely, a State by State lottery for the consumer.

There is quite a number of other disturbing consequences of this cutback in consumer protection. All of them in the consumer protection work of the Commission are ably set out by Commissioner Pengilley in paragraph 3.6 on pages 141 to 144 of the main volume of his report. I do not need, particularly in light of the time, to repeat them. Finally let there be no mistake about what this Government is doing. By surreptitious financial and executive actions it is reducing the scope and efficacy of the Trade Practices Act. It is rendering the Act inoperative by degrees. In fact, it might even be described as a classic case of murder by degree, with each passing year seeing another drop of arsenic administered to the Trade Practices Commission's teacup. The next Labor Government will take immediate steps to restore the Act and the Commission which administers it to their full capacity and effectiveness.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
