SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The debate on the report of the Australian Electoral Office affords the Senate an opportunity to examine the deficiencies that obviously flow from the report. The report deals with a number of matters of a statistical nature but it does not deal objectively with the problems that confront the Parliament and the electors of this country so far as the Commonwealth Electoral Act is concerned. Of course the Government is aware of the deficiencies that exist in the Electoral Act. After the 1977 election the then Minister for Administrative Services, Mr McLeay, caused a report to be prepared. The preparation of that report took almost 18 months. It examined all of the features of the Act and its amendments from 1918 onwards. Subsequently that report was made available to the government of the day. For the Government's own reasons that report has not been made a public document so we do not know what it said, other than the general observation that has been made in the lobbies that the report is critical of the number of deficiencies that exist in the Commonwealth Electoral Act.

SPEECH.PARA: Subsequent to that the new Minister responsible, Mr Newman, following the appointment of Mr McLeay overseas, announced on 2 December 1980 that there would be a further review of the Australian Electoral Act. To our knowledge that report is still not available to the Parliament or to the Government, although in a letter of reply to me of 23 April-six months ago-Mr Newman, amongst a number of other things, said:
Questions relating to voting facilities and assistance for the disabled are among the matters being considered in my current review of the Commonwealth Electoral Act which is nearing completion.

So we have the statement of six months ago by the Minister that the second review of the Commonwealth Electoral Act was nearing completion. Here we are, coming towards the end of this session of Parliament, and still no information is available to us. As was the case with the first report and the report of the Harders Inquiry into Disclosure of Electoral Expenditure about which Senator Missen and I have asked at least three questions in this current session of Parliament, it has not been made available. We think it is treating the Parliament with contempt not to make available the work of the Department of Administrative Services and committees which have been charged with responsibilities concerning electoral reform in Australia. We can say that the situation surrounding the report of the Australian Electoral Office, insofar as it does not refer to the first report, insofar as there is no mention of the Harders committee report and insofar as there is no progress reported in respect of the second report conducted by Mr Newman, is a very unsatisfactory state of affairs.

The Electoral Office report provides us with some important figures and statistics. For example, it shows that 11.9 per cent of all electors in Australia do not vote at their subdivisional voting points; that postal votes, absentee votes and section votes now account for almost one-ninth of the formal votes cast. We have nine million voters and there is need for a review of the legislation to deal with such a dramatic change to the whole voting process.

The report makes reference to the large proportion of informal votes but makes no suggestions or recommendations to the Parliament about what should be done about the 9.65 per cent of votes cast in the last Senate elections that were recorded as informal, as wasted votes. The effectiveness of their votes was denied to almost 10 per cent of the people who voted in the last Senate elections. Surely that is a matter for the Parliament and a matter for the Government. It concerns the Opposition that these matters are still in limbo, that they are not receiving sufficient attention. Surely there is a need for a complete overhaul of postal voting requirements and a complete overhaul of the Act that deals with informal voting. Surely we can reach some agreement in the Parliament that as long as the intention of the voter is clear his vote should be regarded as an effective vote.

We are concerned about the people who are permanently incapacitated or disabled. We are concerned that the requirements of the Act prohibit many people, for a variety of reasons, from being able to record a postal vote, a section vote or an absentee vote. There is a need, therefore, for special steps to be taken in the review of the Commonwealth Electoral Act to enable all citizens of this country, wherever they are, to record effective votes. The Prime Minister (Mr Malcom Fraser) on 30 September last, over a year ago, promised to introduce legislation to change voluntary electoral enrolment for Aborigines to compulsory enrolment. Here we are a year later, with no further legislation projected in this session to overcome the difficulties that are apparent in the Northern Territory, Western Australia and Queensland in regard to the enrolment of Aborigines. We have seen some of the corruption in which some of those associated with the Government parties have been involved. They have attempted to impose restrictions, sanctions and discriminations against the right of Aborigines to be placed on the electoral roll.

The Opposition is very concerned-there is no mention of this subject in the report-about the activities surrounding the habitation reviews and the steps that are taken willy-nilly, haphazardly, by the Australian Electoral Office to check on the enrolment and eligibility of voters. The Electoral Office has made available to me information that indicates that in the year to December 1980, 279,784 voters were disenfranchised, taken off the electoral roll as a result of the haphazard way in which the habitation reviews are carried out by the Australian Electoral Office. Because of staff ceilings they are not carried out in all the electorates; they are carried out whenever a decision is made by an electoral officer that part-time staff will go into a particular electorate to check to see whether people have moved from the area. Consequently, steps are taken to remove them from the roll. In this way some 280,000 people have been disenfranchised.

That is a matter about which we would want to have a great deal to say because the people who are being disenfranchised, the people who are being taken off the roll, are those who are looking for work and who are moving about, those who have difficulties with accommodation, migrants who are not in stable employment or in a stable environment and people who generally move about without necessarily having a permanent place of abode or a permanent position. They are taken off the electoral roll.
I will have more to say about that.

In the few minutes available to me I want to refer to the fact that the Commonwealth, in conducting elections for Christmas Island and Norfolk Island, has applied some important new principles in respect of Federal voting in this country. In both those elections the Australian Electoral Office made decisions to introduce multi-member constituencies and the principle of proportional representation, matters which are the subject of a paper I have had prepared for general debate in the Australian community. I find it interesting that the Government has applied those principles in respect of elections conducted on Christmas Island and Norfolk Island, taking on board the regulations framed by the Whitlam Government in 1975 in respect of the Australian Capital Territory relating to the means by which candidates here are elected to the Australian Capital Territory House of Assembly. I understand that some arrangements have to be met by the Opposition in respect of the Government's legislative program and I therefore seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The debate on the annual report of the Commonwealth Electoral Office gives the Senate an opportunity to raise a number of the deficiencies that we in the Opposition believe exist in respect of voting procedures in our country. There is no mention in the report, for example, of the very important feature which is now operating in three of the States of our Commonwealth-that is, in Tasmania, South Australia and New South Wales. I refer to the system of optional preferential voting. This means, of course, that half of our country is operating under a system different from that operating nationally. That is a very unsatisfactory state of affairs because clearly electors are going to be confused. I would have imagined that a report from the Commonwealth Electoral Office to the National Parliament would at least pose questions for the Parliament in considering how to overcome the difficulties and deficiencies that obviously exist in our voting systems. Consequently, we can only say that a government that twice in the last four years has called for reports dealing with the Commonwealth Electoral Act and has failed to present them to the National Parliament must have an ulterior reason for not giving the Parliament the opportunity to discuss and debate these sorts of matters. Of course, it is in the interests of the conservative parties to have the community confused. It is clearly the young people, migrants and Aboriginals, some of whom are voting in the Australian system for the first time, who will make mistakes. They are the people who generally vote against the conservative parties and against conservative policies. They are disenfranchised as a result of the failure of our Federal Government, the Fraser Government, to rectify and simplify the whole voting processes.

SPEECH.PARA: The report gives us the statistics about informal voting. However, it gives us no recommendations on how to rectify this situation. It does not put forward steps that can be taken to rectify the position. Of course, it points to the obstinate and dogmatic attitude that was so much prevalent when you, Madam Acting Deputy President, were in this place on a previous occasion, when the Senate took the view that the lower House was not the place that ought to be supported in terms of its legislative program. In fact at that time before the Senate was legislation that would have simplified the whole electoral processes of this country. What were the issues six or seven years ago? What were the steps being freely talked about that ought to be taken to simplify the electoral processes in Australia? One proposal for the introduction of optional preferential voting had only one objective, namely, to make the vote more effective and reduce the informality of the vote by recognising that a vote was being cast in a certain direction even if a figure or two might have been transposed or improperly placed on the ballot paper. We said there was a need for a complete overhaul of postal voting and that a more efficient system should be operating. We said there was a need for a home ballot system for disabled persons, that there ought to be mobile polling booths visiting the homes of such voters. We said that there ought to be facilities available to people who are incapacitated in a variety of ways and may not be able even to apply for a postal vote because of the nature of their infirmity. We said the subdivisions should be eliminated so that we do not have the problem of people having to vote in the district in which they perhaps once lived, so that a vote is an effective vote wherever it is cast within the division itself. We said that there was a need to carry out a public education campaign. I think that need is even more pressing today, given the different voting processes which now exist in the States.

I emphasise again the very deep concern that the Opposition has about the way in which the Commonwealth Electoral Office is forced because of the Electoral Act itself to carry out what is known as habitation reviews. It can be said that the provision in the Commonwealth Electoral Act which allows an officer from the Commonwealth Electoral Office to go at random to an electorate and carry out a review to see that electors still reside at the address stipulated on the electoral roll is justified. But the facts are that in one year 280,000 people have had their names removed from the role because of habitation reviews that are carried out informally, haphazardly and in a random sort of way. The Opposition takes a very strong view about this. It believes that the Act needs to be amended, given the changes that have taken place in our society, the great mobility of people, the fact that people move from one electorate to another, from one State to another, often in search of work, often for a whole variety of personal and other reasons.

We stand by the view that once an elector has registered his name should stay on the roll, that the onus of proof should rest on the Commonwealth and not on the individual to place back on the role a name that has been removed. The only time a name should be removed from the role is when there is death, permanent overseas residency, serious criminal conviction or some mental institutionalising. The onus to establish residency of the elector should be on the Electoral Office. What happens, of course, is that the Electoral Office puts a card under the front door or in the letter box of a house if a next door neighbour or some disgruntled person makes a complaint or an allegation, and unless that card is replied to the name of the person is removed from the roll. The fact is that 280,000 people were denied a vote in the last elections because of this process. Yet, these matters are not even referred to in the report of the Australian Electoral Office with which we are asked to deal. I make no criticism of the Chief Australian Electoral Officer. I know, as I have stated in this place, that he has made two reports to the Australian Government but that those reports have not been published. They have been suppressed, and the Parliament and the Australian people have received no explanation.

Finally I want briefly to deal with the question to which I was referring before the suspension of the sitting in relation to the background paper that I prepared in respect of these matters, as well as to the establishment of a different voting system in this country, a system based on multi-member constituencies, a system based on proportional representation and a system which would make one vote one value effective in the way in which our parliamentary democracy operates in this country. This system operates in many parts of the world and, strangely enough, in the legislative councils of New South Wales and South Australia. It has operated in local government in New South Wales since 1941 with five and three member constituencies on the basis of proportional representation. The system was introduced by the Whitlam Government for the election of the Australian Capital Territory Legislative Assembly. As I was saying, it is a system that this Government has introduced in respect of the elections at Christmas Island where an advisory council has been established.

The day after I made available publicly the background paper on electoral law reform, a courier from the Prime Minister's office was on my office steps seeking a copy of that report. It is interesting that the Liberal Party has made no comment about the suggestions that we have put forward for party consideration. It is interesting to note that at Christmas Island this Government has in fact applied the very self same principles of that report to the election of the advisory council. The same applies in respect of the elections at Norfolk Island. One can only say that there is some merit in the system and that it is not way out, radical or revolutionary. It operates in a great number of countries and is already in application in parts of the parliaments of our country. The Hare Clark system has operated in Tasmania since 1907.

One would imagine, therefore, that in this report there would be some comment about the need for the Parliament to be looking at improving the existing voting processes as well as looking at other voting procedures. One can only say that the report is valuable insofar as it tells us statistically how many people vote in Australia and how many informal votes there are. It tells us that the Government is considering compulsory enrolment for Aborigines rather than the present voluntary system which has been corrupted by the Liberal Party in Western Australian and the Northern Territory, and we know all of the problems which have accrued in those two States, particularly in Western Australia, about Aboriginal enrolments. But quite clearly the Government is prepared to allow the Electoral Act to remain in its present form and not take steps to modernise and simplify it in a way that will enable every vote, whether it is cast in Tamworth, Turramurra or Toongabbie, in my own State, to have the same value. Currently we have an inbuilt situation where the seat of Werriwa in New South Wales has more than 90,000 people on the electoral roll and, within a stone's throw, the seat of Grayndler has 67,000 people, a difference of some 23,000. No action has been taken by this Government to bring about some equity in a redistribution to overcome the difficulties which exist in my State in respect of those figures and similarly in the States of Queensland, Western Australia and Victoria.

We are not satisfied with the report. We make no criticism of the officer who has to present a report within the confines of the responsibility of the office, but we are critical that the Government has not seen fit to direct the Commonwealth Electoral Office to deal with the matters which are obviously pertinent and relevant to a modernisation of our Commonwealth Electoral Act and the voting systems that flow from it.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Report: Proposal to Establish a University in the Northern Territory

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 24 September 1981, on motion by Senator Robertson:
That the Senate take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: — The report of the Tertiary Education Commission in relation to the establishment of a university in the Northern Territory I believe requires at least some statement to be made in this chamber. It is an extremely important report concerned with higher education in the Northern Territory which is the type of development likely to ensue in the foreseeable future. I agree totally with the recommendations in the report. I believe that it is a well balanced projection of the possibilities that the Northern Territory has in higher education. The report comes down not in support of the Northern Territory Government in relation to the establishment of a university, but does not cut off the possibility of the establishment of that university when the population is at sufficient level to warrant it.

SPEECH.PARA: I emphasise one major point in the report, and that is the point dealing with the Darwin Community College. The Darwin Community College was the first major attempt in Australia to establish a different type of tertiary institution, one which was able in fact to cope with what are generally called post-secondary and technical courses, courses which are in other States looked after by colleges of advanced education and universities. The Darwin Community College, I believe, deserves support in terms of that type of experimentation and development because I believe it is a model. Although it has been subjected to a fair degree of criticism in terms of its development, nevertheless it does present to Australia a possible model of educational establishments that we could make use of in future. I believe the Darwin Community College would have been a far better model to have pursued than many of the developments that are currently taking place under the Technical and Further Education Commission such as its development of colleges of one kind or another. I see the Darwin Community College as a desirable development within Australia. It is one which is economical in terms of its expenditure and scale and yet is able to provide for a community with a small population a high standard of post-secondary education.

The further point that the report makes in terms of strengthening the North Australian Research Unit of the Australian National University is also welcomed, I believe, because it provides the opportunity for the Northern Territory to establish in due course a university on a traditional model. I believe that must eventually come. One point that does need to be made-it is a point which was raised in debate in the Northern Territory on this aspect-concerns the fact that a number of people saw the establishment in the Northern Territory of its own university in terms of the prestige that would flow to the Territory. Whilst accepting that such prestige is important to local communities, and certainly to a community that is moving rapidly to statehood, I nevertheless believe that to proceed to the establishment of a university with prestige being its sole support would be a bad type of precedent.

The Darwin Community College and the North Australian Research Unit will, between them, adequately cover all of those areas that realistically and economically could be established at the present time in the Northern Territory. I think the people of the Northern Territory themselves are quite happy with this type of arrangement. Obviously it is not to the liking of the Northern Territory Government. Nevertheless I think it is not possible for the Australian community to foot the bill for an additional university in an area where the population is so small. Indeed, if the Northern Territory were able to argue successfully for a university at this time, many major cities in this country would be able to put a stronger case.

The last point I want to make is that since the Government has come down on the side of not establishing a university-I support that decision-I believe there is one further step that it needs to take, and that is to give to students from the Northern Territory support to enable them to study courses which are not offered in the Northern Territory but which are offered at other universities throughout Australia. I believe the Government needs to look at assisting the Northern Territory Government to provide slightly more generous bursaries and scholarships than other States are able to provide from their funds to enable students who have the capacity and the calibre to undertake a variety of courses to do so at other universities. I believe it would not be beyond the bounds of propriety to make it a requirement of those bursaries and scholarships that some undertaking be given by their recipients that they will return to the Northern Territory for at least a limited period to provide to the Territory a strengthening of its technical, professional and economic base. I believe this type of report does credit to the people who initiated it. It also enables the Northern Territory to move forward to statehood with a firm foundation in tertiary education. I look forward to the time when the growth which is currently taking place in the Northern Territory will enable the Territory to have a university which will take its place among the other universities in this country.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: NATIONAL ACCREDITATION AUTHORITY FOR TRANSLATORS AND INTERPRETERS

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 24 September 1981, on motion by Senator Robertson:
That the Senate take note of the papers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The report of the National Accreditation Authority for Translators and Interpreters is, I believe, worthy of comment in this chamber. To date the Authority has accredited some 1,053 people at three levels and in ten languages. In the last year precedence has been given to major community languages in this country, apart from English of course, namely, Arabic, Croatian, Greek, Italian, Serbian, Spanish, Turkish and Vietnamese. The 1980 annual report states that candidates have criticised the Authority's tests, particularly its use of language laboratories. The Authority has said that from now on more tests will be given on a face to face basis instead of reliance on language laboratories. The Authority is also seeking to encourage governmental and educational authorities to establish short term coaching courses to enable prospective candidates to improve or refine their interpreting and translation skills.

SPEECH.PARA: The absence of such courses, in the Authority's opinion, is a factor preventing applicants for accreditation by test achieving better results at their first attempt. One can only praise the Authority for taking this line of action to improve the training of interpreters in this country. This need was reinforced by the report called 'Catalysts for a Multicultural Society', which in June of this year recommended that the Commonwealth and State governments work together with tertiary bodies to ensure that the National Accreditation Authority for Translaters and Interpreters level 2 and level 3 courses are made available in languages which are most needed in the community. It recommended also that adequate allowances be paid to those taking the courses, that employing bodies provide study leave to enable staff members to take such courses and that employing bodies offer in-service training. I think we would all like to know what positive response the Government has made to these constructive recommendations. These recommendations, if carried out, could only assist in the assimilation and settlement of new settlers in this country.

As from now, presumably as a result of pressure from the Government in pursuit of what it calls its user pays principle-one might say it is an obsession-one wonders whether fees will be levied on candidates for accreditation. Certainly the Opposition is unhappy about this principle which the National Accreditation Authority in its report appears to accept on the basis that a professional self-regulatory body will in fact replace the Authority. I do not believe that most of our migrant translators are in the same economic bracket as people in the Australian Medical Association or the legal professional bodies. I would certainly deeply regret it if otherwise qualified people were prevented from receiving accreditation because of a high fee. I believe it is something the Government should keep in mind. It should ensure that there is no restriction on the training and accreditation of interpreters and translators because of this.

In the Authority's report in 1979 it was proposed that the National Accreditation Authority for Translators and Interpreters should extend its responsibilities to accreditation of interpreters in Aboriginal languages. It is a great pity that it has not done so to date, though it claims it will take this responsibility over in 1981. As we have only the 1980 report before us we do not know whether in the previous nine months of this year this project has been started. There are Aboriginal liaison officers in the Northern Territory and other areas with large Aboriginal populations who are trying to do a very difficult job in overseeing the welfare of Aboriginals in remote and distant areas. Anyone who visits such areas, particularly Alice Springs, will know the difficulties that these people face. The tragedy is that most of the officers do not speak Aboriginal languages. Their task would be simplified and the need of the Aboriginal people better met if they had with them, or could use on an easily contactable basis, accredited interpreters who not only know the language but also know the system they would be trying to interpret for those people.

The Accreditation Authority has also been approached to accredit persons in sign language for the deaf. So far it has thought it inappropriate to do this, although I am pleased to see that discussions are still continuing. If the Accreditation Authority will not or cannot do it the Government, and particularly the Department of Social Security and the Department of Education, should make good this deficiency. The profoundly deaf have been left out of what is called the communication explosion. There ought to be a body which takes responsibility for ensuring that, as much as possible, young and adult deaf people receive interpreting help, that as much sign language as is practicable is shown on television programs and that a good deal more help is given to these people in negotiating their way through our government bureaucracies in particular. I hope the discussions with various authorities on this matter are resolved very soon.

There has been a new approach from the Independent and Multicultural Broadcasting Corporation to test sub-titlers. This is a good move but I suspect it is mainly for English speakers. The Authority report has an appendix giving a breakdown of the number of accredited translators and interpreters and their names by State. This is of assistance. The appendix also gives the Authority's objectives of which the first is to:
Establish the standards and conditions leading to professional status, and in so doing developing translating and interpreting in Australia to meet community needs.

To this end the Authority is charged with a number of tasks which include monitoring changing needs for the interpreter-translator services throughout Australia to enable the meeting of these important community needs. I am afraid though that there is minimal information in this report as to how successfully these objectives are being achieved. For instance, it would be useful to know how many of these translator and interpreters are in government service, particularly in the crucial areas of police, welfare and health. Perhaps this information could be included in next year's report. I believe it is important that we have independent translators in these areas. One remembers that when the so-called social security fraud case featured prominently in this place one of the repeated complaints was that the interpreters were frequently the police officers, or associates of the police, who in fact were doing the investigations-hardly a situation in which justice is seen to be done. Neither police officials nor social security officers are amongst the groups with which the Authority said it had consulted in 1980 in spite of the importance and the urgency of migrant needs in these areas in these difficult times.

Finally I will quote from the report I mentioned earlier titled 'Catalysts for a Multicultural Society' dealing with interpreter services in Australia. The report commented on recent government policies. It stated:

. . . the right of the non-English speaking person to interpreter/translator services was gaining general community acceptance in recent years . . . this acceptance is now being eroded by the Government's recent policy changes which among other changes encouraged a 'fee for service' approach for service delivery. This approach is totally contrary to the original thrust of the developments designed to meet the needs of those non-English speaking persons, in the Australian community, disadvantaged by the lack of interpreter/ translator facilities in community services.

Dr Spiro Moraitis from Melbourne is quoted as expressing the fear that the interpreter-translator services would return to the 1960s situation. He summed up the current situation as a 'struggle in a sea of apathy'. The information needs of migrants have been categorised in the Galbally and the Scott reports. They have been detailed and we know the sort of problems being faced. We have to face the fact that if we are going to have the successful multicultural society so many people want, if we are going to have satisfactory settlement of non-English speakers in this country, we must act on these needs that have been now well documented. I believe the Government has taken minimal steps to meet these needs and went backwards as a result of the razor gang report on cutting out publications, restricting the telephone interpreter service, instituting charges for translators and other actions taken in this area. These services, together with readily available interpreter-translator services, are essential to the successful settlement of new settlers. I do not think anyone will disagree with that.

Rapid action needs to be taken to ensure that all proper assistance is available for non-English speaking members of the community not only in the area of justice, social security and education but also increasingly in the areas of medicine and the sorts of areas that English speakers take as readily available and have ready information on. Together with the recommendations in 'Catalysts for a Multicultural Society', this third annual report of the Accreditation Authority gives an opportunity for the Government to revise recent policies and broaden and hasten policies which show a real commitment to assist our non-English speaking migrants. Unless we do this we will add further to the divisions in our society. Unless we do this we could make second class citizens of a large group of people whom we attracted to this country who have contributed much already and who will contribute much to this country in the future.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: NATIONAL ADVISORY COUNCIL FOR THE HANDICAPPED

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 24 September 1981, on motion by Senator Grimes:
That the Senate take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The National Advisory Council for the Handicapped has produced in 1981 its fourth annual report. I note that the report was presented to the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) on 3 April this year and has now been tabled in the Senate some five and a half months later. I suggest this is a delay which is particularly significant as this is the International Year of Disabled Persons. It is a delay for which no explanation has been given in the presenting statement. The report is twice the length, but I suggest it has half the bite, of its immediate predecessor. There is a noticeable muting of the sense of urgency that pervaded the third report, which was presented in 1979. That was a report which caused considerable discussion among those interested in the matter. One is tempted to wonder whether the Council is beginning to realise that the Minister and the Government in fact take very little notice of its recommendations.

SPEECH.PARA: The report is full of general rather than specific material which certainly does not reflect the priorities that have been established by disabled people this year. They have been stressing through direct contact and through their organisations the need to compensate them for the extra costs of disability and to make independent living a real option. Disability is a very expensive life- style. Our country, which is to sign the international covenant, the United Nations Declaration on the Rights of Disabled Persons, has a duty to its disabled citizens to ensure that they have the opportunity to take as full a part in our society as they can.

These issues are covered in the section that follows 'Prevention' in the report. I suggest that on this occasion the recommendations are disappointingly weak and general. Disabled people have been hoping for action as a result of the work on income security by the Australian Council for Rehabilitation of Disabled. Instead they have here a recommendation that there should be more research into the extra costs of disability. This pushes the possibility of action even further into the future and is certainly disappointing in the International Year of Disabled Persons.

On employment, the Council notes that disabled people registered with the Commonwealth Employment Service have less than a one-in-five chance of a job as against the one-in-three chance of the non-disabled person. In the face of this, their sole recommendation, that governments stick behind the National Employment Strategy for Handicapped program, is empty in the absence of some provision for the evaluation of that program. Are we really sure as a parliament and as a country that we just want more of the same? In fact, the strategy that is being pursued by the Department of Employment and Youth Affairs is designed to segregate rather than to integrate. Disabled people are being trained in special rather than existing courses and the jobs at the end will inevitably acquire a stigma. The Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs (Mr N. A. Brown) notes that the Government is trying to give a lead in a program of equal opportunity by providing such opportunities in the Public Service, and I hope that the position in his own Department has improved since I asked a question some time ago about the number of wheelchair users on his staff. On 17 April 1980 the then Minister answered that it was a mere seven for the whole country. I welcome the recommendation that the income test free earnings limit for the sheltered employment allowance be increased. This, and the recommendations concerning regular adjustment, do reflect the demands of the field, and I would like to think that they would be implemented or at least seriously considered.

It is difficult to read the report without the knowledge of all that has happened or has failed to happen in the five and half months since its completion. The Provision of Aids for the Disabled Scheme began belatedly in four States and is already regarded as little short of a disaster in at least one. The Government has retained the unjust, albeit reduced, tariff on imported wheelchairs, and the Australian Bureau of Statistics survey of handicapped people has found even more handicapped people in the country than the previous estimate of 10 per cent. It claims, in fact that there are 1,200,000 such people.

In the light of this, the National Advisory Council for the Handicapped document fails to reflect the urgency with which the Government should address the problems of 12 per cent of the community. Most significantly in the International Year of Disabled Persons, no resounding commitment is made to the fact that disabled people are the real experts on disability and should be moving at the fastest possible rate to take charge of their own affairs. We still consult too little those who are directly involved. We still leave too many disabled dependent on non-disabled groups in the community which, well-meaning though they may be, do not consult sufficiently. The Government does not consult sufficiently, and the community has a long way to go before it accepts the disabled in the manner that it should.

I wish to express my disappointment this year in the Advisory Council's report and hope that it is not being reduced to a mere cipher because the Government has ignored its reports in the past, or from a sense of hopelessness because of the apparent failure of the Government to be interested in this area.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate is of the opinion that legislation should be introduced urgently to provide for payments under the Compensation (Commonwealth Employees) Act to be restored to the 1974 levels, with annual indexation to apply subsequently to those amounts.

Since I have been shadow Minister for Social Security in the Senate, this motion has been a hardy perennial. It arises from the Government's attitude to the compensation paid to its own injured employees. Payments to ex-employees of the Commonwealth who had suffered injury or breakdown of health in its service were indexed annually until the Fraser Government came to power. We ask that legislation be brought down to guarantee at least annual indexation of those payments. If the Senate should wish to increase that to twice-yearly, or even quarterly, indexation in line with pension increases, the Opposition would certainly not oppose it, but I and my colleagues believe that indexation should take place at least annually.

However, in the short term it is important that such an annual increase be introduced. The Fraser Government, on coming to power in 1975, cancelled the increase which was due in that year and provided no increases at all between 1976 and 1979, when it granted a 12 per increase to compensate for a period when the cost of living had increased by more than 36 per cent. On 1 September the Government increased the standard weekly compensation payment to $114. I assume that it will remain at that level until September 1982 or even longer. That figure is $13.89, or almost $14 a week, less than the compensation victim would be getting if the payment had been indexed to the 1974 level.

In July of this year the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) said, in answer to question on notice No. 664, that the estimated cost of raising Commonwealth compensation payments to 84 per cent of the minimum wage in the last financial year had been $3,500,000. To raise payments to the 1974 level in this financial year, which is what we have asked for in this motion, would cost the Commonwealh Government no more than $4m, or about one-third of the recent Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting.

Some people, such as Defence Force reservists, are now receiving more favourable treatment under the Compensation (Commonwealth Employees) Act, and we certainly do not quarrel with that. The position of Commonwealth employees in dangerous overseas postings has raised again the adequacy of compensation payments for those in government employ. Doubtless it has been raised recently in the case of the injury to Mr John Woods of the Department of Foreign Affairs during the assassination of President Sadat of Egypt. The late Tony Joyce of the Australian Broadcasting Commission was covered only by the provisions of this Act, but in that case an ex gratia payment was made to his widow. This is an unsatisfactory arrangement in the compensation region, as has been known for a long time.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was pretty meagre, too.

—As Senator Keeffe says, the ex gratia payment was pretty meagre considering the situation. This motion seeks to draw attention to the inadequacy of the compensation payments and to the present random approach to the cost of living increases to those payments. The current Government practice of increasing these compensation payments by regulation instead of by parliamentary legislation has in the past two years seen increases in the standard rates. It is not necessarily the case that injured ex-Commonwealth workers will get the continued increases unless there is, in fact, legislation. What this motion is trying to get over is a situation in which the Government becomes tight-fisted, as it did in the late 1970s, and refuses to give any increases at all over a period of years, as happened from 1975 to 1979. It is important that compensation victims are truly compensated for the cost of living rises which occur once they are invalided out of the Commonwealth Public Service or indeed out of any service. It is important that they are assured by legislation that they will receive increases to cope with the cost of living rises. In the early 1970s the Senate committee on national compensation commented on the present assortment of State and Commonwealth schemes. The committee's report stated:

SPEECH.PARA: It is clear that the compensation systems are random in their coverage, often provide inadequate compensation and can give rise to inequities. The Committee is concerned that existing social service benefits for sickness are inadequate and that compensation for injuries is effectively limited to work-caused injuries suffered by employees, to some victims of highway accidents who can establish fault in other persons . . .

Senators Chaney, Button, Missen and I took part in that inquiry. I am sure we would all agree that the situation has not improved since then. In fact, in some ways, it has got worse. There is a serious need, therefore, to re-examine the whole compensation system, particularly the question of a national compensation scheme, and whether there is a basis for the fault elements which play such an important part in the awards.

This Government last met with State Ministers in April 1976 regarding a national compensation scheme and then gave away the whole idea. But it needs to be looked at again. The matter requires careful consideration. The present compensation system is far too random. Factors such as where a person lives, how a person received an injury and how and when settlements take place in the courts influence tremendously the amount that will be received and the adequacy of the compensation. It is important to put some regularity and equity, as well as adequacy, into the system of payments. I suggest that this can only be done nationally, and in consultation with the States and the union movement. It is certainly difficult but the problems are not insuperable. New Zealand, under a Conservative Party Government, introduced a national compensation scheme. It should not be beyond the wit of this country to do so. I suggest that it does not make sense to throw the towel in, as was done in 1976. In the meantime it is important that workers who have spent their service, sometimes all of their working lives, with the Commonwealth, should not be financially penalised because they have worked for the Commonwealth. Their payments should be restored to the 1974 figure, which was considered an adequate figure, and adjusted annually. It is one of the best ways in which the Government can spend an extra $4m-a pittance in the total budgetary context.

It is for this reason that the Opposition has put this motion on the Notice Paper. It is again to draw attention to the fact that people under the Compensation (Commonwealth Employees) Act receive payments at the whim of a government. The payments are at risk if a government comes in with restrictive financial policies, as this one did for five years. Those people should not be placed in that situation. We must ensure that we do not create a similar situation to that which existed from 1975 to 1979, when there were no increases and these people were asked to bear more than their fair share of the burden of the Government's economic policies. For this reason I urge the Government to reconsider the situation and to restore some justice to this group of people for whom it is directly responsible.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Keeffe Sen J.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the remarks of the Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, Senator Grimes, in relation to Commonwealth compensation payments. I wish to quote from a number of paragraphs contained in a letter written by one of my constituents. The letter was addressed to the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) and was dated 5 October 1981. I wonder why the Minister has left the chamber. I must say that he showed very little interest in what Senator Grimes was saying. This letter is not a private document. I have handed a copy to the shadow Minister for Social Security. The first paragraph of the letter states:

SPEECH.PARA: Reference your News Release FC 81/49 of 19.8.'81 it is noted that the overall increase in rates is approximately 8.5 per cent.
He goes on to ask the Minister:
Would you please explain why the increase is less than the CPI of 9.4 per cent?
I suppose that one might go further and ask why the increase was not at least equivalent to the inflation rate of between 10 per cent and 12 per cent which existed at that time. The letter continues:
Particularly in the Year of the Disabled, one would have expected that a more generous attitude would have been adopted and a more meaningful adjustment have been made.

As the Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate has pointed out, there has been an erosion of benefits since the election of the first Fraser Government. Next year is the year of the tree. If the Fraser Government is still in office one can imagine the magnificent reaction of planting ring-barked trees so that water and fertiliser are not required to keep them going. I am quite sure that the Government will save money wherever it can. The letter continues:

The second paragraph of your News Release makes an attempt to make the government's decision appear a generous one by pretending that Commonwealth benefits continue to compare favourably with similar benefits payable under State and Territory workers compensation Codes; this, as you must know is, in general terms, simply not true.
I know that we cannot use that three-letter word 'lie'. My constituent has been well coached by me so he said 'simply not true'. The letter goes on:

However, even if this were true, comparison with State compensation provisions is rather meaningless. It may at best prove that the Commonwealth Government is less mean than others, but is mean just the same.

I do not know where the Minister is at the moment. It is 9 o'clock, which is probably his coffee time. I hope that he will find a spare five minutes in which to reply to the letter. As far as I know, to date my constituent has not had an acknowledgement of receipt of his letter, let alone a reply to his complaint. The letter further states:

Just how mean the Commonwealth Government is in the matter of compensation for its employees, may probably best be demonstrated when one considers that on 1.9.77; 1.9.78 till 1.9.79 no adjustment to rates were made at all.

This occurred at about the time when we were endeavouring, through the ordinary pension rates, to get some sort of indexation restored. I suppose the Government can justify its inability to make those adjustments over that period because of the extreme economic situation in which Mr Fraser found himself. My constituent's last remark is:
So, please, spare the public hypocritical statements on the Government's generosity.

In the Budget Speech the Government was very vocal in praising itself for its implementation of compensation payments, pensions and various other handouts that it was making under the Acts associated with the Social Services Act. I suggest that the statements made tonight by Senator Grimes are absolutely and utterly true and that it is time for the Government to take a good look at some of its own legislation and some of its own payments in this regard.

My constituent, who I am sure is one of the most honest people I have ever met, has set out the details in a number of documents on this occasion and on previous occasions. He is not one of those people who sit down and wait for something to happen, as the Prime Minister of this country appears to do. Apparently the same sort of attitude has now been adopted by the Minister for Social Security. He sits and waits for something to happen. Whatever complaints we might have had about Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle at least there were times when she made things move. The current Minister is apparently incapable of moving anything at all and he is certainly not capable of increasing pension rates, particularly in the Commonwealth compensation field. I hope that the few words I have added to the debate tonight have helped. I threatened the Deputy Government Whip that if I was not allowed to speak for five minutes now I would speak for an hour in the adjournment debate. I conclude on that point.
Debate (on motion by Senator Thomas) adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate notes with concern the rising rate of unemployment amongst girls and women as documented in the Myers Report on Technological Change and the failure of the Fraser Government to take specific steps to train women and girls for the changed job market.

At this stage of the parliamentary sitting I do not pretend that this evening I will be able to do justice to the subject I have raised. We have a crisis in women's unemployment in this country, a crisis which is not even being acknowledged, let alone addressed, by the Fraser Government. In the six years I have been in this place the situation in relation to women's employment has deteriorated month after month. Yet, not once have I heard a Minister of this Government acknowledge and propose any remedies for this situation. Indeed, a number of economic strategies which the Fraser Government is pursuing in a whole range of areas seems to be having the direct effect of creating even more female unemployment.

Women in this country are being forced into dependence either on a spouse or on the state. As I speak about three million Australians are living on benefits and the majority of those are women. The majority of women living on benefits are either unemployed or living on the supporting mothers' benefit. Of those women living on the supporting mothers' benefit very many, perhaps the majority, would be in employment if appropriate employment were available, if they had the opportunity to train for employment and, to speak of perhaps a most basic inadequacy in the Fraser Government's provision of public services, if there were proper child care services for their children so that they could be free to go to work. This is a very serious matter.

Over the last six years we have seen a number of economic strategies which are creating a huge and growing class of permanently dependent people, most of whom are women. We do not argue against the payment of a supporting mothers' benefit. Indeed, it was the Whitlam Labor Government which introduced it. What we on this side of the chamber are increasingly alarmed about is that women who are forced into unemployment or who are responsible alone for the care and development of children are being forced to live the life of a pensioner. There is decreasing opportunity for any woman in this country to move from a position of dependence to independence and that, I believe, is a crisis in itself. The scope of the crisis widens daily.

It is very many months since the report of the Myers Committee of Inquiry into Technological Change in Australia was tabled in this place. Yet, to date, there has not been an adequate consideration of this report by the Government. It is a most crucial report because it documents in convincing detail the changes that have taken place in the structure of our economy as a result of the introduction of new technology-those changes which have specifically led to unemployment or underemployment in a number of areas. Many of those areas, as was documented in the report, are traditional areas of female employment. I have been critical publicly and in this place of the amount of attention paid in the Myers report to the consequences of technological change for women. However, I must endorse its conclusion. The report states:

In summary then the adverse employment effects of technological change tend to fall disproportionately on particular groups in the community (women, youth, immigrants and the aged) and the beneficial effects are best able to be enjoyed by other groups (the more highly educated and the more mobile adapative and retrainable workers).
The report came to another very important conclusion which has been totally ignored by the Government. It states:

The Committee sees it as being the role of governments to ensure that benefits accruing from technological change are equitably distributed among all members of the community, both in and out of the workforce, and that the costs incurred in pursuit of these benefits are likewise equitably distributed.

All I can say in response to that conclusion is that the Fraser Government has done absolutely nothing to ensure that women do not bear a disproportionate share of the cost while missing out on the benefits. Both of those things are, in fact, happening. If we look at the unemployment rates for women we see how disproportionately the effects of technological change are affecting the female employment market. Unemployment among women and girls is consistently higher than it is among men. The latest figures show that 7.1 per cent of the female work force compared with 4.7 per cent of the male work force is unemployed. Female youth unemployment figures are appalling. In August 18.3 per cent of females aged between 15 years and 19 years were out of work compared with 11.8 per cent of males in the same age group.

When we look at migrant women we find rates which are very much worse. Of course, when we get to the stage of looking at employment opportunities for Aboriginal women we see that they hardly exist in this country. Because so many women are ineligible for unemployment benefit and therefore do not register, the unemployment situation is actually much worse than is indicated in the statistics. A recent assessment by a Sydney University economist, Dr Margaret Power, shows that on her calculations probably the real rate of female unemployment is double the measured rate. Yet we hear nothing from the Government in response to this.

Another disturbing trend in the female work force is the growing substitution of part time jobs for full time jobs. There was a time when women interested in promoting the employment status of women in the community argued the case for more part time employment. Indeed, I have argued that case myself under certain circumstances. Certainly, while ever child care is so hard to come by and while ever women continue to have to bear the full domestic duties as well as work force duties, part time work is an option that can be of assistance to some women. But in recent years we have not been seeing the development of beneficial part time work with all the benefits of permanency; we have been seeing, in fact, the abolition of full time permanent employment for women and the substitution of casual employment.

By casual employment I mean employment which may be a few hours a week. It may be 20 hours a week. It is paid by the hour. There are no proper entitlements such as holiday pay, sick pay, superannuation, long service leave or anything of that kind. Women are simply being called on to work for as many hours as is profitable for the employer and are sent home without pay for the rest of the week. This is happening at the expense of permanent, proper employment-not in addition to it. Because of the unemployment market the campaign to have permanent benefits for part time work has not been very successful. There has been very modest progress towards that objective in the public sector and hardly any progress in the private sector. What is happening, as I have said and as has been documented in a number of areas, including the Myers report, is that employers are simply sacking their women employees and taking on casuals.

Another aspect of the casualisation of the female work force is a form of age-ism which is creeping into employer practice in this country. Not only are full time jobs being abolished with part time jobs replacing them but also employers are anxious wherever possible to employ the youngest female school leavers, the 15 and 16-year-olds, in these jobs. Why? Because they attract the lowest rates of pay. When these 15 and 16-year-old girls turn 17 or 18 years of age and become eligible for a higher rate of pay, what happens? I know very well that in my own electorate-I am sure many honourable senators in this place can back me up-the employers sack them and take on a new group of employees that they can employ at the lowest possible rate. This is the reality of what is happening in the female labour market in this country.

I must remind honourable senators that it is quite pertinent to speak in terms of the female labour market because we still have a sex-segregated labour force in this country. Despite the efforts of the Whitlam Government and despite the efforts of some State governments in introducing anti-discrimination legislation and equal employment policies within the public sector, we still have a sex-segregated employment market. That means that the lowest paid, unskilled, least sought after jobs are the jobs available to women. The high-paid jobs, the jobs that attract on-the-job training, promotion opportunities, security and so forth, are the jobs that men get, speaking in very general terms. The mobility of women from the female labour force to the male labour force in the last six years has been at an absolutely minimal level. Even in the public sector, the figures put out by the Public Service Board for the Commonwealth Public Service indicate that the number of women who have changed from Fourth Division jobs into Third or even Second Division jobs is absolutely minute and almost statistically insignificant.

Despite the fact that the female labour force is growing in crude numbers there has been very little desegregation of the labour force and indeed there is now a new kind of sex-segregtion in the labour force which is not only segregation between the low-paid unskilled jobs for women and the high-paid promotion oriented jobs for men but also it is between casual employment, which is for women, and permanent employment, which is for men. This situation has been getting worse and worse and yet no Minister responsible for employment in this Government has even acknowledged that it is happening. A total of 36 per cent of the female work force is now in part time or casual employment. Seventy per cent of women part time workers are married and 55 per cent are aged between 25 and 44 years-the time when child care responsibilities are heaviest. It is quite clear that women with family responsibilities are moving into casual employment with inferior conditions and that they are doing this because of the lack of proper child care services.

These developments do have a lot to do with technological change, as documented in the Myers report, because technological change has been eroding those areas of employment which have been female areas. The clerical areas, of course, are very susceptible to the new technology. Word processors, computers and all that kind of technology may create jobs for some people but they are not creating jobs for women; they are destroying jobs for women. It is very easy to be slick and to look at the overall change in the job market while ignoring the sex-segregated aspects of it and to say that the new technology is bringing all these benefits such as improved efficiency in business and things of that kind. Certainly it is to an extent, and certainly the Australian Labor Party wants to see improved efficiency in business. We want to see profitability increase and we want to see development in entrepreneurial activities throughout this country, but where women's jobs are being eroded we also want to see appropriate government action to ensure that those women who are discarded by the introduction of new technology are given other employment options. It is certainly not happening at this time.

The Myers committee of inquiry received a number of very interesting submissions which documented exactly how technological change is eroding women's jobs. I would like to refer briefly to some of those. The Council of Australian Government Employee Organisations and the Australian Council of Trade Unions submissions pointed out that technological change will allow the banking and insurance sector to cut staff by between 30 per cent and 40 per cent in 10 years. Experience in overseas banking systems has demonstrated that this is inevitable. New technology has already cut jobs in these sectors by 150,000 and, of course, most of the jobs which have disappeared have been women's jobs. The Westaff temporary employment agency told the Myers committee that word processors have taken over the jobs of more than 20,000 typists in Sydney alone. The Commonwealth Bank said that computerisation will cut staff by 2,000 after allowing for the employment of 700 staff. Despite the documentation that the Myers committee received we have had virtually no response from the Government except for the tired old expression of the pious hope that somehow the economy will be all brought right if we get enough new technology to do it.

As I said, my concern is not specifically that the jobs are disappearing but that no other job opportunities are being created. We are not going to argue that unproductive kinds of employment should be retained in this country but we do argue and advocate that there should be a national employment policy, a national labour force policy, whereby changes in the work force, such as the ones to which I have been referring which affect women, are properly monitored and documented, that new areas of employment are discovered and identified and that training schemes with proper allowances, proper opportunities, child care and whatever is necessary, are provided for the displaced workers. The Whitlam Labor Government attempted to institute something of this kind when it instituted the National Employment and Training Scheme. I think that scheme was a fairly rudimentary kind of national training scheme. I would not defend it in every detail but I am sure that had we stayed in office longer we would have refined it and made it a more focused, more effective tool of management of the employment market.

However, the present Government has dismantled most of the effective aspects of the NEAT Scheme and has replaced it with a number of schemes which are not training schemes at all; they are really just employer subsidy schemes. They are really just handouts to employers to encourage them to take on employees that they might otherwise have been reluctant to take on. What sort of training takes place, whether the training is appropriate to the labour market and whether any training takes place at all is entirely up to the employer. The schemes are not monitored. I have sought, and I think other honourable senators in this place have sought, year after year with questions on notice to find out what kind of scrutiny the Government engages in to see whether training is taking place under these employer subsidy schemes. We have got very little result for our trouble. Basically the Government hands over the money to the employers and asks no further questions. As a result, very little training is taking place and certainly training that would assist women to re-equip themselves for the changed structure of the labour market hardly exists.

Our criticisms of the Government in this case are quite general. I would say that in view of the current trends in work force requirements the Government has failed entirely to come up with an appropriate training policy. Since 1975-76- the last year of the Whitlam Government-government spending on employment and training has fallen by 44 per cent in real terms. The majority of training programs which the Government has funded have not been based on the fundamental manpower principle; that is, channelling people away from areas where there is a contracting demand for labour into areas where there is an expanding demand for labour. This failure creates situations such as the one which currently exists in the Department of Defence. Because the Department has drastically reduced the training of technical officers, over $1m is now being spent to bring engineers, technical officers and other skilled personnel from Britain.

It should be noted that of some thousands of engineers, draughtspeople, naval architects, technical officers and trainees in these fields who are employed by the Department of Defence, fewer than a dozen are women. Fewer than 12 trainees in the entire Department of Defence are women. The Defence Forces also implement employment policies which discriminate against women. Women are still not accepted as officer cadets at the Royal Military College, Duntroon, and on current plans they will not be accepted at Casey University when it opens either. It is ironic that the area of defence, where discrimination against women in government employment is at its most blatant, has been the only area of Government spending to get a boost in the Budget-a 5.3 per cent increase in real terms. Clearly that boost will do nothing for employment for women.

Much of the increase in Government expenditure on training in this Budget is directed towards the Commonwealth Rebate for Apprentice Full-time Training scheme, which subsidises private employers to take on apprentices in areas such as metal and electrical trades and the construction industry. There is no mechanism, that is, no legislation or government policy, to ensure that women receive equal access to these programs. Of course, in practice they do not. While the Department of Employment and Youth Affairs does not keep a male-female break-up of those receiving assistance under CRAFT, the facts are that over 90 per cent of apprentices are male. It is reasonable to assume that a similar percentage of those receiving assistance under CRAFT are also male. While the Government advertises its CRAFT scheme in full page newspaper advertisements showing two young males in work clothes with the caption 'More Jobs for the Boys Means More Bikkies for the Bosses', this situation is unlikely to change. Such advertisements actively discourage young women from considering themselves eligible for apprenticeship training, and also discourage employers from considering female trainees.

The increased Budget allocation for skills in short supply will also go mostly to males because the areas of need are not traditional areas of female employment. No special effort is being made to encourage young women to stop training for office jobs which do not exist and start training for the skilled jobs that do. Without action on the part of the Government to ensure equal access for women to these schemes, the Budget's training provisions can be seen only as further subsidising male youths seeking skills at the expense of young unemployed girls. I have already referred to the huge disparity between unemployed male teenagers and unemployed female teenagers.

I would like to make a couple of comments on education funding and the failure of the Government to ensure educational opportunities which would assist women to overcome their disadvantages on the labour market. Part of the Government's Budget package is the imposition of fees for second and higher degrees in tertiary institutions. Who will this affect? Women who have spent some years out of the work force raising children are much more likely to need to upgrade outdated qualifications or to take a second or higher degree to be employable. They are much less likely than men to find themselves in the exempt categories announced by the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs (Mr N. A. Brown), so many of them will have to give up the hope of qualifying themselves for a good job. The area of women's employment is vital because it is a major determinant of women's incomes. As I have pointed out, women comprise a disproportionate percentage of those on low incomes and those on social security benefits.

Almost two-thirds of those who rely on social security benefits for the major proportion of their income are women. Budget figures on taxable incomes of males and females show that while 90 per cent of men earn less than $30,000 per annum, about 90 per cent of women earn less than $15,000 per annum. Fifty-five per cent of women who pay tax have incomes of under $10,000, compared with 27 per cent of men. One-quarter of all women paying tax earn under $7,000 per annum. This reflects women's part time participation in the work force. So it is very clear, whether we look at incomes, employment statistics, access to tertiary institutions for higher education, or job training that women are missing out. If we look at the Government's employment policies within areas of employment where it is the employer, such as the Department of Defence, we see highly discriminatory practices and policies. We need a complete change of approach if we are going to put a stop to the erosion of women's employment prospects.

I refer honourable senators again to the report of the Myers Committee of Inquiry into Technological Change in Australia, which documents the disadvantage suffered by women in the job market. The disappointing aspect of the report is that it paid so little attention to positive recommendations with regard to education and training to overcome this. It should not be beyond the capacity of a government of determination and good will in this matter to evolve appropriate training and education schemes. As I said at the beginning of my speech, there is much that could be said on this subject. I certainly do not pretend to have said it all tonight and I do not intend now to delay the Senate by saying anything further. I wanted to take this opportunity to make some comments on the situation. I hope that other honourable senators in this place will address their attention to this matter and follow suit and that we can have, at least in this chamber, a proper consideration of this most urgent and critical problem of women's employment and technological change.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Giles Sen P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: -As Senator Ryan has so eloquently stated, the recommendations of the report of the Myers Committee of Inquiry into Technological Change in Australia were excellent as far as they went. However, they have been left languishing on the shelf amongst many other excellent recommendations such as those of the Williams Committee of Inquiry into Education, Training and Employment and, looking back over the years, those contained in another excellent report entitled 'Girls, Schools and Society'.

SPEECH.PARA: In the meantime, employment of young women in Australia has become an ever-increasing problem. The double labour market has gradually developed into a triple labour market. One market is for males, and one is for mature experienced women who have been in the work force or have the skills that are valuable in the work force and to employers. The third is for young women who have left school, typically at about 15 years of age, who have no job experience, whose education may be rudimentary in the sense that they are barely literate and numerate, and whom nobody wants to employ. Their ambitions, on the whole, are very limited. They lack knowledge, they lack opportunity, and their aspirations are very low. School curricula in the main have led them into a circumscribed set of options. Community attitudes still see them in a very narrow range of occupations. Most of them, when they look for work, indicate that they are looking for jobs as shop assistants and clerks when, as we have been told so clearly this evening, those are exactly the fields in which job opportunities are declining rapidly.

The lack of education and guidance in vocational fields is a matter of great concern. I feel it would make an excellent reference for our Standing Committee on Education and the Arts and it is something which should be dealt with fairly soon. Eighty per cent of the women in the work force in Australia today would have left school at 14 or 15 years of age and would have only basic levels of education. Their training, such as it is, is what they have received on the job and may take perhaps from an hour to a week. They have learned their job sitting or standing next to Nellie. They go into jobs which have been described as low wage, low satisfaction and low status. Many of them work on a weekly contract, which means that their employment can be terminated with simply the giving of a week's notice and for no other reason whatsoever except that they are on a weekly contract. Very few of them have ever qualified for long service leave, especially the three-quarters of them who are employed in private enterprise and who would have to work continuously for 15 years before qualifying.

As I have said, four-fifths of the female work force has very little in the way of formal qualifications. This is not to say that they are stupid. Very many of them are intelligent, loyal, hard working and good natured. That is why they are employed. It looks as if an enormous sector of the female work force is in this category. However, looking at the increasing number of young women who stay at school for four or five years of secondary education, one would think that the situation could change. But, of course, this will happen only very gradually over the years, given that the average age of working women is now in the late 30s and early 40s.

In addition to being immobilised in terms of her occupation, geographically she is unable usually to move far away from home and her family responsibilities to work. Our typical working woman will have the choice of only a very narrow range of occupations. These will be found in one of eight industrial groups. She will be working in the retail trade, in some sort of clerical work, in manufacturing industry or in the catering industry. If she has done an apprenticeship she may be a hairdresser. Apart from that she may be doing cleaning of some sort or another. If she is one of the fortunate well educated women she will be working as a nurse, a teacher, a social worker or a librarian. She will be one of the 10 per cent or 11 per cent in the female work force who are elite by comparison with the rest in the sense that she is working on a somewhat better contract than the one that makes her vulnerable to being sacked on an hour's or a week's notice. She has some opportunity for promotion, for training, for moving up in her profession.

A study of young employed women that was carried out in Melbourne two or three years ago found that young women by comparison with young men were invisible. When unable to get work they tended to return home quietly to do the housework, to sit and watch television and to be out of sight and out of mind of society. Young migrant women particularly are in this position. The tendency, of course, is for them to feel that the only thing for them is to justify their existence by marrying young.

Unemployment rates for young women have always been higher than the national average with young girls-those between 15 and 19 years of age-constituting over 20 per cent of the registered unemployed in 1979. That has been the situation for quite a long time except that 20 per cent of the unemployed in 1970 did not represent a very large number of young women or, for that matter, any other sector of the work force.

There has been a gradually developing change in the attitude of young women towards themselves and work. When I started talking to groups of high school students five or six years ago about women in the work force I found that the main ambition among the majority of them was to marry. However, when forced really to study the situation most of them admitted that their mothers, their older sisters, their next door neighbours and their aunts were in the work force if not for all of their adult lives, for probably most of their adult lives. In fact the figures show that something like two-thirds of adult mature women are in the work force at any one time. One could turn that statistic on its head and say that almost all adult women are in the paid work force for something like two-thirds of their adult lives.
