In a study recently carried out in Australia on young unemployed women and their attitude towards work comments were made that young women were gradually taking a different approach to themselves as potential members of society and as potential workers. In the 1930s Wight Bakke wrote:
With a job there is a future, without a job there is slow death of all that makes a man ambitious, industrious and glad to be alive.

I might add that the word 'man' in that statement is not particularly appropriate. In fact it is one of my ambitions to see the word 'manpower' completely eradicated from the dictionary and replaced with something a little more appropriate in view of the fact that well over one-third of the work force is female.

More recently research in Australia and overseas has clearly shown the social, economic and psychological consequences of prolonged periods without work. Indeed, given the overwhelming agreement as to the negative consequences for the societies, the individuals concerned and their families, the general neglect of the problem is difficult to understand.

One of the other unfortunate spin-offs of retraction in the Australian work force and in the cutting back of funds for essential services is that women are being forced more and more into voluntary and semi-voluntary work. In health care, in hostels for homeless youth, in women's refuges, the funding is becoming so pathetically inadequate that to keep these facilities functioning the people who have taken on the responsibilities are being forced to accept far less than awarded wages. Some of them are working appallingly long hours without claiming any sort of overtime. We have a society which is saying: 'Yes, we need the community health services; yes, we need hostels for homeless youth; yes, women's refuges are essential', but declining to set aside sufficient funds so that the workers in these essential services are correctly paid. Not only do we see deteriorating work standards as a result of these sorts of policy but, worse than that, we see a deterioration in the way that women perceive themselves in society and in relation to the work force. They are being told quite clearly that their services are not worth a great deal of money. In some institutions it is even more blatant than that. They are being told that the type of work they are performing can be done at home and therefore it is valued very poorly in the market place.

Opportunities for young women to work could be made available just as they could be made available for young men. But the inadequacies are a great deal more blatant. As I said earlier, the only apprenticeship which is truly open to women is hairdressing. The number of young women who have in the most recent years become pioneers in traditionally male trades are greatly to be commended, but their lives have been very difficult, and it is really only the toughest who have managed to survive. They can still be identified in their ones and twos in occupations such as mechanical engineering and the electrical trades. They are entering in greater numbers trades such as pastry cooking. They are doing optical mechanical work and are becoming dental mechanics and dental therapists.

Women are entering the newer occupations or the ones that have become trades fairly recently, such as horticulture, in slightly greater numbers. I believe there are 12 in that trade in the Australian Capital Territory. But it is still only a trickle rather than a flood, and there is no real encouragement for girls to apply for apprenticeships while so many young men are unable to get the trade training which they traditionally have believed to be their right.

The ratio of occupations actually available to women and to males by comparison is quite startling. When the Australian Statistician takes out his average award wage earnings each quarter he looks at 500-odd common awards for females and 2,500 common awards for males. That gives us some idea of the very restricted opportunities that are available for young women in this society. It seems to me that the Government could do a great deal more than has already been done. Earlier this year a set of equal opportunity guidelines were released with a great deal of pomp and ceremony by the then Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs, Mr Viner.

That particular set of guidelines was designed to apply to small and large industries and to both government and private industries. It was put together as a joint exercise of the women's employment sub-committee of the National Labour Consultative Council which means that it was a tripartite project. In the event and after many drafts and redrafts of those guidelines that sub-committee came up with a document which was acceptable to the Federal Government, to the Confederation of Australian Industry and to the Australian Council of Trade Unions. It was released, as I said, with a considerable amount of publicity and with a complete commitment from those people who are supposed to be able to make things happen. We have seen very little activity in the way of equal opportunity from a government which should be able to put into effect such important principles as equality of opportunity.

In the defence forces in particular, where a very expensive advertising campaign has been conducted over the last few months, we have seen very little extra opportunities made available for young women. The Department of Defence has a number of installations and institutions in which there are quite significant numbers of apprenticeships and training places available, but still there is very little acknowledgement of the fact that young women should be able to apply for a complete range of occupations in the way that young men can do; that in fact their potential is what matters, not their sex.

As I said earlier, I would very much like to see the word 'manpower' removed from the names of all our committees, policies and publications. This word crops up in the weirdest places. I recently saw a manpower study on nursing in Australia, and I cannot imagine anything less appropriate than that particular title.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have male nurses.

—We do have male nurses, I agree, but they are not what one would say in a majority in the industry. I think it will be quite some time before they are. I would very much like to see-I think many people agree with me-a genuine approach to a labour force which consists of the people who want to work, regardless of their sex and age, and emphasis given to the fact that the majority of people, regardless of their sex and age, want to be engaged in meaningful activity.

SPEECH.PARA: Debate (on motion by Senator Haines) adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate is of the opinion that legislation should be introduced to compensate families for the erosion of family allowances, the value of which has been cut by 50 per cent since they were introduced in 1976.

I will not delay the Senate long but as this motion has been on the Notice Paper since November 1980-if it disappears into the lists again it may not appear for another year or so-I think it is important that I make some points on it, even if briefly. The motion, I believe, needs little explanation. The matter has been gone over at length many times in this place. Certainly it is out of date in that it says:

That the Senate is of the opinion that legislation should be introduced to compensate families for the erosion of family allowances, the value of which has been cut by 50 per cent since they were introduced in 1976.
We know that inflation has increased since that time even more. We know that changes have been made in the last Budget to the family allowance scheme, but the motion is still relevant.

In 1976 the Government introduced the present family allowance scheme. The family allowances replaced the old child endowment payments which had been reduced to a derisory level by inflation and they also replaced the children's rebate which not long before that had replaced the old tax deduction system for children. When other family allowances were introduced they were certainly an advance, and the Opposition agreed with them. They represented a positive payment for women. They represented a positive payment to families, some of whom had previously received nothing out of the rebate scheme because they paid no tax. The Opposition was suspicious at the time that the scheme had been in fact introduced as a money saving measure in the long run, because if the children's taxation rebate had been retained and had been indexed with other indexation changes, the cost to the revenue, of course, would have increased. At the time we and others pointed out that family allowances, unless they were increased annually in line with inflation, would quickly erode in value and would in fact end up heading down the same track as the old child endowment payments.

The Government, of course, has always been very strong on claiming that it supports the family and the main item it has always cited in its support has been family allowances. One remembers the continuous self-praise which was heaped on Government members by other Government members in this place at the time of the introduction of the scheme. One can well remember Senator Baume telling us that it was the greatest advance in social security since the introduction of the old age pension.

TALK.START.PARA: —That has not done the pensioners much good, has it?

—No, not at all. But other members of the Government over the years, of course, have had plenty to say about family allowances and about support for the family in general. In 1976, Mr Fraser had this to say:

SPEECH.PARA: We committed ourselves to helping the disadvantaged in ways leaving them the greatest scope for independence. We have acted by introducing our family allowance scheme. This has been recognised as the single most important reform in the Australian welfare system since federation.
That is typical Fraser-type rhetoric. The only person who recognised the scheme as such, in fact, was Mr Fraser himself. Senator Baume had this to say:

It is only occasionally in the life of any government, and not too frequently in the life of any country, that there is a major revolutionary change in the way in which welfare services are provided . . . It is a major endeavour of which my Government will be proud.
Incidentally, Senator Baume was then a back bencher. He went on to say.
I would be proud to be a member of any party which introduced this measure . . .
In 1977 Mr Fraser said:
Family allowances will not be means tested. This is a universal scheme. It represents the most important innovation in welfare for a decade.

The year before he said it was the most important reform in welfare since Federation. Of course he did not say at the time that the Government was not going to increase family allowances for many years. In 1977 Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle said:
Family allowances provide a regular income to mothers and form an important part of their budget.
That is true, and I will have something to say about that in a moment. She went on to say:

Secondly, family allowances had important redistributive effects to low income families. . . millions of Australians properly regard family allowances as the most important innovation in social welfare for decades.

So we have had the statements that it is the most important innovation since Federation, the most important in a decade and the most important for decades. I think it depends on the circumstances and how government supporters feel as to what they say about them. Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle was right of course; family allowances are important. They do provide regular income for mothers and they do form an important part of the budget of any family. That is all the more reason why they should be increased each year in line with inflation, if we are to have this sort of payment.

One of the important things about family allowances is the fact that they are paid to the mother and it is usually recognised that it is the mother's money and the mother's property. Unfortunately, in some families, even some of the more than low income families, family allowances are the only cash money that the mother gets. In some of the poor families in some of our cities family allowances are known as shoe money. The mothers use it to buy shoes, items of clothing and large items which otherwise would be difficult to buy from the family budget.

TALK.START.PARA: —Under those circumstances they should go up by 2 1/2 per cent from 1 January next year.
—That is right. I will come in a minute to how much they should go up. Obviously Senator Haines has a personal interest in this, and I do not blame her.

SPEECH.PARA: During the last election campaign the Prime Minister, Mr Fraser, made another promise about Australian families. He promised that he would use the increased oil revenues to the Government to help Australian families. It was generally considered by those who were in Tasmania at the time where this promise was initially made that this meant that there would be a general increase in family allowances from this large amount of oil money which the Prime Minister said was flowing into the country. What in fact has happened is that in the recent Budget it was announced that the increase in family allowances is to apply only to families with three or more children. Certainly that increase was needed and certainly it will be welcomed in those families. But low income families and pensioner families who have only one or two children will in fact receive no increase under this Budget. Seventy-six per cent of families in this country have two children or less and in pensioner families the percentage is even higher. The Government's major advisory body, the National Consultative Council on Social Welfare, has regularly advocated indexing or increasing family allowances. In its most recent report it stated:

. . . There is a considerable amount of evidence which shows that families with children, are disadvantaged by recent changes in taxation structures and the level of Family Allowance. The Council regards this situation, and especially that of lower income families with children, as serious and requiring redress as a matter of urgency. The Minister for Social Security is urged, as a matter of urgency, to press for an increase in the Family Alowance to restore it to the 1976 real value and, thereafter, for Family Allowance to be indexed according to the C.P.I.

Family allowances in fact represent some sort of recognition of the cost of parenthood, some sort of recognition of the cost of bringing up children. But what the Government has done in this Budget is to increase the benefits only for parents with three or more children-only one-quarter of Australian families. But 1 1/2 million families with only one or two children were totally ignored in this Budget.

Family allowances in relation to which, as has been said, the Prime Minister has made all sorts of extravagant claims have now become a fairly hollow gesture in the support of families in this country. If family allowances had been indexed after their introduction, families with one child would be now getting an extra $9.30 a month, families with two children would be getting an extra $22.37 a month, families with three children would be getting an extra $25 a month, families with four children would be getting an extra $27 a month and families with five children would be getting $30 a month above the increases which have been promised in this Budget. If family allowances had not been allowed to erode in value the Government would be spending another $580m next year instead of the estimated increase of $124m. The money the Government is saving is a direct take from 1 1/2 million families, irrespective of their living standards and the numbers of children. The impression has been given in fact that the Government is rewarding large families regardless of their income, regardless of their means, and it is in fact penalising small families. It was prior to these Budget changes being announced that I put this notice of motion on the Notice Paper. Others have been put on by other senators in this place. There have been repeated calls from all sorts of authorities in the community concerned about the welfare of women, children and families in general in this community for a regular and proper increase in the amount of money paid directly to families through this measure.

It is quite wrong and in fact it is immoral to replace one system with a new system as was done in 1976, to claim that it represents an advance for the families in the community and then to allow the value of these payments to erode in the manner in which they have been allowed to erode by this Government since that time, even taking into account the extra $124m which is to be spent under this Budget. We must remember that these payments provide for too many families in this community an essential supplement to their income. They provide for so many women in this community the only cash payments they get.

That, briefly, is the case that I put before the Senate in asking it to insist on an increase in family allowances to compensate for inflation. One could, as one has done in the past, have spoken at considerable length on this subject, and I dare say that we will all be doing so in the future. But in this debate on a General Business item I have at least expressed the Opposition's concern and expressed a point of view on the need for this very real difficulty facing families to be compensated for.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question is--
—Mr Acting Deputy President--
—I call Senator Haines.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. I thought for a moment that I had become invisible.
—Melded into the background.

—I have a habit of blending into the background. One learns interesting things in the background. I open my remarks as Senator Grimes opened his remarks: I do not intend to take up a great deal of the time of the Senate. However, as he indicated also during his speech, the topic of family allowances is one about which I am particularly concerned. I am concerned for all families of course but for low income families in particular. As Senator Ryan pointed out in an earlier debate some three million people in this country receive benefits of some sort or another and a considerable number more than that fit into what would be termed low income families. These low income families are hardest hit by the present Government's failure to index family allowances. At the same time, they are hardest hit by the imposition of indirect taxes on the necessities of life and conversely they are helped the least by any income tax relief that the Federal Government may see as a way of offsetting sales tax impositions.

SPEECH.PARA: The problem is exacerbated in families in which-Senator Grimes pointed this out-the only independent income of the wife is the family allowance. I am sure that we all have anecdotes, not very amusing ones, that we could tell of families we know in which the woman is kept so destitute for money that she is forced to wait for the family allowance cheque to come through before she can buy some necessities-socks and so on-for her children, simply because husbands often are not responsible enough in their attitude to sharing the income that they bring in. Of course, as a consequence any income tax relief in this sort of family-Meredith Edwards in a recent study has itemised, discussed and dissected the problem-will help only the husband. Then of course there is the rider that the lower the income the less relief that will be provided anyway.

Income sharing in too many Australian families is limited to the situation in which the husband earns the income because he works in the paid labour force whereas the wife stays at home minding the children, looking after the house and subsisting on whatever pittance her husband elects to give her. This means that in many instances the family allowance is a very real source-not of luxury items or even of necessary expenditure on the children-of income for purchasing food and clothing. Of course, what happens in the case of income tax relief in that instance is that the husband gets it; it stays in his pocket to be spent as he wishes. It very rarely gets passed on to the wife, who obviously often needs it more than he does. On the other hand, of course, any sales tax imposition, particularly that on the necessities of life and that affecting requirements for children, is going to be particularly hard on a wife dependent on the family allowance.

It is for that reason that I have been moved tonight to support entirely Senator Grimes's motion calling on the Federal Government to compensate families for the erosion of family allowances, the value of which has been cut by 50 per cent since they were introduced in 1976, and to urge that the Government give due consideration to doing that as a matter of urgency. I of course, accept that it is not possible for any government to hand out money to all and sundry. The simple fact of the matter is that it is just as expensive to clothe and feed-particularly to clothe-the first two children in a family as it is for subsequent children since there is no opportunity for offsetting costs by handing down. Of course, this is particularly true if the first two children are what is commonly known as a pigeon pair; that is, where there is one of each sex. Then there is no opportunity at all for sharing clothing requirements. On behalf of the Australian Democrats I certainly endorse Senator Grimes's motion and urge the Government to give very urgent consideration to removing the anomaly.
Question resolved in the negative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Business of the Senate-Extended Trading Hours

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

In respect of that motion I say it is unfortunate that on a night when General Business is available for honourable senators to speak on some honourable senators are not available to speak. The Opposition is lacking Senator McLaren who, had he been here, I am sure would have participated in the debate on a number of items on the Notice Paper. Some items will not be debated tonight because honourable senators-in particular Senator Mason-are not available to speak. It is unfortunate that given the time available we are not able to go ahead with other important matters of business before the Senate. At this stage of the game it is a question of how we might better fill the time. It is a matter of some regret on the part of the Government that it looks now as though we need to go home.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will address a few remarks on the adjournment, especially as we have the time available. Mr Acting Deputy President, the matter I wish to raise tonight would be very much to your concern because it affects constituents in Victoria. It is almost a condolence speech tonight because whilst the State Liberal Party in Victoria, the Government, has had a terminal disease, yesterday I think it committed suicide. The issue on which it committed suicide, which affects all the constituents of Victoria, is extended trading hours. We had this debate one decade ago. The main point about that debate was that if we had 9 o'clock closing that would be the very last demand of the retail groups. It is a bit like the situation with Hitler after he went into the Rhineland. The last demand would be 9 o'clock closing. As a result of pressure small businesses and unions eventually had to cave in. So we had 9 o'clock closing on Friday nights.

SPEECH.PARA: Just recently a group, I think very well termed the gang of five-Coles, Woolworths, McEwans, Myer and Safeway-launched a very expensive campaign in Victoria. They were going to spend millions of dollars to bring us Saturday afternoon trading. A quote from the Australian gives some indication of just how far they were going to go. The article reads:
Executives of the Myer, McEwan's, Safeway and Coles groups refused to reveal how much the campaign would cost, but said they were prepared to spend as much and fight for as long as it took.

Many of us expected that this would be a long four or five year campaign. However, immediately opposition was voiced from several groups in the Victorian community. First of all small businesses voiced their opposition. Honourable senators opposite quite often in this place and elsewhere express affection for small businesses. Unfortunately that message has not got through to their State colleagues in Victoria. It is not only the small businesses that are opposed to extended trading hours, but also the major union-I think the largest union in Victoria-the shop assistants union, is opposed to bringing in extended hours, for quite obvious reasons I would think. It could be thought that many consumers would love to have extended shopping hours on Saturday afternoon because it would give them more time to shop. They quite readily realise that this will mean increased prices. Whether the Saturday afternoon trading issue is really what the retailers are about I doubt. I noticed that in an interview in the Business Review a chief Myer's executive said:
' . . . but certainly we would be open from 9 a.m. to 9 p.m. on Thursday, Friday, Saturday. We will eventually open on Sunday, but I wouldn't be pressing Sundays all that hard at the minute.'

If the normal cycle is followed what will happen? After 9 o'clock closing being introduced in 1971 and Saturday trading in 1981, I doubt that the retailers will wait till 1991 to get Sunday trading; it will come quite soon. Of course, a lot of pressure was put on the Liberal Party in Victoria to extend shopping hours. The main pressure has come from newspapers in that State. We do not have a great variety of ownership of newspapers. There is the Fairfax group controlling the Age and there is the Herald group. Of course, both newspapers support longer trading hours. I am sure it is only coincidental that half their advertising revenue comes from the gang of five! Nevertheless, in their rather objective way they have approached the issue and given it full support! Pressure was put on to the State Liberal Party so it had a State Council meeting. Mr Acting Deputy President, I do not know whether you were in attendance at that meeting and I am not sure which way you voted but there was a three to one majority for the following motion:
This State Council calls on the Victoria Government to legislate immediately to enable businesses to trade seven days a week with no restrictions on trading hours, should they so desire.

I have some sympathy for the person who moved that motion because he has been fined a lot of money for opening his hardware shop. He is the one Liberal in Victoria who has put his money where his principles are. We have in Victoria a rather strange situation in that unlike the Labor Party, the State Council of the Liberal Party cannot direct its parliamentarians. It can merely threaten to withdraw their pre-selection. However, I invite honourable senators to note that the immediate reaction of the State Liberal Party, bearing in mind that it knew it had a State election coming up, was to deny completely that motion and the Gang of Five's assertions. I propose to quote what was said by the Victorian Minister for Consumer Affairs, Mr Ramsay. No Minister in this Senate, I am sure, would have the gall to make the kind of turnaround that he made. Mr Ramsay said:
The Government is not proposing, nor is it considering, nor would it agree to, any proposal for a general extension in shop trading hours.
I want to make it quite clear that there is no proposal for a general extension to shop trading hours and the Government would not be prepared to agree to one if there was.

Mr Ramsay said that on 16 September. Perhaps a month is a long time in politics, but yesterday the Victorian Liberal Party decided to introduce extended trading hours. True, it is only to be on a four-week basis, but the State Liberal Party was very fair about it. It said: 'Let us take a nice average trading time, the four weekends before Christmas.' I would have been more impressed if it had taken the four weeks before the Grand Final, to see how many shoppers they got through the doors. Nevertheless, that decision has been made. Many questions have been asked as to why the State Liberal Party made it.
Mr Jim Maher, the Secretary of the Shop, Distributive and Allied Employees Association said:
The deal entails the major retailers donating $500,000 to the Liberal election fund. This, I believe, is bordering on a bribe.

Quite clearly, and I must put it on record, the Victorian Liberal Party has strongly denied that claim. I do not assert that it is true, but it is a pity that those suspicions have to surround such a great party. Nevertheless, I believe the truth to be that the Liberal Party of Victoria has sold out to big business. Traditionally, small business has provided the base of its support. We have to admit that quite often the Victorian Labor Party has failed to generate the support of small business in that State. That is a matter we are moving to rectify, but I would have to admit that generally small business has supported the Liberal Party in Victoria. I dare say that half of the branches of the Liberal Party there consist of the proprietors of small business. Staid old Victoria, we might think, would be the last place in the world where we would get a revolution but, whether people realise it or not, a revolution on the part of the small business groups is taking place in Victoria. That revolution will see the current State Liberal Government defeated at the next election, whether it be on 5 December or in May of next year. I thank honourable senators for their attention.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, despite your obvious fears, I do not intend to be provocative. I rise to respond to the words of Senator Messner in moving the adjournment motion. I wish to say, as one who believes that we need to reform the sitting hours of the Senate, that I have no regret at all that tonight we are to get up about 10 or 15 minutes early. Last night we were to have adjourned at 11 o'clock but adjourned at seven minutes past 12. That was not because the Opposition parties did not have their business organised. It was because the Government could not organise its affairs and, in fact, its program has fallen badly behind. That has happened for reasons for which the Government, not anyone on the Opposition side, must take the blame.

SPEECH.PARA: I point out that tonight there were four notices of motion on the General Business paper, two in my name, one in Senator Ryan's name, and one in the name of Senator Mason. Senator Mason could not proceed with his motion. I do not know the exact reason and am not going to say that there were other than proper reasons why he could not do so. Since 8 o'clock tonight I have spoken twice on reports presented, and twice on my notices of motion. Things are becoming so bad that I am not only boring my colleagues, I am also boring myself. I believe that that kind of situation does arise because of certain unfortunate circumstances. I certainly make no apologies on behalf of the Australian Labor Party for what has happened tonight. I am glad that we are to get up early. I wish that we would get up early more often. I wish that the Government would so organise its affairs that we would not have to sit after midnight on various occasions. Senator Messner may want to stay here all night. If he really has urgent business to bring in and wants to sit on, we will co-operate. However, I believe that he was speaking with tongue in cheek. That is one reason for the mildness of my remarks. The second is the look of anguish on the face of the Acting Deputy President when I rose and he thought that I intended to be provocative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today, at Question Time, Senator Crichton-Browne asked me a question without notice about the report on Australia's Aboriginals by the mission of the World Council of Churches which recently visited Australia. I replied that I was writing to a number of church leaders making detailed comments on that report. I undertook to make that document available to the Senate. It has been settled and sent out. I now have it in my possession and can make it available to the Senate. I have not yet shown it to Senator Grimes. It has gone out to church leaders. It might be appropriate for me to seek leave to have it incorporated in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
World Council of Churches Report
JUSTICE FOR ABORIGINAL AUSTRALIANS
General Comments

While the Australian Government cannot agree with everything in the report, it considers that the team, within the time available to it, has attempted to provide a sympathetic commentary on the Aboriginal situation in Australia.

We are saddened that the WCC could find the sorts of things it has talked about in the report. The Australian Government is committed to improving the welfare and standing of the Aboriginal people and in this regard is at one with the WCC.

Need to establish community consensus of Australia's approach to overcome the many problems which Aboriginals face. If the report contributes to that consensus by promoting discussion among the churches and elsewhere in the community, it will have positive value.
Some of the recommendations are an endorsement of the Commonwealth's general policy approach, particularly in terms of directing funds to Aboriginal organsiations.

By way of example, more than 70 per cent of expenditure by the Commonwealth Department of Aboriginal Affairs on Aboriginal programs last financial year went direct to Aboriginal organisations. The proportion of that Department's health funding to Aboriginal Medical Services relative to State services has tripled in the last six years.
The report gives some recognition of the progress made in Australia in the last decade.
The report points to areas of concern which come within the responsibility of individual States.
The Australian Government considers that considerable progress has been made in Aboriginal affairs in recent years, but acknowledges that a great deal more remains to be done.
Commonwealth Relations in Australia
Australian federal system based on a division of powers between the Commonwealth and the States.
Both levels of Government have responsibilities for making laws and for providing services in particular spheres.

There are very considerable problems for the Commonwealth in asserting its powers to make laws for Aboriginal people if those laws result in State Governments withdrawing normal State services from the areas in which Aboriginals are living.
The Commonwealth and State Governments have since 1967 had concurrent powers in respect of Aboriginals.

The Commonwealth for its part wishes to achieve Aboriginal advancement through co-operation-by negotiation and not by confrontation. That is not to say that in an extreme situation the Government would not seek to exercise its constitutional power vis a vis the States. Such a situation to date has not arisen. It would be a judgement to be made at the time. No Commonwealth Government has yet been willing to take such action.

Advances have been made. The Queensland Government has announced its intention to repeal its existing legislation and is committed to consulting with Aboriginal and Islander people about future land and reserve management options.
RECOMMENDATIONS AFFECTING THE COMMONWEALTH GOVERNMENT
I Federal Government Action
LAND RIGHTS
Recommendation 1. that the Federal Government accept its responsibility and use its powers under the Constitution to override racist state legislation, particularly in regard to Land Rights.
Response
The Australian Government prefers to exercise its consitutional powers where possible in collaboration with the exercise by the States of their own powers.
THE LEGAL SYSTEM

Recommendation 2. that the Australian Government more effectively enforce the Racial Discrimination Act 1975. We express deep regret at the recent downgrading of the Commissioner of Community Relations Office, so that no longer will it directly report to Parliament or have a role in public education.
Response
Australia has recently passed legislation, the Human Rights Commission Act 1981, to enable it to meet its obligations under the International Bill of Rights.

Under this Act, the Commissioner for Community Relations will continue to carry out the complaint-handling and conciliation functions associated with administration of the Racial Discrimination Act. Further, the added resources of the Commission will be available to assist as required in the important task of combating racial discrimination and there will be a recourse, as there was not previously, to the Meeting of Ministers on Human Rights on Racial Discrimination matters.

The Government is confident therefore that establishing the Commission will not make less effective the role of the Commissioner for Community Relations in dealing with complaints of racial discrimination.

Recommendation 3. that the Federal Government undertake a commitment to guarantee permanency to the Aboriginal Legal Service network throughout Australia, and ensure there is sufficient funding to enable the service to broaden its functions to extend beyond case by case representation to areas such as legal education for Aborigines.
Response

The Government has endorsed the continued support of Aboriginal Legal Services as specialist legal aid organisations. The Government believes that Aboriginal Legal Services can most effectively meet the legal aid needs of Aboriginals because of their acceptability and accessibilty to Aboriginal people.

The Government appreciates the need Legal Services have for sufficient funds and every attempt is made, within normal budgetary constraints, to meet this need. Legal Services are, of course, not the only Aboriginal organisations needing funds.

The Aboriginal Legal Service in Sydney and the Central Australian Aboriginal Legal Aid Service have made valuable contributions to Aboriginal legal education with specially designed consumer education and racial discrimination programs. It is also part of the duties of every Legal Service field officer employed by Aboriginal Legal Services to provide advice to individuals and groups on matters affecting them. This is a most effective form of education.
Recommendation 4. that Churches and Governments be urged to encourage Aboriginal voter enrolment in order that they may become participants in the democratic processes of Australia.
Response

The Australian Electoral Office is conducting continuing programs of instruction on electoral matters for adult Aboriginals. The program began in June 1979, and is currently concentrating on remote areas of the Northern Territory, Western Australia and South Australia but will be expanded to other areas as resoures permit.
HEALTH

Recommendation 5. that the current Commonwealth Aboriginal Health Funding Policy (which we understand was described in the programme effectiveness review commissioned by the Prime Minister as being ''irrational'') be substantially altered to ensure increased funding for Aboriginal community controlled health services, with reduced funding for the less efficient programmes for Aborigines operated by the State Health Departments.
Response
The Australian Government strongly supports Aboriginal community controlled health services, and overall funding of these services has almost trebled since 1977-78.
Commonwealth will expand support to Aboriginal Medical Services and try to improve the effectiveness of the States' Aboriginal health programs as well.

The Program Effectiveness Review did not describe Commonwealth Aboriginal health funding policy as irrational, although it did note a lack of rationale for the division of funds between States Grants and Grants-in-Aid.

Recommendation 6. that the Federal Government immediately increase and retain adequate levels of funding to Aboriginal community controlled health services, since such services have proved that they can greatly improve the deplorable health situation of Aborigines.
Response
The Government expects that recent trends whereby an increasing number of Aboriginal Medical Services are receiving an increasing level of funding will be maintained.

Recommendation 7. that Aboriginal controlled programmes for Aboriginal medical aides and nurses, appropriate to community health care, be strengthened and that special effort be made to train Aboriginal doctors.
Response
All reports on Aboriginal health urge the need for more Aboriginal medical manpower, and for greater Aboriginal involvement in and control of health services.
The Government strongly supports both recommendations.
Recommendation 8. that traditional medicine and doctors be respected and used in co-operation with modern medical techniques.
Response
Respect and co-operation are absolutely essential and particularly so in traditional communities.
At present we fund the employment of several hundred Aboriginal health workers and camp nurses (e.g. in Western Australia there are 163).
Most are selected by the communities themselves for the job. Communities are always consulted in traditional areas.
Government would like to see more done to improve non-Aboriginal staff awareness of Aboriginal tranditional medicine and skills.
HOUSING

Recommendation 9. that the State and Federal Governments expand Aboriginal housing programmes as a matter of urgency. Even with an expanded programme, it may take a decade or more to catch up the backlog of need.
Response
The Government generally agrees with the approach taken in recommendations.

Funds were increased by additional $20m per annum in 1979-80 and this increase is being followed up for subsequent years. The total funds spend for identifiable programs Aboriginal housing in 1980-81 were $67m.
Recommendation 10. that, where possible, governments implement their Aboriginal housing programmes through Aboriginal housing Associations or Co-operatives.
Response
The number of Aboriginal Housing Associations funded by the Australian Government has increased over the years to a total of 224, at present.

State authorities, which can usually provide houses much more cheaply than Aboriginal Housing Associations, obtain Aboriginal involvement in the planning, location and management of houses through Aboriginal housing boards.
Recommendation 11. that State and Federal Governments involve Aboriginal communities in the planning, locating and designing of houses to be built in their communities.
Response

Two Aboriginal-managed bodies, the Aboriginal Development Commission and Aboriginal Hostels Ltd, are responsible for Commonwealth housing programs for Aboriginals. These bodies have a policy of close consultation with Aboriginal communities and are largely Aboriginal-staffed.
State Governments consult with Aboriginal communities via their Aboriginal housing boards, which are made up of Aboriginal people.
EDUCATION
Recommendation 12. that State and Federal Governments involve Aborigines more fully in the formulation and implementation of policies on Aboriginal education.
Response
It is a major thrust of Commonwealth policy that Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people assume a central role in Aboriginal programs affecting them.
Establishment of mechanisms and processes to ensure that there is real consultation at all levels has involved:

establishment of National Aboriginal Education Committee (NAEC). Established in 1977 the NAEC is a wholly Aboriginal committee which provides the Commonwealth with Aboriginal views on the educations needs of aboriginal people and appropriate methods of meeting those needs. The NAEC has fulfilled an invaluable and highly professional role in providing a federal Aboriginal voice in education.

establishment by Education Departments in all States and the Northern Territory of Aboriginal Education Consultative Groups. A number of the State groups are now moving to establish a regional structure.
encouragement of educational institutions and administrators to seek meaningful involvement of Aboriginal people at community level.
Recommendation 13. that State and Federal Governments adequately fund Aboriginal initiated schools and programmes for the teaching of Aboriginal culture and tradition.
Response

In recent years the Commonwealth Government has supported Aboriginal community-based non-government schools in Townsville (the Black Community School) and the Strelly, Noonkanbah and Lake Gnangara (Nyoongah) Schools in Western Australia. Funds are also now being provided for the christian Aboriginal Parent Controlled School in Coolgardie (WA).
EMPLOYMENT
Recommendation 14. that the Federal and State Governments provide a fixed percentage of work places for Aborigines within the Public Services. A minimum of 1 per cent would be an appropriate figure.
Response

Recruitment and advancement in the Australian Public Service is based on the merit principle. Those applying to fill a position in the Service must meet specific requirements as to qualifications and ability.

Within the limits of this policy, the Australian Public Service has taken several initiatives to promote the entry of Aboriginals into all areas of the Service and their promotion throughout its structure.

As part of the National Employment Strategy for Aboriginals (NESA), the Australian Public Service has indentified approximately 740 positions in Commonwealth Government Departments for which an ability to communicate with Aboriginals and a knowledge of Aboriginal culture are either essential or of value for the performance of the duties.
It is expected that Aboriginals with their backgrounds will have an inherent advantage when seeking appointment to these positions as they become vacant.
Recommendation 15. that Federal and State Governments request all statutory authorities and commissions to make available a similar percentage of positions for Aborigines.
Response

Commonwealth Statutory Authorities have been approached to identify positions in their staff structure for which a knowledge of Aboriginal culture and an ability to communicate with Aboriginals is either essential or of value in the performance of the duties.

They have also been requested to give sympathetic attention to the recruitment of Aboriginals and to provide training opportunities for their Aboriginal employees and for those participating in National Employment and Training (NEAT) public sector training.
The Commonwealth statutory authorities have made an important contribution to NEAT training for Aboriginals.
Recommendation 16. that Federal and State Governments fund special programs to provide necessary training to enable the above targets for Aboriginal employment to be achieved.
Response

The NEAT system has been modified to enable Aboriginals to receive training in the public sector in positions in excess of the normal staff structure of the organizations involved. While the trainees do not have a guarantee of a position at the completion of training their chances of finding employment are greatly improved as a result of the training they have undergone.

As at the end of April 1981, 1164 Aboriginals were receiving training under NEAT on-the-job in the public sector. From the commencement of public sector NEAT to August 1980, 2040 Aboriginals had undertaken such training in the Australian Public Service. Up to August 1980, 220 Aboriginals who had completed NEAT training had entered the Service.
Recommendation 17. that the Aboriginal Development Commission give high priority to funding employment creating projects in outback Aboriginal communities.
Response

The ADC is an independent statutory commission with a variety of responsibilities which include the promotion and assistance of Aboriginal-owned enterprise projects throughout Australia. The activities of the ADC should aid in the economic self-sufficiency of Aboriginals and the creation of employment opportunities.
POLITICAL PARTICIPATION

Recommendation 18. therefore we recommend that Governments and Churches give top priority in their allocation of funds for Aborigines to Aboriginal-initiated organisations such as Land Councils, Medical Services, Legal Services and Co-operatives.
Response

Commonwealth Government Aboriginal Affairs Policy recognises the need to maximise Aboriginal involvement in the design, management and delivery of services and thus accords high priority to the funding of Aboriginal organisations.
There is a steady trend in DAA programs away from States Grants towards Grants-in-Aid to Aboriginal organisations.
II State Government Action
MINING

Recommendation 3. that the freeze on the granting of exploration licences in Arnhem Land be reinstigated for a further 5 years to allow the Aborigines and the Northern Land Council time to work through the changes occurring and establish the means and procedures to protect their interests.
Response
The Northern Land Council is already processing applications for further exploration licences in Arnhem Land and has not sought an extension of the freeze for this area.
LEGAL SYSTEM
Recommendation 8. that State Ministers for Police ensure police recruits receive special training in Aboriginal history, culture, society and language (where no such courses currently exist).
9. that State Ministers for Police increase Aboriginal involvement in all levels of the Police Forces and Police activities.
10. that State Ministers for Police establish appropriate Aboriginal/Police Liaison Committees.
11. that State Ministers for Police adopt the practice of police notifying any local Aboriginal Legal Service of the arrest of an Aboriginal person.
Response
Since 1978 the Department of Aboriginal Affairs has been promoting a special strategy to overcome problems which Aboriginals encounter in their dealings with the law. The strategy encompasses:
the establishment of police/Aboriginal liaison systems;
recruitment of Aboriginal police and police aides;
the institution of training schemes to assist police in recognising the particular needs of Aboriginals;
improvement in police complaints procedures; and
procedural reforms relating to the detention and interrogation of Aboriginals.
These aspects were also covered by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Aboriginal Affairs in its report-Aboriginal Legal Aid.

In reply to that report the Commonwealth pointed out that it has been seeking the co-operation of State and Territory Governments in introducing programs to improve relations between Aboriginals and police. The Western Australian, South Australian and Northern Territory Governments have taken positive steps to recruit Aboriginal police aides and make police officers aware of Aboriginal problems. Formal Aboriginal/police liaison committees have been established in South Australia and Western Australia. The Commonwealth has also introduced legislation which will improve procedures for investigating complaints against officers of the Australian Federal Police Force.
Recommendation 12. that the Churches and Governments be urged to encourage Aboriginal voter enrolment in order that they may become participants in the democratic processes of Australia.
Response
As for I, 4.
HOUSING

Recommendations 13. that State and Federal Governments expand Aboriginal housing programs as a matter of urgency. Even with an expanded program, it may take a decade or more to catch up the backlog of need.
14. that, where possible, Governments implement their Aboriginal housing programs through Aboriginal Housing Associations or Co-operatives.
Response
As for I, 9-10.

Recommendation 15. that State Housing Departments make every effort to use locally available materials and appropriate building methods to cut the costs of 'imported' houses and so enable more houses to be built.
Response

When suitable local materials are available and are cheaper than imported materials these are usually used. The State housing authorities have their own conventions and standards under which economies are sought but cheapness is not the supreme value.
Recommendation 16. that State and Federal Governments involve Aboriginal communities in the planning, locating and designing of houses to be built in their communities.
Response
As for I, 11.
EDUCATION
Recommendation 17. that State and Federal Governments involve Aborigines more fully in the formulation and implementation of policies on Aboriginal education.
Response
As for I, 12.
Recommendation 18. that State Governments involve Aborigines in curriculum formation and introduce Aboriginal culture and languages into school curricula.
Response

In recent years there have been a number of initiatives taken by State Departments of Education and Commonwealth agencies to promote the teaching of Aboriginal studies programs in schools and to increase the availability of resources.
My own Department provides extensive financial support for curriculum development for Aboriginal education.

Recommendation 19. that State Departments of Education develop curricula that more adequately prepare children for life in a multi-cultural society. Departments of Education should seek to eliminate all racist bias in the interpretation of history and to encourage greater understanding of the culture of Aboriginal people. Positive steps need to be taken to create a climate of awareness of the need for racial justice and mutual acceptance.
As for 18, above.
In most States, Aboriginal Education Consultative Groups have been increasingly involved in providing advice on existing materials and listing priorities for further development.

State Ministers for Education have endorsed the principle of the integration of learning about Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders into existing school curricula for all grades, including the development of appropriate specific studies.

The South Australian Department of Education has an Aboriginal Studies Curriculum Sub-committee responsible for the development of programs. The Queensland Department of Education has recommended to schools the ''Guidelines for Studies about Aborigines in Queensland Schools'' produced by the Queensland and Torres Strait Islander Committee advising the Queensland Department and Minister.
Recommendation 20. that State and Federal Governments adequately fund Aboriginal initiated schools and programmes for the teaching of Aboriginal culture and tradition.
Response
As for I, 13.
EMPLOYMENT
Recommendation 21. that the Federal and State Governments provide a fixed percentage of work places for Aborigines within the Public Services. A minimum of 1% would be an appropriate figure.
22. that Federal and State Governments request all statutory authorities and commissions to make available a similar percentage of positions for Aborigines.
23. that Federal and State Governments fund special programs to provide necessary training to enable the above targets for Aboriginal employment to be achieved.
Response
As for I, 14-16.
POLITICAL PARTICIPATION

Recommendation 24. Therefore we recommend that Governments and Churches give top priority in their allocation of funds for Aborigines to Aboriginal-initiated organisations such as Land Councils, Medical Services, Legal Services and Co-operatives.
Response
As for I, 18.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Trade and Resources, upon notice, on 19 August 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the attention of the Minister for Trade and Resources been drawn to a press report on the sixth meeting to negotiate a nuclear safeguards agreement between Japan and Australia.
(2) Is one of the major issues to be agreed on that of physical protection.
(3) Has the Government allowed contracts to be signed and concluded before the safeguards agreement has been signed.
(4) As the first shipment of Ranger uranium is due to leave Australia in March 1982 when will the agreement be concluded.
(5) Will any concessions be given on unresolved safeguards; if so, what.
(6) What changes, if any, have been made to the Australian model safeguards agreement.
(7) Has any agreement been signed or reached to allow re-transfer within Euratom countries.
(8) Under what terms and conditions is Australian uranium now to be exported-in particular the Ranger shipment.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Trade and Resources has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.
(2) The points at issue in the negotiations remain confidential to the two parties.

(3) Yes; I refer the honourable senator to my statement of 1 February 1979, in which I made it clear that, 'companies which have received Commonwealth approval to develop uranium deposits will be allowed to negotiate sales contracts with prospective customers which provide that delivery is conditional on safeguards agreements being concluded with the customer countries before delivery takes place.'

(4) Australian nuclear safeguards policy requires that before shipments of uranium to Japan under contracts concluded since December 1972 can take place, a nuclear safeguards agreement with Japan, consistent with the safeguards policy announced by the Government since the Ranger Inquiry, must be in force. Without such an agreement there can be no such shipments.

(5) No. All elements of Australia's nuclear safeguards policy will be maintained in agreements with potential customer countries. I refer the honourable senator to the joint statement made by myself and the Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs, on 31 July 1981, entitled Nuclear Safeguards Negotiations with Japan.

(6) As explained when the model safeguards agreement was tabled on 25 November 1978, the document was a negotiating tool which simply reflected in draft treaty form the Government's nuclear safeguards policy. The actual safeguards agreements concluded to date incorporate all of the requirements of the Government's nuclear safeguards policy. Variations in points of detail in these agreements reflect particular concerns of Australia's negotiating partners and the need to take account of differing aspects of national fuel cycles and national safeguard systems characteristics.
(7) Yes; Australia's nuclear safeguards agreements with the United Kingdom, France and Euratom envisage retransfers between Euratom countries.

(8) Under Australia's Uranium Export Policy announced on 1 June 1978 uranium can be exported provided that a safeguards agreement is in force between Australia and the customer country, that the uranium is exported from a project which has the status of Government development approval and where the export is in performance of an approved contract. See also (4) above.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 8 September 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Treasurer aware that divorced persons who pay maintenance to their former partners with or without a court order are forced to pay taxation upon the full amount of that maintenance when in fact the money is not and cannot be retained by them.
(2) Is the Treasurer aware that this creates a taxation anomaly in that the receiver of the maintenance benefits from an increase in their income upon which no taxation is paid.

(3) Will the Treasurer review this anomaly and see whether a more equitable system can be introduced whereby people pay taxation on the money actually earned by them plus or minus maintenance payments, especially where court orders are involved.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I am aware that the income tax law does not provide a deduction for maintenance paid by divorced persons to their former partners.

(2) The present income tax law provides exemption in respect of amounts received by way of periodical payments in the nature of alimony or maintenance, to a woman from her former husband, provided that for the purpose of making such payments the former husband has not diverted from himself any income producing assistance or diverted from himself income upon which he would otherwise have been liable to tax. This exemption has been a feature of the income tax law for very many years and, although it has been examined on a number of occasions, successive Governments have not seen their way clear to change the law.

(3) To amend the law in the direction suggested would require a provision to allow a deduction to eligible taxpayers for alimony or maintenance payments to their former partners. This would be contrary to the basic principle of the income tax law that deduction is only allowable for expenditure incurred in gaining or producing assessable income. Expenditure of a private nature is precluded from deduction. Furthermore the proposal would place divorced persons who pay alimony or maintenance to their former partners in a more advantageous position than a married taxpayer who contributes to the maintenance of his or her spouse during a year and who is limited to a concessional rebate of $800 in respect of that maintenance.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 8 September 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: Will the Treasurer consider an extension of the income tax deduction for dependent children after leaving school for the period of time that such dependants are apprenticed and on low incomes, since their parents are forced to heavily subsidise the support for them during what amounts to specialist schooling.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The system of income tax rebates for the maintenance of dependent children under 16 years of age or of dependent student children between the ages of 16 and 25 was terminated in 1976 when the present scheme of family allowances was introduced. Little entitlement existed under that system to claim a rebate for a child engaged in full-time employment because the rebate was reduced by $1 for every $4 by which the child's separate net income exceeded $170.

The allowance of an income tax deduction for children who are apprenticed would necessitate a reconstruction of the personal income tax system. It could not be considered in isolation from the question of an income tax deduction for dependent children generally. Consequently, it would be difficult to justify an amendment to the law solely in the direction sought.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 15 September:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister for Communications aware that service clubs such as Apex, Lions and Rotary are seeking to have their postage rate for regular magazine postings reduced from Category B to Category A.
(2) Have such clubs been unable to reduce their postage from Category B to Category A.
(3) Upon what basis was this decision made.
(4) Is it the case that political parties are able to make use of Category A for their regular magazine postings.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.
(2) Yes.

(3) Eligibility requirements for registration of publications are set out in the Australian Postal Commission Postal By-laws. Unless publications satisfy the special conditions prescribed in the Postal By-laws for inclusion in Category A, publications eligible for registration are classified as Category B publications.

Classification as a Category A publication is restricted to four types of organisations and registration is determined according to the dominant aims, intention or conduct of the person or organisation involved. Moreover, the dominant intentnion of the organisation in publishing the publication is significant.
Category A registration is restricted to publications which are:

published by an organisation, the dominant purpose of which is the investigation or relief of particular disabilities of individual persons. Additionally, the publication must consist mainly of articles relating to that dominant purpose;

published by a religious organisation and contain articles which relate to the interests of members of that organisation. (Publications reflecting social, recreational and scholastic activities are excluded);
a returned servicemen's publication; or
a 'country interest' publication.

(Note: Specifically excluded from registration as Category A publications are the publications of the following types of organisations: social, recreational, motorists, employer/employee business (other than primary production) and professional.)

Australia Post has examined the constituent documents and activities of the Apex, Lions and Rotary organisations. Whilst it is recognised that these organisations are interested in and carry out worthwhile work in respect of the relief of disabilities of individual persons, activities of this nature do not rank as the dominent purpose and function of these organisations. Furthermore, their publications generally reflect the wider-based interests of the organisation and are concerned largely with administrative and social matters. Accordingly, the publications of Lions, Apex and Rotary are not eligible for Category A registration.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 22 September 1981:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mulvihill Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Trade and Resources, upon notice, on 23 September 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: What statistics are available for the Northern Territory for the 1980-81 financial year in addition to those relating to South Australia, New South Wales, Victoria, Queensland and Western Australia, concerning kangaroo meat and hide exports contained in the answer to Question on Notice No. 1048 (Senate Hansard, 15 September 1981, p. 740).

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.
