ANSWER.PARA: Preliminary figures from the Australian Bureau of Statistics for 1980-81 indicate that there were no exports of kangaroo meat or hides from the Northern Territory in that year.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 31 March 1981 (Hansard, page 885) Senator Jessop asked me, as the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Has the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations noted a Press statement indicating that the maritime unions have imposed what they consider to be an effective ban on the shipment of uranium through the port of Darwin? Is it a fact that a large number of unionists in Australia are in favour of exporting uranium in the interests of overseas trade and the consequent benefit to the Australian economy? What is the Government doing to ensure that this valuable overseas trade is safeguarded? Is it a fact that under section 51 (i) of the Constitution the Commonwealth has the power to legislate in respect of matters that interfere with interstate or overseas trade? If these unions persist with their current attitude, will the Government consider introducing appropriate legislation to deal with the situation?
The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

The Australian Government's commitment to the mining and export of uranium is well known and it is continually reviewing options open to Government and the industry to ensure Australian producers are able to meet their supply commitments with overseas utilities. Australia values its reputation as a reliable supplier of resources and the Government has no intention of seeing that reputation marred.

In this regard you will be aware that on 19 June, Mary Kathleen Uranium effected shipment of export contracts through Brisbane notwithstanding certain union action. Similarly Queensland Mines Ltd and Earth Resources of Australia arranged shipment through Darwin on 10 July to meet their obligations to overseas buyers. In both cases, the Government was in close consultation with the companies concerned and was determined to demonstrate that Australia's uranium would be transported by established commercial means.

Despite the attitudes of some members of unions such as the Seamens Union of Australia and the Waterside Workers Federation of Australia, and the current policy of the ACTU which is opposed to uranium mining and export, development of the industry in the Northern Territory has proceeded without major difficulty and current mining operaions at Mary Kathleen in Queensland have not been unduly affected. This demonstrates that a significant sector of the trade union movement is prepared to co-operate in the development of the industry.
The Government will continue to see that the uranium industry is able to flourish and export with its protection.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 31 March 1981, (Hansard, page 884), Senator Gietzelt asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Communications, without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Is the Minister aware that, due to the increasing popularity of subscriber trunk dialling calls, it has become very difficult to make such calls between the hours of 6.30 and 8 each evening and that this results in the first 0 digit in such calls consistently returning an engaged signal during this period? As 000 represents the emergency number for citizens to call the ambulance, fire brigade and police, does the Minister recognise that failure to reach that emergency centre because of the heavy use of the digit 0 could result in tragedy or suffering? Will the Minister take up this problem with Telecom as a matter of extreme urgency, with a view to reaching a solution to the present inability of citizens to use 000 between the hours of 18.30 and 20.00?
The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

Telecom has confirmed that concessional STD rates are proving to be very popular and this is causing some congestion. As a result, it is true that there are problems in some locations in obtaining numbers commencing with '0' including '000'.
I am advised by Telecom that the answer to the congestion is in an expansion of switching and transmission facilities and that priority is being given to these matters.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 19 August 1981 (Hansard, page 47), Senator Townley asked me, as Minister representing the Treasurer, a question without notice concerning ownership of real estate in Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: The Treasurer has provided the following information in answer to the honourable senator's question:

The Government's foreign investment policy provides for the review of proposals by foreign persons to acquire Australian real estate to ensure that where acquisitions occur they are not contrary to the national interest. However, the acquisition of real estate by an individual foreign person up to a cumulative value of $350,000 is not subject to review if the transaction does not fall within the scope of the Foreign Takeovers Act 1975. Accordingly, a person who is not an Australian resident may be in a position to acquire real estate up to a total value of $350,000 without the need to obtain approval under the Government's foreign investment policy.

The exemption from review was introduced in order to simplify the administrative procedures, against the background of experience which indicated that many transactions involving the acquisition of real estate valued at less than $350,000 were made by intending migrants and Australian citizens living abroad.

The Government is aware of comments made in the press and elsewhere expressing concern at the effects of foreign investment on the Australian real estate market. It is, however, important to place in perspective foreign investment in Australian real estate. In 1979-80, New South Wales was the State which attracted most interest regarding investment in real estate by foreign interests. Foreign Investment Review Board and Reserve Bank statistics indicate that in that year there were 269 foreign acquisitions of urban real estate in New South Wales involving a total consideratoin of $97m; figures provided under the Real Estate and Property Act of New South Wales show that in the same year there were in total over 200,000 transactions with an aggregate value of over $9,000m. These data are not strictly comparable but the orders of magnitude implied are not likely to be misleading.

Hence, while the Government does not have specific data on the number of houses owned by persons who do not reside in Australia, the above-mentioned statistics indicate that foreign investment in urban real estate in Australia comprises only a very small proportion of the total.

It is not clear what would be gained by adopting the honourable senator's suggestion regarding social security numbers. Proposals that come before the Government are those involving acquisitions of property by foreign residents. If there are cases in which the question of whether a person involved is an Australian or foreign resident, the advice of the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs is obtained.

ANSWER.TO.QWN.TITLE: Finance: Farmers in Drought Affected Areas

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 19 August 1981 (Hansard, page 52) Senator Walsh asked me, as Minister representing the Treasurer, a question without notice concerning the availability of finance for farmers in drought affected areas.

ANSWER.PARA: The Treasurer has provided the following information in answer to the honourable senator's question:

The States provide carry-on loans at concessional rates of interest to assist primary producers within their areas affected by drought. A State's expenditure on carry-on loans is eligible to attract Commonwealth assistance under the terms and conditions of the natural disaster relief arrangements. Under the arrangements the Commonwealth is not involved in the detailed administration of relief assistance. The States, in line with their overall responsibility for natural disaster relief, administer the provision of carry-on loans and determine the eligibility for assistance of particular primary producers, subject to guidelines agreed to with the Commonwealth.

While detailed information regarding the provision of such carry-on loans would need to be obtained from the States, the guidelines for such loans, while varying in some details from State to State, in general restrict the availability of such loans to primary producers who are:
in necessitous circumstances as a result of the drought;
unable to obtain finance through normal commercial channels;
in working occupation of their properties and who derive their main income from such properties; and
considered to have a potentially viable enterprise.

Following the decision to raise the maximum interest rates which banks can charge on overdrafts drawn under limits of less than $100,000, with effect from 3 December 1980, the Treasurer reached an understanding with the banks that any resulting increases in interest rates would not apply to farmers and others adversely affected by the drought in drought-declared areas for the duration of the drought. The concession is administered by banks on a case by case basis on application by individual borrowers to the respective banks. That understanding was extended to include the further increase in the permitted maximum rate which took effect from 17 August 1981. This concession does not apply where the overdraft limit equals or exceeds $100,000.

These arrangements are intended to provide relief to those who are suffering from the severity of the drought and they are essentially temporary in nature. The majority of farmers pay the same interest rates as other borrowers for their finance, depending, inter alia, on whether the loan is above or below $100,000.

The maximum interest rate for loans of less than $100,000 by trading and savings banks for owner-occupied housing is, as the honourable senator noted, 12 1/2 per cent which is itself a concessional rate when compared to the great majority of other bank lending.

ANSWER.TO.QWN.TITLE: Hire of Telecom Equipment to Deaf People

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 23 September 1981, (Hansard, pages 895, 897-898), Senator Hearn asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Communications, a question without notice concerning the possibility of Telecom making the Porta Printer available on a rental basis.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The Porta Printer, like many other devices available for use by the handicapped, is but one of a wide range of products approved by Telecom for connection to the network and marketed by private enterprise. In the case of the Porta Printer, Telecom is acting as a distributor for the importer-Intercept Communications Pty Ltd-to make it easier for deaf people throughout Australia to obtain and utilise this new product.

Telecom has given consideration to the Honourable Senator's suggestion of making the Porta Printer available on a rental basis but regrets it is not in a position to include in its range of customer facilities special equipment of this type, for which at this stage there is a fairly limited demand. Moreover, even if it were practicable to offer the unit on a rental basis, the level of rental to cover provision and maintenance would be such that it would not be an attractive alternative to the outright purchase of the equipment. It will be appreciated that there are very significant costs in establishing and maintaining the national telecommunications network. It is necessary therefore that the charges for services provided by Telecom be set at rates which enable it to operate as efficiently and economically as practicable. In general, this requires that charges for services be set at rates which reflect the cost of their provision and maintenance.

Telecom is mindful of the needs of the handicapped and is contributing resources and expertise towards increasing the range and availability of products for the handicapped generally. The Government's position on this matter is that financial assistance to make these facilities more readily available to the handicapped should be funded by taxpayers generally through the Government's social security program.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 27 August 1981, (Hansard, page 378) Senator Townley asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Communications, a question without notice concerning public telephones.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

Public telephones are considerably more costly to provide and maintain than subscriber telephone services for which Telecom receives annual rental, and the extra revenue derived from the marginally higher call fees presently paid by public telephone users; 10c compared to 9c falls far short of meeting operating costs. Currently, the loss on the public telephone service is of the order of $37m annually, which means that effectively it is being subsidised by telephone subscribers to the extent of about $7 a year per subscriber's service.

Telecom does not expect the public telephone service to be self-supporting and even with the proposed increase in the public telephone local call fee from 10 cents to 20 cents, which is in line with the CPI increase since 1 October 1974 when the fee was last increased, the service will still operate at a loss.

Against this background, the decision to increase the fee to 20 cents was based on the amount needed to make up at least part of the financial shortfall in public telephone operations rather than on the conversion costs or the level of the public telephone fees overseas. In regard to the latter, in the United States of America the unit fee ranges from 20 to 25 cents, in Canada from 10 to 20 cents, while in the United Kingdom local calls are timed-8 cents for three minutes. It should be noted too that local call areas in Australia are large by world standards.

An increase in the fee to 15 cents was justified some years ago but, at that time, the resources necessary to effect the conversion would have diverted effort from the public telephone modernisation program. That program, commenced in 1976 and involving the progressive replacement of a variety of older type instruments with the Japanese manufactured CT3 multi-purpose units, is nearing completion.

The result is that most areas now have a modern and considerably more reliable public telephone service, and by deferring a fee increase, public telephone callers have enjoyed cheaper calls than would normally have been the case. At the same time, Telecom has avoided the high costs that would have been involved in converting the coin mechanism of a variety of instruments for 15 cent operation and minimised the cost of converting to 20 cent operation. Conversion of the CT3 instruments, a number of which have been modified to accept 50 cent coins for trials of ISD in high usage areas such as international airports, is simpler than many of the older type units.

No public telephones will be made obsolete by the increase in the local call fee. On the other hand, the changeover of public telephones to 20 cents operation will not enable Telecom to liberalise the provision of new installations. It will continue its present policy of providing public telephones where there is a researched need for such facility and where it can expect a return from the facility to cover, to a reasonable extent, the costs associated with its provision and maintenance.

The CT3 units, although relatively costly, have proved considerably resistant to vandalism and for this reason, coupled with the fact that they cater for both local and STD calls as well as telegram lodgements. Telecom prefers to continue its policy of providing these units in all installations in street locations. Because of the vandalism problem, wherever practicable Telecom seeks to meet community needs by leasing to business people coin telephones installed in protected and supervised locations. In these situations less expensive units (Red phones) can be used, though for user convenience it is desirable that they should cater for STD calls as well as local calls. In this regard, tenders are currently being evaluated for a new leased coin telephone which will provide STD facilities, a feature currently not available on Red phones.

Telecom continually monitors technological developments and consideration will be given to introducing any less expensive public coin telephones that become available and which would be suitable for use in Australia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 8 September 1981 (Hansard, page 498) Senator Townley asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: In view of the prevailing high interest rates, will the Government examine the possibility of adding interest to taxation refunds at the same interest rate as the Taxation Office charges on overdue payments? In other words, if a refund is mailed out at the end of August, the taxpayer could expect to receive two months' interest added to that refund. Secondly, if the Taxation Office objects to an item which has been deducted by a taxpayer but which it eventually allows, will the Government consider adding interest to the refunded amount so that the taxpayer is treated in a fair way?
The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

As indicated when the honourable senator's question was asked, the matter of interest being paid by the Taxation Office has been raised previously. I am advised that there is no legislative authority for the payment of interest by the Taxation Office. The matter has, however, been considered by governments from time to time over many years. On each occasion the conclusion has been reached that, because the cost of administering the scheme and paying the interest would need to be passed on to the general taxpayer, incorporation of the concept in the law would not be generally advantageous.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 16 September 1981 (Hansard pages 749-50) Senator Sibraa asked me, as Leader of the Government in the Senate, a question without notice relating to Press reports that an international standard motor racing circuit would be developed on a site known as 'Ravenhall' near Melbourne. I undertook to check the factual contents of the Press article and have the relevant Minister look at the question.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Home Affairs and Environment has supplied the following information in response to the honourable senator's question:
There is no substance in the media reports that the Commonwealth and Victorian governments have agreed to develop the international standard motor racing circuit in Melbourne.

Since the Prime Minister announced in his policy statement on 30 September 1980 that the Commonwealth Government would help establish an international standard motor racing circuit in the Australian Capital Territory, a number of representations proposing alternative sites for the circuit have been received. In the light of these representations, the whole question of the location of the racing circuit has been re-examined by the Government in consultation with the Confederation of Australian Motor Sport (CAMS). A decision on the location of the circuit will be made by the Government in the near future.

The Commonwealth's contribution to the development of the circuit will be under the International Standard Sports Facilities Program for which the Government has provided $25m over the next three years.

The responsibility for programming races at circuits throughout Australia is a matter for the respective motor sport bodies and I am sure that they would take into consideration the significance of the Easter and October motor racing events at Bathurst when determining the timing of any World Driver's Championship event in Australia. As the level of attendance at any sporting event in Australia is beyond the Government's control the question of compensation for the Bathurst City Council is not relevant.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 9 September 1981, (Hansard, page 561) Senator Townley asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Communications, a question without notice concerning registered publications-Category A registration for Lions, Apex and Rotary Publications.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

Australia Post is required, under the terms of the Postal Services Act 1975, to meet all of its operating costs and to provide at least half of its capital expenditure from revenue. In this context, unless otherwise determined by the Government, postal charges are set so that users of the services generally pay the cost of providing them.

The financial burden placed on Australia Post as a result of the very generous concessions provided for registered publications is of particular concern. For 1980-81 the deficit incurred as a result of registered publication concessions has been assessed at around $19 million. A deficit of this order is equivalent to about 1c on each standard letter posted.
Higher registered publications charges, to take effect from 14 December 1981, are not expected to prevent the loss currently generated by the service from rising by nearly $2 million in 1981-82.

Eligibility requirements are set out in the Australian Postal Commission Postal By-Laws. Unless publications satisfy the special conditions prescribed in the Postal By-Laws for inclusion in Category A, publications eligible for registration are classified as Category B publications.

Classification as a Category A publication is restricted to four types of organisations and registration is determined according to the dominant aims, intention or conduct of the person or organisation involved. Moreover, the dominant intention of the organisation in publishing the publication is significant.
Category A registration is restricted to publications which are:

published by an organisation, the dominant purpose of which is the investigation or relief of particular disabilities of individual persons. Additionally, the publication must consist mainly of articles relating to that dominant purpose;

published by a religious organisation and containing articles which relate to the interests of members of that organisation. (Publications reflecting social, recreational and scholastic activities are excluded);
A 'returned servicemen's' publication; or
a 'country interest' publication.

(Note: Specifically excluded from registration as Category A publications are the publications of the following types of organisations: social, recreational, motorists, employer/employee, business (other than primary production) and professional.)

Lions, Apex and Rotary publications are classified as Category B publications. Cateogory B rates offer a very generous concession on ordinary postage rates. (In most instances, Category A registration would provide only a further two cents per copy reduction.)
Australia Post has examined the constituent documents and activities of the Apex, Lions and Rotary organisations.

It is recognised that these organisations are interested in and carry out worthwhile work in respect of the relief of disabilities of individual persons. However, activities of this nature do not rank as the dominant purpose and function of these organistaions. Furthermore, their publications generally reflect the wider-based interests of the organisation and are concerned largely with administrative and social matters.

Accordingly, the publications of Lions, Apex and Rotary are not eligible for Category A registration. They will continue to receive significant concessions, however, as Category B registered publications.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mulvihill Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, upon notice, on 18 August 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) If the Australian Environment Council introduces a voluntary interim notification scheme for new chemicals what assurance or protection exists to deal with pirate manufacturers who can introduce new chemicals without any consideration of their injurious effects on the atmosphere.

(2) Has the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment noted the views expressed in July by the Australian Environment Council in regard to the increasing concentration of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere.
(3) Has the Review of Commonwealth Functions dismantlement of certain Government agencies in any way impaired Federal Government air pollution monitoring.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Home Affairs and Environment has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Australian Environment Council's Interim Notification Scheme for new industrial chemicals being introduced into use in Australia commenced on 1 October 1981. The Scheme is intended to provide Commonwealth and State and Territory Governments with sufficient information to enable an assessment to be made of the possible environmental and health hazards associated with newly-introduced industrial chemicals. It is expected that as an outcome of this assessment process, recommendations as to appropriate management procedures and control measures will be put to the members of the Australian Environment Council. However, as before, responsibility for control of hazardous chemicals is for the most part the responsibility of State and Territory Governments.

(2) The Minister for Home Affairs and Environment is a member of the Australian Environment Council (AEC) and was present at the last meeting of Council which expressed concern with respect to the increasing concentration of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere. The Department of Home Affairs and Environment is currently preparing a review paper requested by the Council. Commonwealth, State and Territory environment Ministers, meeting as the Australian Environment Council, are expected to give further consideration to the issue.

(3) State and Territory Governments have the principal responsibility for monitoring air pollution in Australia. Activities of the Department of Home Affairs and Environment have been directed at coordinating air pollution monitoring in Australia. Encouragement and assistance is given to the State and Territorial Governments for the collection of nationally uniform air quality data so that significant decisions on air quality issues, such as a national strategy for the control of motor vehicles emissions, may be soundly based. These activities have not been impaired as a result of the Government's decisions on the Review of Commonwealth Functions.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 8 September 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does Qantas intend to run a service from Brisbane to Tokyo, or are there any plans to include the port of Brisbane on a return service.
(2) What has been the total number of passengers disembarking in Townsville from the weekly Qantas service from the west coast of the United States since the inauguration of that service.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Approval has been given for Qantas to operate, from 2 September 1981, a once weekly service between Sydney and Tokyo via Brisbane.

(2) A total of 2,944 passengers have disembarked in Townsville on the Qantas service from the west coast of the United States in the period since the commencement of the service on 9 February 1981 to 15 August 1981.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations, upon notice, on 22 September 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister's Department aware of any information, disclosed in submissions to it, advice available to it or public documents such as Auditor General's Reports, which suggests that the department and instrumentalities under the Minister's responsibility are forgoing revenue because of insufficient staff.
(2) How much revenue is alleged to have been forgone.
(3) Approximately how much revenue does the Department estimate may have been forgone.
(4) When did the information or items of information become available to the Minister's Department?
(5) What has been done to improve the situation.
(6) What are the details of any staff rearrangements that have been made as a result of action in this regard.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Industrial Relations has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) to (6) No information available to the Department indicates that any areas under the Minister's responsibility are forgoing revenue because of insufficient staff.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 9 June 1981 (Hansard, page 2795) Senator Kilgariff asked me a question without notice concerning the General Aviation Study. Questions raised sought assurance that the Government would critically examine the report, that movement charges would not prove to be the deathknell of flying training and that, before any recommendations of the Study are introduced, the cost structure of the Department of Transport would be reviewed. In my reply I said that I understood that the Minister for Transport would take such factors as Senator Kilgariff had mentioned into account during the final determinations and I undertook to obtain a reply to the detailed matters raised.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Transport has provided the following information in response to Senator Kilgariff's question:

The Government has decided not to accept the recommendations of the report in relation to cost recovery. However, the level of air navigation charges for the general aviation sector will continue to be considered annually in the Budget context.
